IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cdk5 is a brain expressed serine/threonine kinase known to regulate negative valence states in male rodents, yet very little is known about the role of Cdk5 in female brain or regulation of the Cdk5 gene in either sex. Gene expression changes conferred by molecular alterations to the genome, known as epigenetic modifications, underlie affective states, including reward seeking and fear learning and memory. There is growing evidence that these changes, and the physiological responses to stress, are regulated differently in men and women. This proposal specifically manipulates Cdk5 in order to pinpoint the role of epigenetic regulation of this single gene following different types of stress. The experimental strategy will complement 30 years of existing literature on the role of Cdk5 in male brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative CVST has a high morbidity and mortality in young adults despite anticoagulation treatment. Herein, we propose the development of a predictive score for early identification of high-risk patients using novel biomarkers and advanced analytic methods. The score will be potentially used as a stratification tool to evaluate new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is relevant to public health because stroke is a leading cause of long-term disability and death in the United States and better treatments are needed. Building on our preliminary research showing that blood pressure variability after stroke may be harmful, in this study we will prove this relationship to be true and define critical elements for a future trial dedicated to lowering blood pressure variability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The world is facing a growing epidemic of obesity which, in addition to other consequences, increases the risk of death due to breast cancer metastasis. The proposed studies will elucidate key mechanistic details related to the interaction of a low oxygen environment (hypoxia) with the proinflammatory cytokine interleukin 6 that work in tandem to support aberrant lipid metabolism in obesity-driven metastasis. The results of these studies will contribute to making appropriate, targeted recommendations for preventing obesity-related metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults are less likely to disclose suicide ideation to others, seek help for it, or engage social contacts into suicide safety planning. This study combines lab-based and mobile health tools to investigate social cognitive abilities and biases that may interfere with motivational systems involved in help seeking, within the networks of at-risk older people. The goal of the study is identify new targets for interventions that increase help seeking behavior for the benefit of late life suicide prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dynamic and differential RNA expression and processing among neuronal types underlies differences in neuronal development, fate, and the acquisition of sexual dimorphisms. This study will develop the first complete understanding of these dynamics, fundamental knowledge that is critical to understanding how differential gene expression and splicing are regulated to achieve cellular and functional diversity in the nervous system. The proposed research is relevant to public health because these diversities contribute to neuronal function, structure, and disease susceptibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The Portland Alcohol Research Center (PARC) will perform in-depth genetic analyses to evaluate the role of a 4-part brain signaling complex known as the tetrapartite synapse (the pre-synaptic neuron, post-synaptic neuron, astroglial processes, and extracellular matrix) in the risk for chronic heavy alcohol use, consequences of use, and individual variation in alcohol consumption despite high genetic risk. Comprehensive research will be performed in male and female mice and monkeys that will evaluate the constituents of this signaling complex, in addition to its relationship with drinking behavior and cognitive performance. Findings will be integrated to provide comprehensive information relevant to disease prediction and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Many brain disorders are associated with circadian and myelin phenotypes, but how these two biological processes intersect during brain maturation remains unknown. The proposed experiments aim to deepen our understanding of the circadian mechanisms mediating myelin-forming cell dynamics and myelination in neurodevelopment and early adulthood. Through the development of new model systems allowing us to probe the interaction of both environmental and molecular circadian disruption and developmental and adaptive myelination, we will contribute a more comprehensive understanding of myelin biology, ultimately providing novel chronotherapeutic strategies targeting the dysmyelination associated with numerous brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Microphysiological tumor systems, which are small human tumors grown outside the body, are useful models for cancer research, drug discovery, and personalized therapy, but they lack clinically relevant imaging endpoints. This project will develop a quantitative and high-resolution approach to image these microtumors using the existing array of clinical PET radiotracers, thus bridging the gap in physical scale that exist between clinical tumor imaging and microphysiological tumor models. The approach will be demonstrated in a pilot study in a cohort of head-and-neck cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to investigate the role of a nucleic acid-like protein modification, poly ADP-ribose (PAR) which can drive protein aggregation in stress granules and thereby contribute to age dependent neurodegenerative diseases. The knowledge gained from the proposed study will reveal the underlying mechanism by which PAR nucleates neurotoxic protein aggregation, which can lead to therapy development against the incurable ALS, FTLD, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many states are aggressively reforming their long-term services and supports systems by constraining the growth of nursing homes and expanding the availability of home and community-based services (HCBS), especially through the growth of Medicaid waiver programs, which intend to delay or avoid nursing home admission for individuals living at home and at risk for nursing home care. This study will determine how living with Alzheimer's disease and related dementia affects health service utilization, achievement of goals of care, and informal caregiver support systems, in a statewide, racially and ethnically diverse population of older adults enrolled in a Medicaid waiver program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will provide critical information about home- and community-based services (HCBS) use, health outcomes, and health care costs for people with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD). This knowledge will help inform state Medicaid policymakers who are seeking the most effective approach towards HCBS and ultimately improve health outcomes for people with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The interdisciplinary Cell, Molecular, and Developmental Biology (CMDB) T32 training program is dedicated to training highly motivated students in cell, molecular and developmental mechanisms that contribute to normal and aberrant physiology, disease pathogenesis, and birth defects. The CMDB T32 program selects exceptionally talented predoctoral trainees that matriculate into the UAB Graduate Biomedical Sciences (GBS) umbrella program to provide them with enhanced training and career development opportunities, along with a flexible curriculum that can be tailored to the individual research and career goals of the trainee. Our overarching goal is offer a comprehensive and rigorous training program that nurtures the maturation of students into creative, independent-thinking, research scholars in the biomedical sciences.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Cell, Molecular, and Developmental Biology
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - A[TWD-A]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: Providing high quality home and community-based care (HCBS) for persons with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias is a national priority. Despite this priority, very little is known about the relationship between HCBS and person-reported outcomes (i.e., value of services from the client perspective) for those with and without AD/ADRD and whether person- reported HCBS outcomes influence health care use. Our proposed study will be the first to provide data on these complex relationships and will help inform the design of HCBS programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Doxorubicin is a wonderful anti-cancer drug. Unfortunately, a major side effect of this drug is causing a muscle dysfunction in patients suffering from cancer in the U.S. and around the world. Doxorubicin induces inflammation by attracting M1 macrophages is now becoming a considerable cause of development and progression of muscular dysfunction and fatigue. We report as a preliminary data that presence of M1 macrophages causing immune mediated cell death called pyroptosis and adverse muscle remodeling. We have generated ES-Exosome from ES cells which could be an excellent therapeutic option as these cell free components don't form teratoma and are capable to attenuate pyroptosis and adverse muscle remodeling is proposed in the grant. Overall if successful, ES-Exos will provide protection in DOX induced muscle toxicity by inhibiting pyroptosis and adverse muscle remodeling at short and long term of the disease. Overall if successful ES-Exos could have broad therapeutic option treating in doxorubicin induced toxicity in related diseases as well as in various other muscle dysfunctions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A fundamental trait of bacterial pathogens is the ability to scavenge essential nutrients from the host environment. Sulfur is a critical requirement for bacterial growth, but how Staphylococcus aureus acquires sulfur during infection is not known. The objective of this proposal is to establish the strategies utilized by S. aureus to obtain sulfur from the host environment, potentially revealing new therapeutic targets to combat antibiotic recalcitrant infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related alterations in attention likely contribute to changes in both spatial representation and episodic memory formation, negatively impacting goal-directed behaviors. The proposed research will leverage immersive virtual reality spatial paradigms along with behavioral and neural markers of attention to examine a) whether and how attention impacts spatial representation and navigation, b) how attention-mediated changes to spatial representation influence episodic memory encoding and memory integration, and c) how age-related cognitive change relates to disruptions in neural systems of attention and episodic memory, and their interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative We aim to understand the pathogenesis of C9orf72 mutation-induced frontotemporal dementia (C9-FTD), a fatal and incurable neurodegenerative disease. C9-FTD involves the loss of specific neuron populations (vulnerable neurons) and the appearance of disease-associated microglia (pathologic microglia), but the molecular profiles of these cell types are unknown. This application proposes to identify the molecular profiles of vulnerable neurons and pathologic microglia as well as these cells’ spatial proximities and interactions in disease in order to define novel treatment targets for C9-FTD and potentially other neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE 4’-ethynyl-2-fluoro-2’-deoxyadenosine (EFdA, also known as MK-8591) is an extremely potent inhibitor of HIV, including drug-resistant viral strains, and blocks the virus by a different mechanism than all currently approved anti-HIV drugs. This project will determine the EFdA mechanism of action in the context of HIV infection in cells, and will also study the factors that affect development of high-level HIV resistance to EFdA, why certain HIV viruses that are resistant to other approved antivirals are hypersusceptible to EFdA, and address EFdA’s efficacy and resistance profile in various HIV subtypes. These studies will provide important insights on the design of combination therapies of EFdA with other approved antivirals leading to optimal treatments for HIV-infected patients around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) currently affects millions nationally with no clearly effective treatment that can target disease pathology. This proposal utilizes biophysical, structural and cell biological techniques to test a novel hypothesis that will aide our fundamental understanding of unique structure-function relationships of the protein tau by studying its canonical and disease-associated interactions. Our research will contribute to the field’s understanding of the mechanistic changes in tau behavior that drive AD and other tauopathies and will facilitate the development of novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of tau-based neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcoholism is chronically relapsing disorder characterized by behavioral, cognitive, and neurobiological dysfunctions. The importance of the cholinergic circuits of the brain in alcoholism is accepted and has been studied; however, few of these studies have examined the striatal cholinergic interneurons, including any potential subtypes. Therefore, the experiments proposed in this project will lead to a better understanding striatal cholinergic interneurons broadly, and more specifically, how they are affected by acute and chronic alcohol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will elucidate the DNA damage response properties of testicular germ cell tumors (TGCTs) and the cells from which they arise, which will inform the mechanisms underlying their remarkable sensitivity to conventional genotoxic chemotherapy. Understanding the basis of TGCT chemosensitivity will apply broadly to the development of treatments for the many other cancers that do not respond favorably to chemotherapy. Additionally, investigating the malignant transformation of pluripotent cells will be important for improving stem- cell based therapies, which carry the risk of tumorgenicity.

PROJECT NARRATIVE The data collected from the proposed studies will increase not only our understanding of the behaviors associated with alcoholism and PTSD comorbidity, but also how alcohol use during adolescence may alter a person's ability to successfully cope with a traumatic event later in life that can lead to PTSD and abuse of alcohol. The findings will also provide a better understanding of the brain changes associated with these disorders that will help develop new and more effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given that the current cost of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and dementia care is currently estimated at over $216 billion annually, treatments to delay or prevent AD-related cognitive decline would alleviate the immense financial burden and emotional toll currently facing patients and caregivers. However, without a better understanding of the genetic and neuronal mechanisms that underly AD, development of these treatments will not be possible. In the short term, I will determine if the gene Dlgap2 is a genuine mediator of AD-related cognitive decline and provide insight into dendritic spines as a therapeutic target of AD; in the long term, I will develop a better understanding of the synaptic mechanisms that contribute to AD and build a framework for future AD research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Previously our lab observed the accumulation of misfolded lysosomal hydrolases in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), ER fragmentation, and an inability to induce the unfolded protein response (UPR) in dopamine neurons differentiated from Parkinson’s disease (PD) patients harboring mutations in alpha-synuclein. This failure to effectively clear aggregated proteins in the ER may in part be due to defects in the ER proteostasis pathway ER-phagy, a form of macroautophagy wherein regions of proteostatic stress in the ER are selectively degraded. We intend to test whether ER-phagy plays a role in PD pathogenesis, and if so, whether restoring functional ER-phagy can alleviate ER stress and improve neuronal survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative During pregnancy, Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) caused by infection with Zaire Ebola virus (EBOV), leads to ~100% loss of the fetus or neonate with or without the additional loss of the mother. This project will begin the process of understanding the pathogenesis of EBOV during pregnancy by determining the route and mechanisms of infection in placental tissues. This data from this project will add to the knowledge regarding viral infections in placental tissues and the barrier role of the placenta as well as the development of potential therapeutics or treatment protocols to improve the maternal and fetal outcomes of EVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia with no clearly effective disease modifying therapies. Alterations in glial lipid metabolism have been shown to be central to AD pathogenesis, and the present study is designed to evaluate the effects of modulating microglial lipid buffering capacity on inflammation and disease progression in a mouse model of tauopathy. Our findings will inform the development of novel classes of microglia-targeted therapies that may slow the progression of neurological diseases characterized by aberrant lipid metabolism like AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapy is a promising antitumor therapy, but the success in solid tumors especially prostate cancer has been limited. While current immunotherapies focus on targeting the T cell compartment, combination therapies that incorporate activation of the myeloid compartment could increase the efficacy of immunotherapy in solid tumors. I have profiled single cell transcript and protein expression in peripheral immune cells in a prostate cancer cohort during combined immunotherapy treatment, and I will use this dataset to investigate the heterogeneity of the myeloid compartment and how that heterogeneity relates to treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RESEARCH NARRATIVE Follicular lymphoma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma represent the two most common forms of human B cell lymphoma and remain incurable in a significant fraction of patients. This research proposal seeks to elucidate how missense mutations of the CREBBP acetyltransferase, the second most frequent genetic alteration in these tumors, contribute to malignant transformation by reprogramming the pre-neoplastic germinal center B cells as well as the immune microenvironment. The outcome of these studies is expected to further our understanding of the biology of these common cancers and to pave the basis for the development of improved biomarkers and therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the first hours of development, the embryo undergoes rapid cycles of DNA replication followed by high-level transcription of sets of genes required for subsequent developmental processes. We will test the hypothesis that pioneer transcription factors like Zelda in Drosophila play a dual role, first to mark origins of DNA replication, then at those same sites, transcriptional activation. Our findings will have broad implications for pioneer factors in coordinating developmental events in more complex organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  This work investigates several fundamental and conserved processes used by bacteria for the acquisition of new genes and traits via horizontal gene transfer, for responses to cellular stresses, and for growth and propagation. Our focuses on the mechanisms controlling conjugation (a prevalent type of horizontal gene transfer) and the interplay between conjugative elements and bacterial viruses (bacteriophage), and between mobile genetic elements and their host cells. This work is directly related to mechanisms of bacterial survival, horizontal gene transfer, and competition between selfish DNA elements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Stresses such as increased heat and oxidation cause condensation of protein and RNA into aggregates which drive a universally conserved response. Following our recent discoveries that these aggregates, long thought to be toxic, are instead often adaptive, we are pursuing an understanding of the novel functions and regulation of these adaptive condensates in the response to heat shock. We use integrated methods, from biochemistry to cell biology, to understand these phenomena in molecular detail, continuing our longstanding work in a budding yeast model and extending our efforts to understand physiological temperature-dependent responses in the immune system during fever.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The non-canonical NF-κB signaling pathway controls a major branch of immune cell activation and drives essential biological processes including lymphoid organogenesis, B-cell maturation, osteoclast differentiation, and inflammation in mammals. This proposal examines the molecular mechanisms of non-canonical NF-kB suppression by the SIX-family transcription factors. A deeper understanding of the biochemical and cellular mechanisms of SIX proteins revealed by this work will lead to a greater understanding of the innate and adaptive immune system that controls human infectious disease and will reveal new therapeutic opportunities promoting resolution of chronic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Interoception is the sense of the physiological condition of the body and critical for maintaining homeostasis and regulating cognitive and emotional processes. Interestingly, vagal stimulation (major interoception input) modulates intractable chronic pain in patients. Lack of understanding about neurobiological mechanisms whereby vagal activity modulates chronic pain poses a significant hurdle for improving chronic pain management through the regulation of interoceptive inputs. Here, we focus on studying neural mechanisms of vagal modulation in a mouse model of temporomandibular disorders (TMD). TMD are the most prevalent orofacial pain conditions that involve the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), chewing muscles, and associated head and neck musculoskeletal structures and patients with TMD suffer from myofascial pain, limited mandibular motion, and TMJ sounds and the prevalence among U.S. adults is about 25% who experiencing TMD at least once in their lifetime and among them over 35 million suffer from TMD pain and resulting severe psychosocial and economic burden is more than $60 billion per year. Here, we will study functional neural mechanisms of interoception inhibiting pain. Our central hypothesis is that vagal interoceptive circuits intersect with peripheral and central nociceptive pathways to inhibit pain from TMJ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Determining the genetic factors underlying human disease will support needed development of therapeutics and interventions. A critical step toward this is identifying the biological mechanisms and target genes that disease-associated genetic loci perturb, especially considering that most disease loci are not within the boundaries of any known gene. This proposal describes an integrative approach leveraging functional data to determine the target genes, cell types, and pathways affected by both rare and common genetic variation in the human population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of this project is to expand our understanding of the Moloney murine leukemia virus – prototype of the simple mammalian retroviruses, and a model for the human retroviruses HTLV-1 and HIV 1 – and of the host regulation of viral DNA expression. We are especially focused on characterizing the mechanism of action of specific host factors that we have identified that restrict virus expression in embryonic cell types. The work will reveal new aspects of the host machinery that can induce and maintain the latent status of integrated proviral DNAs and will inform new approaches to treatment of viral leukemias and AIDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antiretroviral therapy has greatly improved the lives of HIV positive patients, reducing their risk of progressing to full blown AIDS and the likelihood that they will pass the virus to their partners. However, delayed diagnosis, interruptions in treatment, or the emergence of drug resistant virus all put these patients at risk. The aim of this project is to develop a new HIV test that can be performed by an individual in their own home or other non‐clinical environment without specialist equipment. To do this we will exploit a novel molecule, found only in sharks, for the efficient detection and quantification of virus in unmanipulated samples such as blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Technological advances have fueled the ascent of personal genomics and the promise of precision medicine. To unlock this potential, we must first understand how the environmental and genetic interactions unique to each individual contribute to variation in disease-related traits. This is the theme of my research program, which I advance using innovative strategies to dissect complex trait variation; the ultimate goal is prediction of an individual’s disease risk from his or her genome sequence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unique genetic alterations promote a characteristic pseudo-hypoxic response and metabolic defects in kidney cancer cells. How these cell intrinsic mechanisms affect immune cell function and therapeutic resistance in the tumor microenvironment (TME) is not understood. This study will highlight a novel organoid model of kidney cancer and demonstrate the pseudo-hypoxic contributions on the TME to uncover new strategies for modulating and improving anti-tumor immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a devastating neurodegenerative disease without cures. Recent progress has revealed stress granules as the cellular locales of the formation of protein aggregates and disease development, renewing efforts to understand the molecular basis of pathogenesis. We will use biophysical experiments, simulations and theory to understand the physical principles underlying the formation of protein aggregates in stress granules overcoming critical bottlenecks for combatting the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is a highly heritable neurodevelopmental disorder, most often identified at school-age after impairment is present; therefore, early precursors to the development of ADHD need to be identified as a first step to developing early interventions aimed at preventing the disorder. This K23 career development award will aid in establishing Dr. Joseph as an independent physician-investigator equipped to investigate neonate and infant markers of inattention to address the intergenerational transmission of ADHD. Research suggests that the development of attention can be influenced by the parent’s behaviors, although little is known about the developmental trajectory in offspring of parents with ADHD; thus, the knowledge gained from prospectively following neonates, at high and low familial risk for ADHD, to toddlerhood will inform our understanding of (1) the clinical predictive utility of early indices of attention, (2) the influence of parenting behavior on offspring attention that may ultimately serve as an intervention target, and (3) when to intervene to promote the development of attention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor postnatal growth is a common problem among extremely preterm infants that is associated with adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes. This work has potential to lead to novel approaches to optimize growth and development of preterm infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Hispanic-Serving Institutions are institutions of higher education that prioritize supporting low-socioeconomic position students of color through their educational experiences; these institutions’ efforts may also promote health among diverse young adult populations. The design of this study allows us to longitudinally examine the economic and educational determinants of cardiometabolic health among diverse emerging adults, which are not yet comprehensively understood. Our study will help identify modifiable risk and protective factors from the economic and education sectors that could be targets for interventions to promote positive health behaviors and reduce risk of negative cardiometabolic health outcomes among emerging adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ovarian cancer and pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) are two of the most lethal cancers and notoriously resistant to standard therapies. We have developed a dual-domain therapeutic, S2/IAPinh, that selectively delivers a drug cargo into cancer cells and induces enhanced tumor cell death. Recent experimental evidence suggests that S2/IAPinh, while far more effective than IAPinh alone, is insufficient to eradicate the tumors as a monotherapy. Here, we will explore a number of new avenues for successful combination cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative Given the complexity and multimodal nature of the input to the child, learning language should be a challenging task, but most young infants proceed in achieving language competence with enormous speed. We hypothesize that the alignment and use of multimodal cues, including touch, in the input may play a key role in this achievement and explore this hypothesis in a series of experiments. The primary translational signiﬁcance of this work is the potential to provide insights into language learning mechanisms, which ultimately could impact treatment protocols and interventions or parent-training programs with high-risk infants consistent with the mission of NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE Increasing access to tobacco cessation medications is a key part of U.S. health policy’s strategy for reducing smoking rates, especially for smokers with low incomes. The central objectives of this project are to estimate the impact of prior authorization requirements for tobacco cessation medications in Medicaid programs on the use of cessation-related health care treatment and to understand prior authorization’s implications for disparities in the use of tobacco cessation medications and for potentially contraindicated prescriptions. The findings from this study will provide public health stakeholders with information that can be used when making decisions about whether to require prior authorization for tobacco cessation medications and, conditional on requiring prior authorization, to set up systems and rules that improve the prior authorization process for tobacco cessation medications.

The proposed research will evaluate how mutation in a chromatin regulator independently alters brain development and synaptic function in the brain. A secondary aim of this work is to test a novel therapeutic option for treating this disorder that could be rapidly translated to the clinic if our work is successful.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the integrity of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is critical for numerous cellular processes, mtDNA is the target of highly disruptive truncating mutations in over 10% of all cancers. Understanding the function of truncating mtDNA mutations has been dually impeded by a lack of experimental tools to engineer mtDNA mutations and a lack of analytical methods to study the sensitivity of mutant phenotypes to mutation dosage (i.e. heteroplasmy). Here, we propose an innovative and multidisciplinary approach that overcomes these challenges by combining a novel genetic engineering technology (the DddAtox cytosine base editor, DdCBE) with integrative computational analyses to establish the function, dosage sensitivity, and therapeutic vulnerabilities of one of the most common and underexplored genetic insults in the cancer genome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current functional neuroimaging studies target either the brain or the spinal cord, but usually not both at the same time because simultaneous acquisitions from brain and spinal cord are challenged by several obstacles posed by conventional MRI modalities. In this project we will exploit a novel MRI pulse sequence entitled Multi- Band SWeep Imaging with Fourier Transformation (MB-SWIFT) that overcomes such challenges and will allow for the first time simultaneous fMRI of brain and spinal cord. The proposed study will prove that MB-SWIFT is a transformative approach for conducting unprecedented investigations of the central nervous system, crucial for advancing knowledge in several areas of research including spinal cord injury, neurodegenerative diseases, pain and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Anhedonia is a transdiagnostic symptom of multiple psychiatric disorders, including depression, schizophrenia and post-traumatic stress disorder, which are linked with increasingly high levels of economic burden related to substantial health care costs and unemployment. Anhedonia is independently associated with substantially increased risk of suicide, treatment resistance and reduced quality of life, yet its biological basis remains elusive. We will use computational models of behavior and cutting-edge neuroimaging techniques in combination with artificial intelligence approaches to biologically define anhedonia, with the ultimate goal of improving clinical practice for anhedonia through biologically informed clinical decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Oral anticancer agents (OAAs) account for over half of the new cancer treatments approved by the Food and Drug Administration. For older adults who are taking OAAs and self-managing care in the home environment, research is crucial for the development of supportive interventions to improve communication, information exchange, and self-efficacy in the management complex OAA and related symptoms/side effects. This study will explore concordance of the timing, frequency, and continuity of information sharing, communication, and knowledge gaps between patients, caregivers, and oncology health care providers specific to OAA treatment; examine patient-reported outcomes associated with OAA self-management; and to explore perceptions of supportive web-based program design features that may assist with the development of future intervention tool.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood, and despite significant advances in the diagnosis and treatment of this disease, the prognosis for many patients remains poor. Overexpression of multidrug resistance protein 1 (MRP1) is strongly associated with neuroblastoma drug resistance and reduced patient survival. This proposal seeks to identify the structural basis by which MRP1 promotes neuroblastoma drug resistance, and completion of the proposed work will lay a foundation for future therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Many animals perform complex behaviors that are the result of varying arousal/motivational states, though identifying these states by behavior alone is challenging. In turn, how these states influence specific neuronal circuits to alter behavior is diffifcult in complex brains, but tractable in smaller invertebrate brains. We propose to use orb-weaving spiders to investigate how neuromodulation organizes behavioral states, and nematodes to understand how these states alter neuronal architecture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel diseases affect 1 in 200 Americans. Human studies have elucidated that signaling between key immune cells and stromal cells drive disease pathogenesis and determine response to therapy. This project will utilize an important pre-clinical genetic mouse model with direct relevance to at least 10% of patients with IBD to study these signaling pathways and interactions with micronutrient (zinc and manganese) availability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Diagnosing TDP-43 proteinopathy in living patients with frontotemporal lobar degeneration or Alzheimer’s disease is difficult due to the heterogeneity of clinicopathologic relationship, and molecular composition of TDP- 43 pathology. The purpose of this study is to elucidate a novel toxic TDP-43 species and its association with pathology and neurodegeneration. The long-term goal is to develop a biomarker that can predict the presence of TDP-43 in living frontotemporal lobar degeneration and Alzheimer’s disease patients, which will have a significant impact on future therapies for both diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans differ in their susceptibilities to disease, and individual cells within a population of infectious microbes or a tumor differ in their susceptibilities to drugs. Understanding the causes of differences within populations is therefore of great importance in human health. By developing and applying methods for simultaneous measurement of many individual cells, this research program aims to advance understanding of the complex ways genetic and nongenetic factors combine to make individuals more or less similar to one another.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a full-time eight-week summer research experience program at Howard University, aiming at engaging, recruiting and training undergraduate students from underrepresented minority and other disparity populations into minority health care and oral health disparity research. The program is designed to be a specialized didactic and mentored academic program with tailed research and education activities. We will also develop a highly networked team of motivated and skilled mentors from various disciplines by establishing a strong partnership between Howard and Johns Hopkins Universities. By participating in multi-disciplinary research projects and education events, the students will gain valuable research experience and knowledge, and promote them into advanced education in oral health disparity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most deaths related to hematologic malignancies such as multiple myeloma (MM) or myeloid leukemias are caused by the inability of applied systemic treatments to eradicate all tumor cells and prevent formation of treatment-persistent residual tumor cell populations that will become the “seed” for eventual relapses and inability to achieve curative outcome. A better understanding of how this “minimal" residual disease (MRD) in MM or leukemia persists through pharmacological therapies is essential to develop new treatments that can decrease the burden of cancer-related deaths. This project seeks to study MM or leukemia cells which have developed persistence to chemotherapy or other drugs with cytotoxic activity against tumor cells and we will specifically characterize the mechanisms which regulate whether these MRD tumor cells will respond or not to natural killer (NK) cells, in order to better inform the development of future immunotherapies that can eradicate the residual malignant cells of MM or leukemias and bridge the gap towards curative outcomes for these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The goal of this application is to extend and enhance our current highly successful R38 program allowing for continued identification and engagement of those pediatric and medicine residents with the aptitude and passion to become clinician-scientists through our mentored training program. We will focus on research themes where Vanderbilt has internationally recognized programs of discovery combined with a record of sustained excellence in research mentorship. Each R38 Resident Investigator will have an individualized training program developed by the Preceptors and Training Directors in collaboration with a multidisciplinary scientific oversight team, and will be supported by a broad array of institutional and departmental resources with the expectation that graduates will transition to well-established long-term clinician-scientist career development programs at Vanderbilt or other research intensive institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Suicidal ideation and behavior are increasingly serious public health concerns, particularly for individuals recently discharged from psychiatric hospitalization for suicidal ideation or behavior. We propose the development of an integrated, multimethod model of acute suicide risk emphasizing proximal (i.e., momentary affective, cognitive, and contextual) risk factors and the moderating effect of more distal risk factors, based on data collected from a combination of intensive ecological momentary assessment, digital phenotyping, laboratory-based behavioral assessments, and traditional cross-sectional measures (i.e., clinical interviews and self-report questionnaires). We believe that this integrated multimodal approach will yield improved prediction of suicidal ideation and behavior as they occur in individuals' daily lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

This project will study how immunotherapy affects the properties of CD8+ T effector and T regulatory cells and their crosstalk with other immune components of the tumor microenvironment. This work may significantly improve the outcome of immunotherapy and provide a major benefit to cancer patients.

PHR: NARRATIVE: SOD-OHSU R25 Summer Research Education Experience Application (PAR-21-168) To open Dentistry and Oral Research Summers (DORS) in Oregon The overall goal of the SOD R25 Summer Research Experience is to open doors for undergraduate scholars in pursuing a career in dental, oral, and craniofacial research and to increase representation within our research community from rural Oregon and from under-represented communities within Oregon. By presenting the opportunities and rewards that lie in being a research scientist and addressing barriers, we will transform learners who are interested in summer research to oral health researchers at all levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death worldwide, and lung adenocarcinoma is the most frequently diagnosed subtype of this disease. The proposed research will investigate molecular regulators of identity in lung adenocarcinoma and provide fundamental knowledge required for the design of integrative therapeutic strategies that target this disease on the basis of differentiation state-specific vulnerabilities as well as actionable mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Practice-based improvements in our ability to detect or discriminate subtle sound features – a process known as perceptual learning – is important for the development of speech and language, and for maximizing the benefits of hearing aids and cochlear implants. While non-sensory factors, such as attentional state or delivery of reward, are known to shape perceptual learning, we lack a comprehensive understanding of the neural mechanisms involved. The experiments proposed here will address this issue by assessing the contribution of one non-sensory brain region, the orbitofrontal cortex, and its descending projection to the auditory cortex to perceptual learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  There is a lack of viable intervention strategies to alleviate the potential health risks of living alone with cognitive impairment (CI). This proposed R21 will develop and test the feasibility, acceptability, and usefulness of a home-based, seven-module intervention (“Home Alone”) to assist persons living alone with CI to successfully navigate the challenges of living independently. If successful, the proposed R21 will position Home Alone for a subsequent randomized controlled evaluation and later as a flexible, much-needed evidence-based resource that is scalable for healthcare systems and other dementia support providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The key to successfully treat prevalent skeletal disorders such as osteoporosis relies on understanding changes in the tissue associated with the observed reduced bone quality and increased fracture risk. Here, we propose a unique approach to investigate in clinical biopsies the complex relationship between multiple bone nanoscale compositional properties and typical histopathological and morphometric findings of osteoporotic bones. This innovative project will reveal valuable insights into the nanoscale origins of impaired bone health, contributing to elucidating osteoporosis pathogenesis and to inform future clinical studies into new therapeutic tissue targets to improve bone quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fluorescence guided surgery using the exogenous agent 5-ALA has been increasingly utilized to enhance the ability to detect residual tumor and improve the extent of resection for glioblastoma. As currently implemented, intensity-based detection by the surgeon viewing fluorescence through the operating microscope is non- quantitative and background light-sensitive, requiring the surgeon to work in a dark field. Our novel optical imaging FLIm system captures and analyzes tissue fluorescence quantitatively, and successful integration of this technology with existing stereotactic neuronavigation for spatial annotation of FLIm data and visualization is expected to generate a new tool for improved tumor detection and resection while overcoming the current limitations of 5-ALA use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Severe wrist osteoarthritis is exceedingly common, but the currently available treatments are much less successful than those available for hip, knee, or shoulder arthritis. The ability to advance novel technologies to the clinic requires data from fit-for-purpose large animal models, thus the goal of this proposal is to validate the Yucatan minipig as a preclinical, large animal model of the wrist. The Yucatan minipig wrist model will provide a critically needed tool for the rapid development of next-generation wrist implants and biologics for the treatment of severe wrist osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We currently do not understand the mechanisms that underlie the majority of congenital heart defects, which are the most common birth defects, or how to efficient repair injured hearts. This project will provide a greater understanding of the causes of congenital heart defects, normal heart development and regeneration. Ultimately, the information gleaned may allow the generation of novel therapies able to prevent congenital heart defects and regenerate injured hearts in children and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Apidaecin and Drosocin are antibacterial peptides produced by honeybees and fruit flies, respectively. They stop the growth of bacteria by exploiting a unique mechanism - inhibiting the termination step of protein synthesis. However, these antibiotics are active only against several bacterial species and many aspects of their action remain unknown. In the proposed project, we will expand the understanding of how this class of antibacterials achieve their inhibitory action on bacteria. We will expand the variety of antibacterial peptides that affect protein synthesis termination and broaden the spectrum of action of these unique antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals may be predisposed to metabolic diseases like Type 2 diabetes as a result of the early life environment. Embryonic toxicant exposures can cause redox stress, disrupt developmental signaling pathways, and result in subtle structural or functional alterations to the insulin producing pancreatic β-cells. This project will use cell culture and zebrafish to provide an understanding of how embryonic exposure to chemicals like per-and- polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) can damage the developing pancreas and insulin production, identify later-life functional impacts, and potential targets for mitigation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Impaired mitochondrial function is a point of convergence for numerous neurological, neurodevelopmental, and neurodegenerative disorders. In this proposal we investigate newly discovered long-lived mitochondrial proteins that persist for months in the mammalian brain. The proposed research will elucidate novel aspects of mitochondrial biology and new avenues of research into the processes of age-related neurodegeneration and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tissue repair and disease progression involve significant cellular flux and many molecular regulators controlling such cellular behavior remain unknown. Our proposed research uses the latest high-throughput genomics approaches to investigate gene control mechanisms that are often broadly modulated in intestinal tissue repair as well as malignancies, including colorectal cancer. Additionally, we develop novel methods to quantify molecular change in cells at unprecedented detail, which will help in development of novel disease prognosis methods and identification of novel targets for drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) responds poorly to immunotherapy and the mechanisms of this resistance are unknown. We hypothesized that cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) mediate this intratumoral immunosuppression in a HIF2-dependent fashion and provide evidence that HIF2 inhibition improves survival in mouse models of PDAC by potentially improving immune responses. In this grant, we explore the mechanisms of HIF2-dependent immune modulation by CAFs and perform preclinical studies to repurpose an FDA-approved HIF2 inhibitor to improve the response of pancreatic cancer to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traditional epidemiological research and methods often focus separately on how social, economic, and environmental factors affect individuals' life course health, yet evolving research underscores the importance of considering the integrated effects of factors that cluster in those who are most socially disadvantaged. While substantial research examines the developmental origins and biologic mechanisms underlying toxicant-health associations, few cohorts have the ability to address the intergenerational legacy of toxicant exposures and social structures on life course health. In the proposed application we will expand on our E3Gen cohort maintenance activities by utilizing data integration and analytical techniques to incorporate novel measures of social structure, economic indicators and ethnographic data into our biologic and data repositories for 550 original ELEMENT mothers, 600 of their young adult offspring aged 18-33 years, and establish passive surveillance to recruit their grandchildren currently and projected to be born over the next 5 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In this prospective multicenter observational study, we will collect clinical, EEG, and 2-year neurologic outcomes data for 3000 patients with acute brain injury, in order to validate three novel machine learning models for future use in clinical trials and clinical care: 1) a seizure forecasting model (“2HELPS2B”); 2) a model that predicts the effect of the Burden of Epileptiform Activity on Neurologic Outcomes (“BEACON”); 3) a model that uses properties of epileptiform EEG abnormalities in the acute phase of brain injury to predict the risk of developing chronic epilepsy. Deliverables will include a large, public database of high-quality EEG and clinical data on brain-injured patients with 2-year of outcomes data, and validated EEG tools to guide care and improve outcomes for patients recovering from acute brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The oral bacterium Porphyromonas gingivalis is one of the keystone pathogens associated with human periodontitis and other systemic illness such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, arthritis, and Alzheimer’s disease. It produces an arsenal of virulence factors. Understanding the role of those virulence factors in the pathogenicity of P. gingivalis will ultimately lead to a new modality to prevent and treat periodontitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adenosine is an important neuromodulator that could provide neuroprotection during diseases, such as ischemia or traumatic brain injury, but little is known about the rapid mode of adenosine signaling to function during neuroprotection. Here, new technology is developed to allow measurements of multiple neuromodulators and neurotransmitters simultaneously. This technology is critical to understanding the rapid role adenosine plays in neuroprotection during stroke, and possibly developing therapies involving rapid adenosine release.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic pain is more prevalent and of greater intensity in Veterans than in the general population (VA Research on Pain Management Factsheet 2020). According to CDC, an estimated 25% (58 million) of U.S. adults have chronic pain. Chronic pain is highly prevalent in Veterans with nerve and spinal cord injury, traumatic limb amputation, burn injury, cancer, osteoarthritis, and peripheral neuropathy. There are also over 27,000 Veterans with SCI and related disorders including MS, who suffer from spasticity. Current treatments for chronic pain and spasticity are inadequate; they carry dose-limiting side effects and exert CNS side effects including the risk of abuse and addiction. Our research is aimed at developing better treatments for chronic pain and spasticity to substantially improve rehabilitation and quality of life of Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) is a neurometabolic disorder that causes irreparable brain and spinal cord degeneration in both children and adults, with a wide spectrum of outcomes ranging from chronic disability to the total collapse of the brain’s major functions. The underlying cause for ALD is a defective break down of fatty acids which leads to an accumulation of fats that are deleterious to various tissues. I hypothesize that a nuclear receptor, Pparβ/δ, can be targeted to counterbalance multiple disease processes in ALD, and will determine how Pparβ/δ mitigates underlying disruptions in lipid metabolism in order to identify novel therapies in ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Emergency department (ED) overcrowding and related factors during a patient’s stay increase their risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD) events and subsequent PTSD. The purpose of this research is to test whether modifiable ED factors increase CVD and psychological (burnout) risk in the millions of ED clinicians worldwide who are exposed to those same risk factors for years. If our hypotheses are supported, this research may motivate changes to EDs that offset CVD and psychological risk in clinicians, and may improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching research focus of the Wake Forest Translational Alcohol Research Center (WF-TARC) is to study behavioral correlates associated with heightened vulnerability to alcohol use disorder and identify neurobiological adaptations responsible for these behaviors. The highly integrated experimental design of this renewal continues to leverage the unique benefits of rodent, nonhuman, and human subjects research and facilitates backward and forward translation between projects. Collectively, these studies may lead to novel therapeutic interventions for individuals at greatest risk of developing alcohol alcohol use disorder.

PHR: Project Narrative Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) causes COVID-19 and has resulted in ongoing pandemic, tragic loss of life, and dire economic consequences. COVID-19 patients with severe and critical disease also develop pulmonary inflammation and abnormal bleeding problems. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Proper shaping of the brain and spinal cord is driven by highly coordinated cell movements during early embryonic development. Disruptions in this process can result in neural tube defects such as spina bifida, but the signals that control cell movements within the future neural tube are poorly understood. The proposed research will use zebrafish embryos as a model to identify novel regulators of cell movements that shape the developing neural tube.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Endogenous opioids control neuronal excitability at circuits throughout the brain, and may provide a mechanism for limiting excitation in the hippocampus, specifically in the epileptic brain. Here, I aim to characterize the impact of endogenous release of opioid peptides on brain network function. The proposed experiments will improve our understanding of the influence of endogenous opioids on hippocampal circuits, and possibly lead to improved epilepsy management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Recent advances in treatment for cardiac arrest (CA) have allowed patients to survive neurologically intact, but 1 in 3 report high negative psychological factors (NPF; e.g., depression, posttraumatic stress disorder) at hospital discharge that may increase risk for poor recovery marked by low health-related quality of life (QoL) and lack of independence in activities of daily living (ADL) as well as dangerously reduced cardiac vagal control, which is an index of the health of the autonomic nervous system that predicts risk for future cardiovascular events and mortality. Although NPF cannot be prevented, modifiable positive psychological factors (PPF; e.g., optimism, positive affect, and purpose in life) predict improved recovery and physical activity (PA) in non-CA patients, and therefore this study will test whether PPF predict long-term post-CA recovery—independent of NPF—and whether PA may be a behavioral mechanism underlying these associations. There are currently no clinical practice guidelines for identifying either cardioprotective or harmful psychological factors after CA because there is currently little evidence to guide clinicians, so the proposed research will represent a first step toward developing standard psychosocial interventions with a focus on positive psychological resources and negative psychological risk factors to improve recovery after CA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: We propose a two-arm randomized controlled trial to evaluate the impact of a multicomponent electronic health record intervention on racially-informed guideline concordant care for patients with poorly-controlled hypertension. The interventions tested in this trial aim to reduce health disparities in racial and ethnic minorities by using provider disparities report cards, electronic decision support, and enhanced patient portals and communication materials. Findings from this trial will provide important insight into whether a multicomponent racially-informed intervention leveraging health information technology can reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A central tenet of neuroscience is that memory storage involves changes in the functional properties of neuronal networks and that memory deficits are associated with disruptions in network function. Studies outlined in this proposal will use a relatively complex, yet tractable, neuronal network to examine the distributed representation of the memory for operant conditioning, a ubiquitous form of associative learning in which a subject learns from the consequences of its behavior. A deeper understanding of the design principles that govern the implementation of mnemonic mechanisms in neuronal networks may help guide the development of better treatments for neural dysfunction, and thereby improve human brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The focus of this project is to understand the catalytic mechanism of the metalloenzyme nitrogenase. Nitrogenase is the only biological agent that can reduce atmospheric dinitrogen into a bioavailable form (ammonia) and therefore has an immense global impact on human health and welfare through supporting the agricultural/nutritional needs of ~3 billion people. It is also a unique model enzyme that couples biological redox catalysis with ATP-dependent energy transduction processes, which are both central to cellular metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative To lessen the negative impact of drug-resistant epilepsy on children and improve their surgical outcomes, novel methods are needed to augment the EEG interpretation - especially when invasively recorded – and to estimate the epileptogenic zone, without requiring the recording of unpredictable seizures (which can be difficult to capture and interpret in many cases). The proposed study is relevant to public health because, if successful, it will provide the community with a new approach to estimate the epileptogenic zone, which goes far beyond the traditional identification of frank epileptiform activity on the EEG and can complement the techniques that are currently used to define an optimal resection strategy in children undergoing epilepsy surgery. The project is relevant to the NINDS's mission because the resulting findings can augment the surgical treatment of children with drug-resistant epilepsy and significantly improve their quality of life, since successful epilepsy surgery represents the best opportunity for these patients to avoid lifetime disability, recover function, and improve cognition.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Building Research Aspirations In Neurology (BRAIN) program provides an intensive, hands -on research experience to support the development of future clinician scientists in neurology. Undergraduate students from populations typically underrepresented in clinical neurology are trained in research methods to conduct studies to better understand, diagnose, and treat neurologic conditions. The students will participate in professional development and educational activities to establish a solid foundation to enable them to transition to a graduate-level program in clinical neurology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is diagnosed by spirometry but significant disagreement exists between spirometric diagnosis and presence of emphysema on computed tomography (CT) due to possibility that a substantial portion of the lung has abnormal mechanics. Using image registration to match inspiratory and expiratory scans point-to-point, we will identify Silent Zones of the lung that appear normal using density thresholds but have abnormal mechanics. The proposed project will use a combination of quantitative imaging and deep learning tools to establish a novel CT biomarker that will enhance diagnosis of clinically significant COPD and also identify individuals at high risk for disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer progression and metastasis account for the majority of cancer- related deaths, yet how cancer overcomes the immune system to metastasize is only beginning to be understood. Moreover, we have yet to determine how interactions between microbes residing in our gut and our immune systems modulate cancer metastasis. Since antibodies produced by B cells interact with microbial products and are critical for fighting cancer we propose to combine the use of a novel animal model lacking a major class of immunoglobulins, developed by Dr. Zeng, with fecal matter transplantation in a state of the art germ-free animal facility, to: 1) dissect the role of antibodies in cancer progression and 2) determine how the gut microbiome may modulate antibody-mediated anti-tumor responses in well-characterized mouse models of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The mechanosensitive channels MscS and MscL are ubiquitously expressed in bacteria, including in most pathogenic strains. While they allow bacteria to survive extreme osmotic changes in the environment, their inappropriate opening can be lethal for the bacteria, making these channels intriguing targets for developing novel antibiotics. MscL is also being explored for nanotechnological applications, such as in the delivery of active molecules to inflamed or cancerous tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in USH2A, which are responsible for ~85% of all USH2 cases, lead to severe auditory defects and late onset retinitis pigmentosa (RP), and in some cases autosomal recessive non-syndromic RP. Developing an effective treatment for USH2A has been challenging due to its very large coding sequence and the presence of isoforms with functions that are not fully understood. We aim to extend the benefits of our proven non-viral gene therapy platform consisting of nanoparticles, nanospheres, and sulfotyrosine to enhance delivery, protection, controlled release, and distribution of intravitreally delivered Ush2a gene to rescue vision loss associated with USH2A.

PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) The membranes of mammalian cells have complex compositions that are required for their unique structure and vast array of functions. The research in our laboratory is focused on defining the diversity of mammalian membrane compositions and how those lipids are organized to facilitate cellular physiology. The insights from work are expected to inform therapeutic strategies for diseases associated with membrane dysfunction, including cardiovascular disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The misfolding and aberrant liquid-liquid phase separation of several different RNA-binding proteins is implicated in Alzheimer’s disease and several related dementias such as frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Matrin-3 (MATR3) was recently implicated in FTD and has several key similarities and differences as compared to other proteins known to drive dementia. Here, we will delineate key properties of MATR3 with respect to liquid-liquid phase separation, RNA binding, and interactions with other FTD-associated proteins in order to better understand how to develop new therapeutics for dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CHAMACOS is a 20+ year old longitudinal cohort study of Latino mothers (1st generation) and children (2nd generation) from a California farmworker community who have been followed since before birth through young adulthood. As the 2nd generation approaches prime reproductive age, we propose to enrich the cohort by enrolling 3rd generation children and incorporating neighborhood-level data on social determinants of health. This grant would also support the CHAMACOS infrastructure to promote data sharing and scientific engagement with Latino students, faculty, and clinicians to increase work force diversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Short tandem repeat expansions in transcribed regions of the genome are the cause of numerous neuromuscular and neurological diseases for which no known cures exist. Here we develop innovative RNA-based therapeutic platforms to target these toxic gain-of-function transcripts for degradation, and establish novel human cellular and mouse disease models to evaluate safety and efficacy of our candidate therapeutic systems. As proof-of- principle, we focus on myotonic dystrophy type 1 with the aim to address both the muscle and neurocognitive deficits of the disease.

PHR: Project Narrative A key goal of this project is to reveal the role of the blood microbiome in asthma pathogenesis. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it enables us to systematically identify candidate causal microbial strains that can potentially prevent asthma. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission towards developing fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems and the application of that knowledge to enhance human health and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The severe toll that chronic pain takes on society, made especially clear by the recent opioid epidemic, underscores the need for innovative treatments, particularly for those people with intractable pain who have failed conventional medical and surgical management. Intracranial electrodes implanted for the purpose of epilepsy monitoring provide a rare opportunity to define neurophysiological signatures of pain representations in the human brain and modulate neural circuit activity to attenuate the pain state. Information gained from targeted, high-resolution access to human pain networks can be directly translated to improve existing therapies, including the implantation of deep-brain stimulating electrodes for the treatment of chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a debilitating demyelinating disease of the central nervous system (CNS) that affects approximately 2.5 million people worldwide. There remains an unmet clinical need for new therapeutic strategies that can restore and sustain long-term immune tolerance in MS patients. The current proposal is aimed at understanding PD1 signaling in MS patients, a major pathway implicated in peripheral immune tolerance, and leveraging these insights to maximize the efficacy of PD1 agonist monotherapies along with low-dose IL-2 combination therapies in clinically relevant MS models. The successful completion of this clinically-oriented proposal has the potential to impact treatment for MS, as well as other inflammatory and autoimmune diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 380 million people worldwide are suffering from diabetes mellitus, and the majority of them will encounter corneal defects at some point in their life. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor (Glp1r) agonists are used to treat diabetes and obesity due to their ability to stimulate insulin secretion and reduce food intake. The molecular mechanisms mediating these effects remain ill-defined, so the present application builds on our published and preliminary data showing that a key interaction between canonical Glp1r signaling and nutrient-sensing molecules mediate the beneficial metabolic effects of the clinically-relevant Glp1r agonist Liraglutide. Findings from this application will help us either improve current Glp1r-based drugs or assist us in identifying new molecular targets that can be used to develop newer, more effective diabetes and/or obesity therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Environmental toxicant exposures play a key role in the regulation of the epigenome, but the mechanisms remain unclear. In this proposal, we hypothesize that toxicant induced replication stress, paired with defective repair due to STAG2 loss, drives pre-malignant cell evolution and creates a permissive epigenome for transformation. This proposal is focused on understanding the molecular mechanisms by which 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD), alone or in combination with 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4- D) and 2,4,5-trichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4,5-T) affect the replication stress response (RSR) and contribute to genetic and epigenetic heterogeneity in these tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: HSV-1 is a ubiquitous DNA virus that can cause devastating disease in immunocompromised patients and neonates, can be used as a viral vector for gene therapy approaches, and serves as an easy to manipulate model system to understand fundamental cellular and viral processes. HSV-1 utilizes multiple approaches to avoid eliciting host DNA damage responses while at the same time redirecting host proteins to viral genomes to be exploited for viral processes. We propose to use innovative approaches to investigate the role cellular proteins play in determining the outcome of infection, which will provide insight into how these proteins can be targeted for antiviral therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to democratize MRI research by developing Cloud MR, an open-source software simulation platform where researchers can test new technology and radiologists can optimize clinical protocols without operating an actual MR scanner. Through a web-based graphical user interface and cloud computing, Cloud MR will enable radiofrequency coil modeling, pulse sequence design, and the development of image reconstruction methods within the same integrated framework. Cloud MR will be a powerful tool also for training and education.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Monomorphic epitheliotropic intestinal T-cell lymphoma (MEITL) is a rare but lethal disease with a median survival of 1 year. The molecular role of SETD2 (the most frequently silenced gene in MEITL) and its interaction with activated oncogenes in MEITL pathogenesis is largely unknown. In this proposal, we develop novel mouse models of this disease to define the role of SETD2 in MEITL pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic beta cell dysfunction is pivotal in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes. The proposed study will build a pathway centered on C2CD4A, a human type 2 diabetes susceptibility gene identified from genome- wide association studies in every ethnic group studied to date. Understanding the mechanism of C2cd4a- regulated insulin secretion in the pancreatic beta-cells will provide insights into diabetes therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement/Narrative Targeting inflammation may be key to developing a disease-modifying therapy for Alzheimer’s disease. This project investigates blood and central nervous system biomarkers of inflammation and their modulation by IL-2 administration in people with Alzheimer’s disease. This project will facilitate the development of immunotherapy strategies for various stages of the Alzheimer’s disease process and advance the use of inflammatory biomarkers to assess disease progression or treatment efficacy in Alzheimer’s disease clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Racial and ethnic disparities in surgical care and outcomes have been a persistent and well-documented public health problem in the U.S.; however, strategies to effectively close this disparity gap have not been developed. Using an innovative dataset that includes comprehensive information on (1) patient characteristics, (2) surgeon factors, and (3) characteristics of medical schools and residency programs (e.g., the proportion of racial and ethnic minority faculty/peers/patients, the presence of cultural competency programs), the investigators will determine the impact of individual surgeon factors and education/training on racial and ethnic disparities in surgical care and outcomes. This research has the potential to offer novel approaches for unraveling one of the key determinants of disparities in surgery—“surgeon factors”—and to provide a strong evidence base for developing interventions that can effectively reduce racial and ethnic disparities in surgical care.
