IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Defects in genes involved in replication stress response often lead to neurodevelopmental disorders and predisposition to cancer. The Coats Plus disease, caused by dysfunction of genes involved in combating replication stress, is a rare genetic disease characterized by developmental failure of multiple vital organs including brain, eye and GI tract. The proposed research aims to reveal a new signaling pathway regulating the cellular response to replication stress and is expected to yield new mechanistic insights into how cells protect genome stability during perturbed replication and how genome instability leads to disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We remain ignorant about bat henipavirus spillovers through intermediate hosts – including the specific viruses spilling over, the frequency and distribution of spillovers, and the pathways of transmission – at our own peril. Until and unless we better understand and prevent spillovers of bat-borne viruses into intermediate hosts and humans, we will be severely limited in our ability to stop pandemics. The knowledge gained from this study will be immediately applicable to human and animal health programs because if we know which henipaviruses infect humans and domesticated animals, and how they are infected, we can advise public health surveillance programs on how to optimize detection and prevention of infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project investigates the mechanism by which dynamin enables membrane fission during endocytosis, how SH3 domain-containing proteins interact and regulate dynamin during endocytosis, and how dynamin interacts with actin filaments during various cell processes that rely on the actin cytoskeleton. This work is of public health relevance because dynamin has critical roles in endocytosis necessary for cell signaling, and for cell-cell fusion and migration which require actin bundling by dynamin. Furthermore, dysregulation of dynamin causes neuropathies, cancer and defects in organism development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite guidelines recommending dialysis initiation via an arteriovenous vascular access (fistula or graft), 80% of US patients start hemodialysis with a catheter, leading to significant morbidity, mortality, and healthcare system expense. In other chronic illnesses, strengthening patient preparedness through education and support has been shown to improve adoption of evidence-based health recommendations and associated patient outcomes. In this randomized controlled trial among people with advanced kidney disease planning for hemodialysis, we will compare the effectiveness of three education strategies for increasing pre-dialysis arteriovenous vascular access creation and evaluate the implementation of the education strategies to inform equitable and effective translation to the non-trial setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is primarily caused by an aberrant increase in feeding motivation that leads to the overeating of calorie- dense food. In this application, we propose to study zona incerta dopamine neurons for their role in the control of feeding motivation and food consumption. The expected outcome from this project will shed light on the mechanism by which central dopamine signaling regulate feeding and reveal a novel neural target for developing treatments in eating disorders and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Asymmetric cell division is an evolutionary conserved mechanism to create sister cells with different fates. This proposal investigates mechanisms involved in cellular and subcellular asymmetry, biased segregation of molecules and organelles and its contribution to binary cell fate decisions. Incorrectly regulated asymmetric cell division can result in tumor formation and neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 2-3% of trauma cases involve peripheral nerve damage. The treatment options for these injuries are limited, and clinical outcomes following surgical reconstructions can yield incomplete recovery, where estimates of adequate recovery are only achieved in 52% of cases. This project advances scientific knowledge on principles of nerve regeneration and functional recovery, where there is significant potential that the outcome of the research could lead to new therapies to improve the treatment of nerve injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRITIVE Groundbreaking discoveries resulting in the “immuno-revolution” have established the importance of immunology across medical disciplines. However, the potential of targeting the immune system in the context of heart failure remains to be realized. The overarching goal of the proposed research program is to 1) dissect biological mechanisms governing cardiac macrophage diversity and function, and 2) translate our findings into new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches to abrogate heart failure pathogenesis, potentiate functional recovery of the failing heart, and prevent heart transplant rejection.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose that EGFR functions as a switch in glioblastoma (GBM). IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Metastatic cancer cells are able to colonize distant organs, resist therapy and cause cancer death because of their ability to dynamically change their gene expression programs to adapt to diverse stresses. The molecular mechanisms of such metastatic plasticity are not understood. Leveraging patient samples, organoids, and insights we have generated, we will define critical mechanisms of dynamic transcriptional reprogramming in metastasis, with the potential to impact therapeutic outcomes for patients with metastatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Overexposure to the essential metal manganese (Mn) results in  basal ganglia neurotoxicity and the development of incurable motor deficits. Proposed experiments aim  to determine whether Mn-induced dysfunction of GABAergic or catecholaminergic neurons in the basal  ganglia is associated with motor deficits. Proposed experiments also aim to further elucidate the role of  the primary Mn efflux transporter SLC30A10 in regulating brain Mn homeostasis.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative The Zika virus (ZIKV) is of major health concern due to its link to devastating pathologies such as microcephaly in newborn infants and the Guillan-Barré syndrome in adults. We have succeeded in identifying a novel “lead- like” compound (MS2045) for the inhibition of ZIKV’s RNA capping activity and for blocking its replication. We will design, synthesize, and characterize analogs of MS2045 that can be potentially developed into even more potent inhibitors of ZIKV replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breathing is controlled automatically to preserve homeostasis but must also be conditionally regulated to adjust breathing to changes in behavior and emotion that typify the awake state. This project characterizes a novel neural circuit in the pons important for the state-dependent control of breathing at frequencies not achievable by known mechanisms of respiratory rhythm generation. Insights gained from these studies will significantly expand our basic scientific understanding of respiratory control with potential implications for pathologies that involve links between breathing and emotions such as panic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Gain-of-function (GOF) p53 mutations are very frequent in all types of chemo- and radio-resistant intractable lung cancers with poor prognosis, and are required for their tumorigenic phenotype. The proposed project is designed to identify and validate small molecule inhibitors that specifically inactivate the oncogenic function of GOF p53 in tumors, sparing normal cells. Thus, the identified inhibitors should have a cancer cell-specific efficient therapeutic property for lung cancers with p53 mutation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Why are some animals able to fully regrow lost appendages when humans cannot? In this proposal, we will identify features of the metabolic landscape that favor regenerative healing and growth using Xenopus tropicalis, a vertebrate that is able to regrow appendages under some conditions but not others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance) Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is a condition that affects tens of millions of adults and is often associated with increased susceptibility to interference by irrelevant external stimulation which can adversely affect home and work life. In this project, we propose to (1) use a new method to study susceptibility to interference from irrelevant external information, (2) model the results from this method to uncover the underlying processing difficulties faced by those with ADHD, and (3) apply this method to three different tasks both of which feature the need to control interference.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This R21 proposal aims to analyze the potential of tissue kallikreins (klk), an important set of molecules in the kallikrein-kinin system (KKS), in lupus-prone mouse models (MRL/lpr and Sle1,2,3). Experiments in vitro will analyze the effects of klk1(one of the tissue klks) on brain cells (microglia, astrocytes and microvessels [that form the blood-brain-barrier]), and klk1 administration in MRL/lpr mice will assess the disease outcome (clinical, immunological, and behavioral). There is currently no specific treatment for neuropsychiatric (NPSLE) lupus; the results of this study will provide a rationale to use tissue klks for systemic and NPSLE treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurochemicals in the brain, such as serotonin, transmit information between neurons to process input and produce normal behavior, but that occasionally when their levels are disrupted lead to neurologic and psychiatric disorders. We are proposing to develop a novel neurochemical recording method called N-shaped Multiple Cyclic Square Wave Voltammetry that for the first time measures tonic serotonin concentrations in real-time in the brain with single-second time resolution and unprecedented chemical selectivity. Furthermore, we propose to standardize this novel technique for use in neuroscience research directed to understanding the neurochemical basis of neuropsychiatric diseases by demonstrating its capability to quantify tonic levels in both acute and chronic animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The proposed research will demonstrate that the gut microbiome acts in concert with the direct effects of envi- ronmental toxicants, such as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), on the brain and the influence of these interac- tions on neurotoxic outcomes, such as Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). This outcome is relevant to public health because it will provide critical insights regarding the plausibility of microbiome-based approaches to diagnose and treat neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders induced by exposure to PCBs and, potentially, other neurotoxicants. Therefore, the proposed research is pertinent to the part of NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge about living systems to enhance health and reduce the burden of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We are studying how viruses that cause lymphomas or sarcomas in humans or monkeys use RNA molecules to manipulate their host cells to the advantage of the virus. These RNAs are not templates for making proteins but act to alter how other genes function after infection. Understanding these viral noncoding RNAs will provide novel targets for the design of therapeutics to combat these cancer-causing viruses, as well as many insights into host-cell processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The global burden of disease due to Group A Streptococcus (GAS) is a major unmet public health challenge. After more than 100 years of vaccine development efforts, resurgent momentum flowing from investment in discovery and design of next generation GAS vaccines remains threatened by the absence of a human correlate of protection and the limitations of currently available in vitro assays and preclinical models. Our cross- disciplinary collaborative research aims to strengthen the development pathway for novel GAS vaccine candidates by applying cutting edge human immunology tools and techniques to diverse human specimens to discover broadly applicable potential correlates of systemic and mucosal protection that will inform design of scalable, high-throughput, practical immunoassays.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The biomedical community lacks a complete description of the effects, frequencies, and molecular nature of causative variants underlying complex genetic diseases and other quantitative traits. The multiparental population we pioneered, and continue to develop here, enables powerful genetic dissection of trait variation in the premier fruit fly model system, and allows a community of users a smooth transition from mapped genomic regions to sequence variants. Our resource is complementary to GWAS (genomewide association study) methods, and under several likely genetic models has distinct advantages over this approach for the identification of causative variation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunoglobulin heavy chain germline gene IGHV6-1 encodes a multi-donor class of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs) to the highly conserved stem region of hemagglutinin (HA). IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Human gut microbiome composition has recently been associated with a wide array of diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and colorectal cancer. We propose to study the structure and function of the gut microbiota in the development of IBD associated colorectal cancer. Our proposed study may lead to better understanding of the interplay between gut microbiota and colon mucosa and could shed light to novel diagnostic and therapeutic approaches to IBD and associated colorectal cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative Polycomb group (PcG) genes encode a group of proteins that can maintain gene repression by modifying chromatin. This proposal seeks to study the mechanisms and functions of PcG proteins in mouse preimplantation development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Mast cells play a critical role in the induction of immune responses, promoting both IgE-dependent allergic responses such as food allergy and non-IgE-mediated inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. Our studies provide a unique opportunity to dissect the mechanisms by which IL-10 modulates mast cell function in the context of both IgE-mediated activation as well as IgE- independent signals such as IL-33 stimulation. These investigations will not only provide key mechanistic insight into the proinflammatory effects of IL-10 on activated mast cells, but also further enhance our understanding of how mast cells promote the development of allergic responses towards better therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We hypothesize that mutant p53 drives the pathogenesis of myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) through altering pre-mRNA splicing in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs) during aging. We will determine the mechanisms by which mutant p53 alters pre-mRNA splicing in HSPCs. We will determine the sensitivity of human MDS cells with TP53 mutations to spliceosome inhibitor treatment and develop novel therapeutic strategies for MDS patients with TP53 mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We will determine the mechanisms that chromosome segregation and determine how these are dysregulated in tumors. We focus on the regulation of Aurora B kinase, which is an important target for new cancer therapies. In addition, we will determine how the complex containing Aurora B generates important structures on the mitotic spindle that segregates chromosomes and resolves R- loops during mitosis, which are structures that can generate genomic instability when they are not properly regulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) require life-long therapy with BCR-ABL1 tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) to avoid relapse. CML cells minimize expression of membrane-spanning four A (MS4A3) to escape TKIs. We will identify the underlying mechanism, and whether re-expression of MS4A3 can be harnessed to increase response to TKIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE  The orphan nuclear receptor 4A1 (NR4A1, Nur77) is overexpressed in colon cancer patients and this receptor not only regulates genes associated with tumor cell growth, survival and invasion but also plays a pivotal role in immune suppression and T-cell exhaustion. Bis-indole derived agents (CDIMs) developed in our laboratories are high affinity ligands (and antagonists) of NR4A1 and their dual role as chemotherapeutic and immunotherapeutic agents will be investigated in cell culture and mouse colon tumor models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Stuttering negatively impacts communication and reduces the overall quality of life and well-being of individuals who stutter. The proposed research program is directly relevant to the NIH’s mission because the project’s findings will form a strong foundation for developing neural and behavioral interventions for stuttering. In addition, this project’s findings will inform theories of speech by describing the contributions of predictive processes to fluent speech production.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The immune system is capable of slowing or preventing cancer progression; however, the immune tolerance of cancer significantly hinders protective anti-tumor immune responses, and leads to treatment failures and poor patient survival. We uncovered that melanoma-associated Schwann cells inhibit the formation of the tertiary lymphoid structures in tumors and promote immunosuppression, favoring immune tolerance and cancer progression. We will determine the molecular mechanism of tumor immunity regulation by the Schwann cells, and target them genetically and pharmacologically as a novel therapeutic strategy aimed at breaking the immune tolerance and synergizing with anti-PD-1 and anti-CTLA4 immune checkpoint inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our network of study sites initiated Regional Prospective Observational Research in TB (RePORT)-Brazil in 2013 in Rio de Janeiro, Salvador, and Manaus, Brazil, with the data coordinating center at Vanderbilt. Clinical data and stored biorepository specimens have facilitated studies of TB and TB/HIV treatment outcomes, predictors of M. tuberculosis (Mtb) infection and progression to TB disease and incipient TB, TB-diabetes, drug-resistant TB, TB diagnostics, and Mtb transmission. Phase 2 of RePORT-Brazil will build upon this strong foundation through three Specific Aims: 1) Gain insights that improve TB diagnosis, treatment, and outcomes; 2) Improve our understanding of Mtb transmission and infection, including latent, incipient, and sub-clinical disease; predictors of progression to TB, and protection against TB; and 3) Support and develop the next generation of TB scientists, and enhance the scope and collaboration of RePORT-Brazil.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study employs a novel approach to investigate the effects of channel interaction and a strategy that promotes channel independence to improve cochlear implant (CI) outcomes that require high-fidelity spectral encoding, such as music perception. Study results could provide the first evidence-based recommendations for programming CIs for music, which is of immediate interest to clinicians for counseling patients and programming devices, CI candidates for increasing utilization of CIs, and CI recipients for improving their performance and quality of life. More broadly, this study is of interest to CI researchers and manufacturers by providing a foundational model and preliminary data to inform future work striving to improve performance on other spectral tasks, such as speech understanding in background noise and musical sound quality and appraisal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adaptation of gene transcription is earliest fundamental response of heart to compensate for increasing stress during work overload, before it goes into irreversible state of cardiac failure. In this study, we examine the underlying mechanisms that regulate basic transcriptional machinery for expression of essential and inducible genes under hypertrophic stress conditions. The project will enhance our understanding of transcription in heart, open new avenues of basic and translational research, identify factors that control gene expression and contribute to pathophysiology of cardiac hypertrophy and failure

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal seeks funding for a PhD training program in the biomedical sciences that enables students from underrepresented backgrounds to excel in research, hone their academic and professional development skills, explore biotech shadowing experiences, and engage in educational outreach activities in the community. These activities will prepare our trainees to excel in graduate school and to transition successfully into top positions in the biotech, academic, science policy and other STEM- related career sectors. As teams with diverse perspectives outperform those with more limited perspective, our program, which seeks to diversify the scientific workforce, is essential to continue the tradition of scientific excellence in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Metastasis is the major cause of cancer-related death, but the metabolic adaptations that enable a cancer cels originated from one organ to grow in a distal organ remain unclear. Here, we propose to develop new mathematical models to infer the metabolic fluxes rewired in metastasis, knowledge that may open new strategies to prevent and treat metastatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to build an innovative, first-in-clinic, easy-to-use, oxygen scanner for repeated monitoring of tumor oxygen levels in cancer patients. The scanner will be built using the advanced in vivo electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) technology developed at Dartmouth College and in partnership with ViewRay®, a pioneer in the development of MRI image-guided linear accelerator for radiation therapy. The new oxygen scanner can provide potentially important and previously unavailable information on tumor oxygen status, which is important for accurate prognosis and development of effective treatment strategies for cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Breast cancer patients using aromatase inhibitors (AIs) as an adjuvant therapy often report severe side effects, including hot flashes, cognitive impairment, insomnia and mood changes. Despite long-term use in humans, little is known about the long-term effects of AIs on brain function. This proposal uses a primate model to understand how AIs affect the brain and behavior and to test whether a drug that delivers estrogens exclusively to the brain can safely alleviate these deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This grant proposal aims to investigate sympathetic activation with mental stress in women with chest pain who have coronary microvascular dysfunction. Cardiac sympathetic imaging, autonomic and vascular reactivity assessment, as well as home monitoring for autonomic function and daily life stress are proposed. The application incorporates a multi-disciplinary team of experts and innovative methods to study a clinical problem that disproportionately impacts women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Many chemicals that cause dopaminergic neurodegeneration and Parkinson’s disease also cause mitochondrial dysfunction. However, hundreds or thousands of chemicals in commerce cause mitochondrial dysfunction, by a plethora of different mechanisms. Therefore, to inform efforts to reduce exposures relevant to Parkinson’s Disease, we will identify which specific kinds of mitochondrial toxicity cause dopaminergic neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cystic fibrosis (CF) and its comorbidities have a major impact on human health and socioeconomic burden, making the proposed research relevant to public health. CF-associated lung disease is associated with airway inflammation and mucociliary dysfunction. We will study Fibroblast Growth Factor receptor inhibition as a potential novel anti-inflammatory therapy option, which is relevant to the NHLBI’s mission to promote the prevention and treatment of lung diseases and enhance the health of individuals so that they can live longer and more fulfilling lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The adoptive transfer of T cells engineered to express synthetic receptors that target cancer cells for elimination has emerged as an effective modality with curative potential in some types of cancer. Limitations of current adoptive cell therapies include the ability of tumor cells to escape elimination because they express low levels of, or lack, the antigen being targeted. This project will address these problems by developing two new classes of synthetic tumor targeting receptors that have exquisite sensitivity for antigen and can recognize constellations of antigens expressed on tumor cells, making treatment more effective for achieving durable remissions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current systemic therapies for liver cancer, including sorafenib and the combination of atezolizumab (anti- PD-L1) and bevacizumab (anti-VEGF), have limited therapeutic benefits with no predictive biomarkers available. Our preliminary studies uncovered roles for a targetable LIFR−NF-κB−LCN2 pathway in regulating liver tumorigenesis, sorafenib-induced ferroptotic cell death, and tumor infiltration by cytotoxic T cells. The goal of this project is to provide new insights into the mechanisms of therapeutic targeting of an iron-sequestering pathway, which has significant clinical implications in regard to the biomarkers and therapeutic targets for liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Epidemiological studies clearly show that advanced age is the most important risk factor for cardiovascular disease, but we have an incomplete understanding of how aging promotes cardiovascular disease progression. The accumulation of somatic DNA mutations over time has recently been demonstrated to be a hallmark of aging in many human cell types. The overarching goal of this proposal is to define the extent of somatic mutations in aging human cardiomyocytes, provide an understanding of the mutational processes acting on aging human cardiomyocytes, and explore the link between somatic mutational burden and cardiovascular pathologies, for developing new strategies to treat millions of adults with heart disease associated with aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In mammals, the right and left heart size and function dramatically change before/after birth, but how this process is determine remain a mystery. This proposal will study a newly discovered pathway first time implicated in this process, using sophisticated genomic and molecular tools. The outcome will fill an important gap in our current knowledge and shed light to potential causes of heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac arrest are a major cause of mortality and morbidity, carrying great economical and societal impact. Our research applies primarily to arrhythmias originating in the cardiac intercalated disc and subject to the interplay between PKP2, Cx43 and intracellular calcium. We use modern physiology, proteomics and microscopy methods to investigate the mechanisms underlying the onset of disease at the molecular level and to design novel venues for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Swallowing impairment (dysphagia) is a common complication of cardiac surgical procedures leading to malnutrition and dehydration, aspiration pneumonia, need for reintubation, increased length of hospital stay, increased cost of care, and death. This study seeks to determine contributing risk factors, accurate bedside clinical markers, and underlying pathophysiology of dysphagia in cardiac surgical patients to support a four- pronged care framework, the Model of Swallowing Integrated Care (MOSAIC). The MOSAIC framework includes prediction, prevention, detection, and treatment considerations to provide an evidence-based guide to enhance clinical decision making, promote efficient resource utilization, and ultimately improve outcomes in cardiac surgical patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety symptoms occur in adolescents with T1D at 2 to 3 times the rate of the general adolescent population and are associated with out-of-range glycemic control, including severe hypoglycemia and diabetic ketoacidosis, poor quality of life, and poor self-management. There are few evidence-based interventions adapted and implemented to assist with alleviating anxiety for this high-risk population. Development of an adapted MBSR mHealth application prototype will provide accessible, cost-conscious, scalable access to a safe intervention, thus reducing cost and increasing access for this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative Electrical synapses, mediated by neuronal gap junctions, are widespread throughout the auditory pathway. However, the functional roles and properties of electrical synapses in the auditory system remain poorly understood. Changes in the strength of electrical synapses are known to dynamically reconfigure neuronal circuits in various neural structures but in contrast to chemical synapses, little is known about the molecular mechanisms that underlie changes in the strength of electrical synapses. The proposed research will lead to the identification of novel molecular mechanisms involved in the regulation of electrical synapses that could fundamentally change the way we understand the organization of circuits associated with auditory dysfunction, thus contributing to the identification of novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application proposes to 1) examine mechanisms of neighborhood social, economic, and environmental risks for lung cancer incidence and stage at diagnosis, 2) to identify the relationship between neighborhood risks and PRMT6-mediated epigenetic changes, and 3) to explore the relationship between neighborhood risk and hair cortisol levels among high-risk individuals. Although the link between neighborhood context and lung cancer outcomes has been documented, little is known about specific mechanisms through which neighborhood context affects biological and behavioral risks for lung cancer outcomes. This study examines neighborhood contextual factors that may contribute to understanding epigenetic changes and lung cancer risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Congenital heart defects (CHDs) associated with the conduction of electrical impulses can be devastating health problems. Understanding how dysfunctions arise in the early, embryonic heart is important for discovering ways to prevent or treat these CHDs. This project will develop imaging tools to capture impulse conduction in the living, beating heart of the early avian embryo in 3D, and map the molecular response of the cells of the heart, under normal and abnormal conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of Americans could benefit from palliative care to address the physical, psychological, and social effects of severe and chronic illness. Artificial intelligence (AI) - computer-based algorithms that can carry out tasks typically reserved for humans – has the potential to give patients and families more detailed and more accurate information about prognosis than ever before, but whether or how to use this information ethically in support of patient- and family-centered care is unknown. To ensure AI supports high quality end-of-life and palliative care that is consistent with patients’ and families’ beliefs, values, and preferences, this project will identify the benefits and challenges of AI for palliative care and then develop practical guidance for its use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Public Health Relevance / Project Narrative Across the United States, adverse events involving law enforcement officers (LEOs) and male minority youth (MMY) and the toxic stress associated with repeated negative LEO-MMY encounters raise compelling public health concerns about racial discrimination in policing. The proposed research addresses these concerns by (a) introducing a novel human development paradigm for the study of police behavior that focuses on how and to what extent LEOs identify with MMY and (b) assessing the technological viability of using broadcast police communications (BPC) for large scale analysis of police behavior, where BPC are analyzed as pre-reflective accounts of LEO thought processes, representing both reactive and stable coping mechanisms (i.e., speech acts) for ensuring the safety of LEOs and the public at large. Accordingly, we propose (1) using this novel data source to understand how LEOs and MMYs come to perceive each other, (2) test a similarly novel survey instrument for measuring LEO identification with minority youth, in the process determining how much meaningful information can be reliably extracted from audio recordings of BPC for identifying racial discrimination in policing without the need to access highly sensitive police records or video recording data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Birth defects of the heart are common, life-threatening conditions that are often caused by changes in a patient’s DNA. It is now possible to determine the complete sequence of a patient’s genome, but it remains difficult to identify those disease-causing changes that do not affect genes and instead disrupt sequences that control gene activity during embryonic development of the heart. We propose a research program that will use cutting-edge genomics techniques to identify and examine these changes, generating insights to support the diagnosis and treatment of birth defects of the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A more comprehensive understanding of the underlying mechanisms associated with elevated maternal distress and caregiving deficits is necessary for early detection, care management, and effective treatment options during the immediate postpartum period. This study will explore a risk phenotype for maternal distress by analyzing neurological changes in reward responsivity, caregiving behaviors, and the maternal experience of goal pursuit and perceived daily functioning in postpartum mothers. Outcomes of this project will support future work on the bidirectional nature of the maternal-child relationship as it relates to Regulatory Focus Theory, and lead to improvements in postpartum care and intervention development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Certain populations are disproportionately affected by obesity, such as families in rural areas, and treatment options for these rural children and families are limited as they face unique barriers. The current study will assess the effectiveness of iAmHealthy Parents First (a 4-month parent-only intervention followed by a 6-month family- based program) compared to iAmHealthy alone (a parent wait-list control followed by the family based program). If effective, this intervention model could easily be disseminated to improve the lives of rural children and parents who need weight management treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative The proposed research seeks to determine how stroke center certifications have changed access, volume, care, and health outcomes over time across NIH disparity populations and communities. It is relevant to public health because it will provide local, state, and federal bodies with the empirical findings they need to create systems-level solutions to the delivery of stroke care that can both improve overall population health and narrow disparities among various segments of the population. The project directly addresses NIMHD’s mission because it seeks to “explain the causes, determinants, and influences of health and life course trajectories that result in health disparities,” by studying disparities at multiple levels: at individual-, facility- and community- levels and exploring consequences of system-level changes in the healthcare system for racial/ethnic, lower socioeconomic, and rural health disparity populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Many asthmatics do not have adequate control over air flow due to airway obstruction, and treatment options are limited to one class of bronchodilator drugs which all work the same way. The proposal seeks to determine the structure of a different class of bronchodilator drug acting at bitter taste receptors on airway smooth muscle, and then find drugs with favorable pharmacologic characteristics to activate these receptors. This will lead to increased treatment options for asthma that could decrease patient morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Roughly 70,000 adolescents and young adults (AYAs; between the ages of 15-39) are diagnosed with cancer every year, an incidence that is nearly 8 times greater than in childhood cancers. Preliminary research indicates that young cancer survivors suffer from considerable challenges due to their life stage. The goal of this study is to develop a population-based cohort (n=2,000) of young adult survivors (ages 21-39; ~42% Hispanic) of the most common types of cancers in this age group who are 3-10 years post-diagnosis. We will examine their health status, including comorbidities and late effects of their cancer treatments, achievement of adult milestones, and use of health care services. Findings will provide physicians and other health care providers with evidence to guide policies concerning young adult cancer survivorship care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preventing the transition from acute pain to chronic pain would reduce individual suffering and provide huge societal savings for hundreds of thousands of injured patients across the country seeking treatment in emergency departments. Identifying the specific psychological responses to traumatic physical injury that contribute to the development of chronic pain and the specific times when these transitions are strongest will inform the design of treatment and prevention strategies. Given that psychological processes are potentially amenable to intervention during the acute and subacute injury phase and are more consistently related to pain outcomes than injury severity, research informing non-pharmacological psychological interventions has the ability to shift the paradigm of post-injury pain management strategies from a largely biomedical and pharmacological approach to a multimodal approach that may serve to reduce opioid overuse yet deliver effective pain relief.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer-related job loss is associated with increased financial hardship, including difficulty paying bills, depletion of savings, accumulation of debt, and bankruptcy. In the parent grant, we are testing the effectiveness of a mobile health application designed to support working during the treatment period by increasing access to accommodations and optimizing symptom control, with the ultimate goal of promoting long-term job retention and financial stability. The 2-year R37 extension will allow us to extend the period of follow-up of the parent grant’s aims, creating up to 4 years of data with a cohort of patients within the framework of an RCT, and providing detailed information about subjective and objective indicators of financial hardship, so that we can study the long-term impact of breast cancer treatment on work and on overall financial hardship, and how our study intervention may affect these outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed study is directed at increasing the fundamental understanding of the causes, mechanisms, and prevention strategies of chronic kidney disease of unknown origin (CKDu) in Latin America. The study’s inclusion of examining sugarcane worker occupational exposure to particulate matter and its nephrotoxic constituents (silica, glyphosate, and heavy metals), renal biomarkers of effect, including early biological change, will advance our ability to identify factors that put individuals at risk for the development of CKDu and also detect illness at preclinical stages. Findings will lead to future interventions designed to reduce morbidity and mortality from CKDu in vulnerable populations around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Disruption of lipid metabolism has been associated with metabolic syndrome including obesity, diabetes and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). VLDL secretion is critical in regulating hepatic lipid homeostasis and impaired VLDL secretion leads to NAFLD and hypolipidemia. Elucidating the molecular mechanisms of how VLDL secretion is impaired by high fat diet, and how NAFLD would progress to more severe non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), will help to develop novel therapeutic strategies for NAFLD/NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Most autoimmune diseases have a profound sex bias, affecting females of reproductive age 3-16:1 over males, and the precise cause of this bias remains unknown. We hypothesize that a short variant of estrogen receptor alpha (ERα), akin to an endogenous ERα variant, is important for anti-inflammatory effects of estrogen in innate immune cells and is targetable. This hypothesis will be tested by varying levels of ERα variants, by selecting ERα cellular location as well as using novel anti-inflammatory selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) that may prove useful as adjunctive treatment for autoimmune diseases such as lupus.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease accounts for 1 in every 3 deaths in the US, many of which are caused by pathological cardiac hypertrophy and subsequent heart failure, for which there is no cure. Our proposed studies aim to decipher the molecular mechanisms contributing to pathological cardiac hypertrophy. We anticipate that this knowledge will help to develop new, mechanistically specific and selective treatments for pathological cardiac hypertrophy and, thus, reduce mortality from this form of heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ligand-dependent protein degradation has emerged as a compelling strategy to pharmacologically control the protein content of cells, which has the potential to substantially increase the number of druggable proteins in human disease such as cancer. We have identified DCAF16 – a poorly characterized E3 ubiquitin ligase – as a target of electrophilic probes that promote the nuclear-restricted degradation of proteins. The goal of this proposal is to investigate biological functions of DCAF16, identify small molecules that disrupt cancer cell growth via a DCAF16-dependent mechanism, and discover additional E3 ligases with distinct and restricted expressions in different cancer types that support ligand-induced targeted protein degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Alida Biosciences is a start-up company focused on reading the epitranscriptomic code, a regulatory layer of biological information controlling how the genetic code is used in cells in health and in disease progression. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein kinases orchestrate a wide range of cellular processes and play integral roles in cardiac development, function, and disease, making them attractive therapeutic targets. A member of the Protein Kinase Novel (PKN) family, PKN2, is dysregulated in numerous human cardiac conditions and is essential for cardiac development. Proposed studies will help us to understand the biological function of PKN2 in cardiomyocytes at molecular, cellular, and physiological levels, and identify critical PKN2 substrates as well as determine a safe therapeutic window for the potential application of PKN2 inhibitors in heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks occur when the protective fluid surrounding the brain and spine escapes through tears caused during traumatic brain injuries, spinal surgeries and otolaryngological surgeries and, if left undiagnosed, increase a patient’s risk for infections, meningitis, stroke and death. Chemeleon, Inc. is developing an easy-to-use colorimetric biosensor that rapidly changes color in minutes in the presence of CSF, a significant advancement from current detection technologies which require sending samples to external labs for results in 4-7 days. Chemeleon’s CSF biosensor will be operated by physicians and EMTs at the point-of-care, providing near-instantaneous results to help prevent future complications and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine how gentrification affects mobility patterns at the neighborhood levels and changes exposure to contextual determinants of health that have been shown to contribute to social and race/ethnic inequalities in health. The project builds on efforts to use longitudinal data based on traces directly produced by consumer activity with broad population coverage and high level of spatial and temporal specificity. This approach addresses the shortcomings of traditional demographic data sources, such as surveys, to establish the impact of gentrification on mobility and contextual determinants of health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: As treatments for rare genetic conditions become more broadly available, the need to identify at-risk individuals as early as possible has become increasingly important. This proposal presents a five-year research career development plan that will allow me to develop a unique set of interdisciplinary skills, thereby enabling my transition to independence as a physician-scientist focused on the implementation of preventive genomic medicine. The proposed research will demonstrate proof-of-concept for genome-first approaches and result in new estimates of prevalence and penetrance of risk variants associated with treatable genetic conditions in unselected populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Transforming Growth Factor (TGF)-Beta superfamily members play a critical role in repair, remodeling and fibrosis of the infarcted heart, signaling through intracellular effectors, the Smads and through non-Smad pathways. The current proposal will investigate cell- specific actions of Smad1 cascades in the infarcted heart. In vivo experiments using cell- specific knockout mice, in vitro loss- and gain-of-function studies and single cell RNAseq experiments will be performed to study Smad1-mediated actions on fibroblasts, macrophages, cardiomyocytes and pericytes, to dissect the molecular mechanisms responsible for Smad1 effects, and to explore the role of TGF-Beta signaling responses in mediating subset-specific functions of immune and reparative cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT: Patients with severe bleeding (hemorrhagic shock) due to trauma and other causes, who often also have infection and sepsis, can develop a deadly complication called acute lung injury. In this project, we will establish how the new inflammatory mediator eCIRP gets released after injury and activates the intracellular sensor STING to cause acute lung injury and death, and evaluate the benefit of a new eCIRP inhibitor, A12, on acute lung injury and survival after hemorrhagic shock complicated by sepsis. This project will establish the importance of these new mechanisms for the development of acute lung injury after hemorrhage and sepsis, and explore a new way to treat patients with these conditions.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of the United States-Mali Research Ethics Training Program (US-Mali RETP) is to strengthen research ethics education and research in Mali through an innovative model of sustainable capacity development to prepare the next generation of ethics researchers. Our approach will be based on close collaboration between George Washington University (GWU) Milken Institute School of Public Health (GWSPH), USA - and University of Science, Techniques & Technologies of Bamako (USTTB), Mali and is aimed at supporting USTTB’s vision of becoming a regional focus for research ethics in French Speaking west Africa. These institutions have a great commitment to understanding the ethical issues around health research, experience and expertise in research and a history of collaborative work and build on their twenty years of experience developing ethics training in Africa and the research environment built at USTTB plus over 25 years of collaboration between USTTB and NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We have identified genetic variants in inbred strains of mice which profoundly impact the initiation of cardiomyocyte cell cycle activity following myocardial injury. The experiments proposed in this application will identify the gene (or genes) responsible for this cell cycle activity and determine if they have a beneficial impact on the heart following injury. Ultimately, the identification and validation of genes underlying intrinsic differences in cardiomyocyte cell cycle rates could suggest potential therapeutic targets with which to enhance regenerative growth in injured hearts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: 8. Project narrative  Despite being a cause of tremendous morbidity to the aging population, treatment of stroke is presently poor in part because of limited understanding of the events set in motion by ischemia that culminate in loss of function and nerve cell death. In this study, we use in vitro and in vivo paradigms to follow up on compelling leads from ourselves and a large number of others investigators over the past two decades highlighting Zn2+ accumulation in neurons as a critical but inadequately understood early event in brain ischemia that plays an integral role in the initiation of downstream injury cascades. We hope that the studies will ultimately lead to improved understanding of mechanisms triggering delayed injury after ischemia and suggest potential new approaches for targeting them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Rett syndrome (RTT) is a neurodevelopmental disorder with a high mortality rate caused in part by respiratory dysfunction. RTT is caused by mutations in the gene encoding methyl-CpG-binding protein 2 (MECP2); however, it is not known how disruption of MeCP2 disrupts breathing. This project seeks to establish novel roles MeCP2 and Kir4.1/5.1 channels in astrocytes as the cellular and molecular basis of sleep-wake state dependent respiratory problems in a mouse model of RTT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The hypertensive diseases of pregnancy are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. ViTrack™ is a cuffless, wrist-wearable device that uses a fundamentally new method to accurately and non-invasively measure blood pressure. This study will validate ViTrack as the first standalone wearable device for accurate and continuous blood pressure monitoring during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Pain is the most common complication for patients with sickle cell disease. Very little is known about how sickle cell disease pain is processed in the brain, and as a result, few non-opioid based therapies are used to treat this symptom. In this proposal, we will manipulate gut bacteria in sickle cell disease mice then measure pain-related brain activity and behaviors to identify new targets for sickle cell disease pain treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Statement Women living with HIV may have a unique inflammatory response to HIV infection, partially attributable to sex- specific factors (such as the sex hormone estrogen) and sexual behavior-specific factors (such as participation in receptive anal intercourse). In this study, we will focus on defining these patterns of systemic and gut inflammation in treated HIV infection, and elucidating the microbial and molecular mechanisms driving these inflammatory signatures. This information could be critical for the development of sex-appropriate interventions for mitigating chronic inflammation in persons living with HIV.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A conserved forebrain to midbrain pathway is involved in a plethora of neural functions, including circadian  activity, reward, decision making, anxiety and fear, and has been implicated in neurological disorders such  as depression, schizophrenia, and addiction. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: People with epilepsy are 16 times more likely than the general population to die suddenly for unexplained pathological reasons. These deaths are classified as sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP), the leading cause of epilepsy-related mortality, but predictive biomarkers of SUDEP are lacking, which hinders accurate patient risk stratification and prevention. This proposal uses a new multidisciplinary bioengineering systems approach to identify pathological functional interactions between the brain, heart, and lungs in potassium and sodium channelopathy mouse models of SUDEP that could serve as new and more reliable biomarkers for monitoring SUDEP risk and disease progression in epilepsy patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that causes life-threatening opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS patients for which safer and more effective therapies are urgently needed. We have identified an essential system of mRNA modification in Toxoplasma that is composed of plant-like components. The goal of this proposal is to determine how these mRNA modification signals operate in parasite replication and development into latent tissue cysts, which promises to reveal important vulnerabilities that could be targeted by new drugs to combat AIDS- toxoplasmosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Primary and secondary (metastases) brain tumors are amongst the most lethal forms of cancer; the finding that cancer integration into neural circuitry drives tumor progression opens numerous doors to a deeper understanding of the role the nervous system plays in disease. Here, we investigate the broad crosstalk between dynamic neuronal circuits from differing regions in the brain that may collectively instruct primary and secondary brain tumor growth. Neuron-tumor interactions, including electrical cues from differing neuronal subpopulations, neuron-cancer circuit dynamics, and subsequent signaling in tumor cells, thus represent a novel set of therapeutic targets for this group of devastating cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune neurological disease affecting nearly 1 million people in the United States and is the most common cause of disability in young adults. MS is highly associated to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), but the mechanisms underlying MS are poorly understood. Success of the proposed studies would explain the connection between EBV and MS on a molecular level and could lead to transformative and fundamental treatment approaches focused on preventing or treating EBV rather than non-specifically depleting B cells or inhibiting immune cell trafficking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 40 million people are infected with HIV, an infection for which we do not have a cure. In this proposal, we seek to identify the properties of T cells that make them better able to kill cells infected with HIV. Our ultimate goal is to find strategies to harness these properties in order to improve future T cell-based therapies to cure HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly half of patients do not recover following the first line of treatment for OCD, exposure and response prevention (ERP). This study proposes to test a novel method of augmenting ERP, a computerized, scalable intervention targeting interpretation bias, which is a critical mechanism underlying OCD. The overall goal is to contribute to the development of technology-driven augmentations to ERP to enhance response rates, which may generalize to treatment for other OC-related and anxiety disorders in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Toxoplasma gondii is a widespread human pathogen that can cause life-threatening infection in the developing fetus and in people who are immunocompromised due to AIDS, chemotherapy or organ transplantation. This project will increase our understanding of how the parasite delivers proteins that are important to its ability to cause disease into the cells of its host during infection. A better understanding of this process will provide new opportunities for the development of drugs to treat the devastating disease caused by these parasites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 100 drugs can cause hearing loss, yet there are few technological solutions to detect the potential for new drugs to impact hearing. We have developed machine learning technology to predict drug-induced hearing loss. We will further optimize our technology to improve performance, then validate the technology in an animal model. Our goal is to improve safety during the drug development process by ruling out drugs that can cause hearing damage before they impact patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the most common cause of death in Veterans. CVD-related deaths are over twice as likely in patients with comorbid alcohol misuse, due in part to alcohol misuse directly exacerbating several modifiable factors that lead to CVD. 9-32% of all Veterans are in this high-risk, preventable population of comorbid alcohol misuse and elevated, modifiable CVD risk. No treatments have targeted this population. Current VA/DoD treatment guidelines for comorbid alcohol misuse in primary care are ineffective. Because alcohol misuse is often a recurrent problem, and the dominant driver of treatment recommendations, timely treatment of these Veterans’ CVD risk in conjunction with alcohol misuse treatment in may be critical for developing clinical traction with CVD risk. This research is highly relevant to Veteran health, VHA priorities, and HSR&D priorities because the combined intervention targets and telehealth approaches address critical gaps in treatment timeliness and access for this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Low use of outpatient PC limits the potential impact of PC consult teams on Veteran quality of life and end of life care. The long term objective of this research program is to understand how PCCT program structure influences appropriate use of high quality outpatient PC and identify programmatic strategies to improve outcomes for seriously ill Veterans. The objective of the proposed CDA is to evaluate the determinants of PC implementation outcomes of adoption and reach by applying the Practical, Robust, Implementation and Sustainability Model (PRISM) for implementation research. The project falls within HSR&D priorities for 1) primary care practice and management of complex chronic diseases and 2) aging, long-term care, and caregiving. The project is congruent with efforts of Durham VA’s Center of Innovation to Accelerate Discovery and Practice Transformation (ADAPT), which focuses on developing and testing models to preserve Veteran function and independence and on implementation science.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: This project is relevant to all aspects of VA healthcare for it will develop and evaluate a training toolkit to assist healthcare teams to change their culture toward learning to enhance Veteran care. This work will support the VA transformation to a learning health system, so clinicians can see every patient encounter as a way to make the next one better. This will be achieved through studying unit-level learning environments, identifying high- reliability practices that support a learning culture and using this knowledge to adapt a team training program to the culture and workflow of clinical units. We will develop and test a training toolkit to empower teams to de- velop their own culture of learning and a rigorous mixed methods evaluation that leads to valid, generalizable lessons applicable across healthcare settings. We expect this study to result in positive changes in learning environments, teamwork, and highly-reliable use of evidence-based practices. The findings will inform future studies to determine the impact of learning environments on Veteran outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Remyelination failure in diseases such as multiple sclerosis is believed to lead to neurodegeneration and cumulative disability, but the mechanisms linking chronic demyelination to neuronal loss are unclear. Here, we propose to use genetic animal models to better understand how neurons respond to loss of glial and myelin support. These studies will lay the foundation to develop new strategies to promote neuronal resilience in the demyelinated human nervous system.

PHR: NARRATIVE Intervertebral disc (IVD) degeneration is a major contributor to back pain and disability with a lack of effective treatment strategies, and the poor IVD healing capacity requires new ways of thinking. This project uses a novel IVD regenerative healing model and innovative genetic and microscopy tools to identify cells and extracellular matrix microenvironment factors critical for enabling IVD healing and regeneration. Next, design criteria for cell delivery are identified and validated on human cells and tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persons with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) experience behavioral symptoms such as agitation, combativeness, depression, and apathy. These behaviors increase caregiver stress, which leads to negative outcomes, such as poor health, depression, and increased caregiver burden. This project seeks to develop and test an intervention to enhance active caregiver skill training to prepare caregivers to better manage behavioral symptoms in order to improve ADRD caregiver wellbeing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This study will breach a gap in knowledge regarding the role Müller cells, the primary glial cell in retina, play in non-neovascular AMD pathology. This study will also identify what stimulates Müller cell migration and proliferation leading to subretinal membrane formation, which we have reported in eyes with geographic atrophy. By looking at how Müller cell changes in AMD affect other cells, including retinal pigment epithelial cells, these studies may identify novel therapeutic targets for treating AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Advanced cancer can lead to significant emotional distress for patients and partners and can adversely affect their relationships. Couples’ ability to communicate openly and effectively with each other about cancer-related concerns can improve their psychological adjustment and quality of their relationship, and may lead to better symptom management and goal-concordant care. This study will test the effects of an intervention designed to enhance couples’ ability to communicate effectively about important cancer-related concerns, delivered via videoconference and targeted to couples at risk for poor outcomes. If successful, we will have developed a brief, targeted, and scalable intervention that could be integrated into routine palliative care, resulting in better outcomes for both patients and their family caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Peripheral and autonomic neuropathies degrade quality of life and are linked to autoimmune disease and prevalent in patients receiving chemotherapy, but few treatments exist to alleviate these conditions. Because our skin and internal organs are in constant motion, so are the sensory neurons embedded in these tissues. The proposed multidisciplinary experiments and integrated theoretical research exploits a simple genetic model to develop a comprehensive understanding of how mechanical force is detected by sensory neurons and how these same neurons bend without breaking, focusing on cytoskeletal structures like microtubules and spectrin that are conserved in humans and implicated in sensitivity to traumatic brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH  Integrin dysfunction has been linked to severe health conditions such as thrombotic disorders, cardiovascular diseases, and inflammatory diseases. We proposed to elucidate regulatory mechanisms in integrin signaling in a species-specific manner and to develop peptidomimetic inhibitors that target the activator molecule of integrin. Our study will offer new insights into the integrin signaling mechanisms and a new class of integrin inhibitors by suppressing the activity of an intracellular integrin activator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Our previous and preliminary studies have identified aging related genes as important players for regulating axon regeneration. The proposed study will determine the roles of several of these genes in promoting optic nerve regeneration and identify novel aging regulatory genes that can be targeted to promote optic nerve regeneration using RNA-seq/ATAC-seq with advanced bioinformatics analyses. The result will not only reveal novel molecular mechanisms underlying mammalian axon regeneration, but also identify new and effective molecular targets for enhancing optic nerve regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging is commonly associated with visceral obesity, insulin resistance, and also increased inflammation. Our project proposes to study the role and mechanisms of adipose tissue inflammation in visceral obesity and insulin resistance associated with aging. Knowledge gained from our studies may help develop novel therapies for age-associated inflammation and metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE  Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a chronic, relapsing, prevalent, disabling and fatal disorder for which new drug targets and neurobiological insight are needed. Guided by novel preliminary data, this multidisciplinary project tests the overarching hypothesis that decreasing dorsal striatal phosphodiesterase 10A (PDE10A) type 2 activity in indirect medium spiny neurons (MSN) can reduce compulsive drinking. Our assembled team seeks to fill key gaps in our neurobiological, pharmacological and genetic understanding of the role of PDE10A isoforms in striatal MSN circuits and compulsive drinking that will shed light on the potential impact of novel translatable PDE10A inhibitors to treat AUD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: A major challenge for the VA lies in the provision of specialty services to the 50% of Veterans who require them, and one condition with a particular unmet need for specialty care is obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Many Veterans are referred to community care providers to provide specialty access, but our preliminary data suggest these referrals can be costly and lead to delays in care. Using care for OSA as a model, our research seeks to inform the delivery of VA specialty services in a Veteran-centered, effective and efficient way. To do so, we will refine and pilot a program of virtual sleep consults to facilitate care within community based outpatient clinics. We will elicit perspectives from Veterans and health care providers to guide necessary adaptations to our program, and will pilot our intervention to obtain information essential to planning a definitive trial. We will also conduct nationwide cost and budget impact analyses to better understand costs of current practices, and project the costs of replacing community care referrals with VA-based services.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cardiac rehabilitation, an outpatient program that includes supervised exercise and cardiovascular risk factor education, is one of the most important therapies for patients with cardiovascular disease. Unfortunately, very few Veterans with cardiovascular disease enroll in cardiac rehabilitation programs. This proposal will evaluate Veterans’ individual barriers to attending cardiac rehabilitation with both surveys and interviews. Using this information, we will develop a behavioral intervention to encourage Veterans to enroll in outpatient cardiac rehabilitation programs. This intervention will be individually tailored to Veterans with the information- motivation-behavioral skills model, a theory of behavior change. We will test the tailored intervention with a proof-of-concept study in Veterans hospitalized with cardiovascular disease at the Veterans Affairs Tennessee Valley Healthcare System. This project is relevant to Veterans’ health because increasing enrollment in cardiac rehabilitation will decrease mortality and increase quality of life in Veterans with cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Individuals on the autism spectrum experience poor outcomes over the life course, including reduced life expectancy, high rates of co-occurring health conditions, poor healthcare access and quality, poor quality of life, and low rates of employment, independent living, and community engagement. In order to evaluate new and existing services targeted toward improving these outcomes, researchers and services providers need accessible, patient-centered, psychometrically sound, and pragmatic patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) that have been tested in multiple real-world settings. The AutProm Toolbox, developed and evaluated in this proposal, will meet that need, enabling researchers and service providers to more effectively evaluate and implement services that improve the health, function, and wellbeing of adults on the autism spectrum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Foveal diseases are a major cause of blindness in the United States without current available therapies. In this proposal we propose to recapitulate in vivo patterns of retinoic acid signaling in human stem cell-derived retinal organoids to establish a novel foveated in vitro model system that can be subsequently used as a valuable platform for disease modeling, drug screening and source of fovea-specific cells for transplantation approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Prevention of depressive disorders has become a key priority for the NIMH, but we have no widely available public health strategy to reduce morbidity and mortality. To address this need, we developed and evaluated the primary care based-technology “behavioral vaccine,” Competent Adulthood Transition with Cognitive-Behavioral Humanistic and Interpersonal Therapy (CATCH- IT). We will engage N=4 health systems representative of the United States health care system, and conduct a factorial design study to optimize the intervention in preparation for an implementation study and eventual dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term goal of this proposal is to develop a protein inhibitor against Bcr-Abl, the causative agent of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and 30% of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), that circumvents current problems with Bcr-Abl targeted therapy. Computationally designed coiled- coil proteins will be synthetically made, and will be tested for ability to inhibit dimerization of Bcr- Abl. These peptides are designed to specifically enter leukemia cells, be resistant to degradation, be stable in the bloodstream, and show efficacy in blocking the activity of Bcr-Abl, thus providing a new type of therapy for these leukemias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the mechanism behind and treatment of genome abnormalities in the population that cause rare genetic disease in the individual represents a major challenge from both basic science and clinical perspectives. We will study the impact of genetic variation found in the Niemann Pick C1 (NPC1) gene, that, like APOE alleles driving late-onset Alzheimers disease (LOAD), is responsible for management of cholesterol homeostasis. We will use Gaussian process regression machine learning (GPR-ML) based spatial covariance (SCV) tools to define the mechanism of action of proteostasis components found in the Hsp70 axis to therapeutically manage the NPC1 fold leading to improved to cholesterol homeostasis in the individual to provide basic and clinical insight into disease management.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Chronic pain disproportionately affects Veterans and is often managed in VA primary care. Because chronic pain may exhibit physical, emotional, social, and existential dimensions, it is also a condition for which interdisciplinary team approaches are clinically important. A variety of pain team models have been implemented in diverse clinical settings and many have been found to be effective. Highly functioning interdisciplinary teams, however, are difficult to actualize, especially when teams have dynamic membership and different providers slot onto teams to fulfill specific roles or tasks around a specific patient’s pain management plan. I therefore propose to develop an intervention to improve the act of dynamic teaming around the multiple shared tasks involved in managing chronic pain. This research brings the theory, methods, and lessons learned from the organizational behavior literature to the challenge of chronic pain management. This proposal offers a timely response to VA HSR&D’s priority of addressing pain and opioid use, both of which are occurring in epidemic proportion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Steady-state hematopoiesis in bone marrow is critical for maintenance of blood cell genesis and immune competence throughout life. Concomitant with aging, the bone marrow hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) compartment produces fewer lymphoid lineage progeny and the molecular basis remains unknown. The goal of this project is to determine the role of the HOX protein Hoxa9 in regulation of lymphopoietic potential from HSC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The focus of the proposed study contributes to National Institute on Aging’s goals of promoting research that utilizes multilevel approaches to elucidate mechanisms that contribute to health disparities in Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders (ADRD), and to identify malleable targets for interventions to ameliorate health disparities. Guided by the NIH-Stage Model, this study will complete the initial stage of the model to identify the mechanisms which ADS influence caregiving-related stressors and needs for African American dementia caregivers. Findings from the study will be used to inform the development of a culturally-tailored stress reduction intervention for African American dementia caregivers.
