IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative During cell division, duplicated chromosomes are organized and separated by an exquisite molecular machine, the mitotic spindle. This project will bring us closer to a complete understanding of how the spindle works. Understanding the mitotic spindle is critical for developing better chemotherapeutics. Drugs that target tubulin are used against many cancers, but they cause considerable side effects. Unlike tubulin, however, other spindle components function only in dividing cells, so new drugs targeting these components could stop cancer proliferation with fewer side effects. In addition to its medical relevance, the work will bring us closer to a complete understanding of one of nature’s most fascinating molecular machines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive and functional decline are common and devastating consequences of sepsis survivorship. Alzheimer’s disease neuropathology is common in the cognitively normal population and may represent a latent risk factor for persistent brain dysfunction in sepsis survivors. We hypothesize that amyloid beta neuropathology and sepsis enhance activity of the complement system in the brain, driving neuroinflammation, glial activation, and synapse loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative A broadly neutralizing antibody (bnAb)-directed HIV vaccine is possible in concept, but exceptional immunological hurdles must be overcome to reach that goal. Major limitations in our understanding of the biology of GCs to difficult antigens include (1) “Is immunodominance in GC responses preventing development of bnAbs to conventional immunizations?”, and 2) “Is sustained exposure to antigen in GCs necessary for the extensive somatic hypermutation (SHM) associated with the generation of bnAbs?” We will explore these questions in the context of a candidate HIV vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Low-level chronic inflammation (LLCI) occurs in mammals during aging as a result of responses in the immune system to a variety of stimuli and contributes to bone loss and the development of osteoporosis, but the mechanisms by which LLCI induces age-related bone loss remain incompletely understood. We have identified a new subset of white blood cells (B lymphocytes, which we have called RANKL+CXCR4+ B lymphocytes, RCBs for short), that accumulate in the bone marrow during aging where they appear to stimulate bone destruction and inhibit new bone formation. We plan to further investigate the biological functions of RCBs, the mechanisms that induce their accumulation in the bone marrow during aging, and to test the effects of compounds that might specifically reduce RCB accumulation in the bone marrow in animal models of age-related osteoporosis and be developed into new drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of the underlying mechanisms leading to the development of senescent FOXP3+ cells in inflammation will open novel experimental therapeutics, including cellular therapy in human Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) and other immune- mediated diseases (i.e., rheumatologic, neurologic, dermatologic conditions, and cancer). Insight into the development of senescent FOXP3+ cells will benefit TREG cell therapy trials, as well as trials of epigenetic regulators in cancer research. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge to reduce human illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) affects over 1.3 million Americans, but despite intensive research, the exact cause of IBD remains unclear. Interactions between the surface proteins and sugars of microbes and human cells have important effects on inflammation and its regulation, but their investigation is difficult due to the complex genetic and chemical environment of the gut. This project aims to design and apply advanced computational methods based on deep learning to enhance the discovery of significant changes in microbial proteins and sugars with a goal of gaining new insights into the development, progression, and treatment of IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small RNA drugs hold great promise for the study and treatment of neurodegenerative disorders, but they must be chemically modified for efficient delivery to the central nervous system (CNS). This project will determine how chemical modifications impact small RNA activity and localization in the CNS, and will use this information to design optimized small RNA drugs to dissect the role of nuclear Huntingtin RNA toxicity in Huntington’s Disease (HD). Findings from this study will inform optimal treatment strategies for HD, and build a framework for therapeutic small RNA design for use in the CNS.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans are more likely than the general population to experience chronic pain. Opioid medications are sometimes used to treat chronic pain, but other treatment strategies, including opioid tapering or switching to buprenorphine, might be good alternatives to traditional opioid therapy, especially for patients experiencing opioid misuse. The results of this project will make it easier to identify when patients taking opioids for chronic pain are at high risk for adverse outcomes, and determine which treatments are most effective at both reducing risks and managing pain. Veterans and Veterans Health Administration providers will be consulted about translating results into practice to improve care for Veterans with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This proposal addresses the need for better understanding of the neurobehavioral basis of the compulsive and chronically relapsing nature of alcohol addiction. Neurobiological and medications development information from animal models of relapse to alcohol use is limited largely to studies in alcohol nondependent animals. To advance understanding of the alcohol addiction process and ultimately improve treatment strategies, the proposed studies will investigate the significance of a previously not well recognized but presumably major factor in relapse vulnerability: the effects of stimuli conditioned to the potent addictive dimensions of alcohol associated with alcohol consumption to ameliorate withdrawal distress and neurobiological basis of these stimulus effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative - Center for Viral Systems Biology (CViSB) Lassa virus, Ebola virus, and SARS-CoV-2 are three of the most devastating human pathogens, yet some individuals are better able to ﬁght infection than others. We will perform system-wide analyses of host, virus, and environmental factors that contribute to the severity and spread of human disease. By creating large integrated systems data sets of clinical, genetic, immunological, biological, microbial, functional, and physiological features, we will build sophisticated predictive models that will reveal the molecular interactions and network structures underlying successful clearance of Lassa, Ebola, and SARS-CoV-2 viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative, Overall (Thalamus in the middle: computations in multi-regional neural circuits) The thalamus is the main conduit for subcortical information flow to the cortex. Despite decades of work in the sensory thalamus, we know little about non-sensory (or 'higher-order') thalamus, even though higher-order thalamus is the largest part of the thalamus and damaging it can cause cognitive and motor disorders, as well as coma and hypersomnia. This collaboration will map the architecture of subcortex → thalamus → cortex circuits, measure functional relationships of these brain regions with cell type-specificity during multiple cognitive behaviors, and synthesize these data in conceptual and computational models for a multi-regional neural circuit theory of cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative, Administrative Core The Administrative Core will provide the leadership and organizational structure to align the efforts of the individual Institutions, projects and researchers to meet the overall goals and milestones. This will involve integrating and aligning the efforts of five Research Projects (detailed map of region-specific and cell type- specific connectivity between subcortex, thalamus, and cortex; connectivity based on electrophysiology and optogenetics; high-density electrophysiology in multi-regional circuits; and multi-regional network models of computation and behavior), the Molecular Science Core (thalamocortical molecular tools), and the Data Science Core. The Administrative Core will oversee the operational management including strategic planning, project management, progress reporting, fiscal management, manuscript and authorship planning, conflict resolution and support for collaboration and communication to create, integrate, and disseminate to the community high- value anatomical and neurophysiological data as well as cloud-based data analysis workflows.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In keeping with NIA’s mission of supporting behavioral and social age-related research – with an emphasis on studying Alzheimer’s disease and other Dementias – as well as the strategic direction to better understand and address the social impacts and burden of age-related disease, this proposal tests an intervention to reduce depression and anxiety among family caregivers of persons living with dementia (PLWD) as well as reduce grief intensity among family caregivers PLWD. In the Caregiver Speaks intervention, caregivers will engage in photo-elicitation storytelling (sharing photos that capture their thoughts, feelings, and reactions to caregiving and bereavement) via a privately facilitated Facebook group. This intervention will longitudinally follow caregivers from active caregiving and into bereavement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative, Molecular Science Core We propose to mine single cell transcriptomics and epigenomics data to discover molecular markers for thalamic cell types and to build mouse transgenic and viral tools for genetic access to thalamic cell classes, subclasses or types. The markers and tools will be used in other research segments to investigate thalamic neuron connectivity, activity and function as soon as they become available. All the data, reagents, and transgenic animals will be made publicly available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative, Project 1 (Comprehensively map the mesoscale thalamic circuits that route subcortical inputs to frontal cortex) We will create a detailed circuit diagram connecting subcortical brain regions, non-sensory thalamus, and the frontal cortex. These circuits are critical for cognitive functions such as reward-dependent learning, short-term memory and movement planning. Mapping these circuits is also necessary for understanding disorders caused by damage to the thalamus, including cognitive and motor disorders, as well as coma and hypersomnia.

PHR: NARRATIVE Disruption of circadian rhythms can result in signficant physiological consequences inlcuding metabolic disorders and cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative, Project 2 (Produce the cell-type-specific thalamocortical projectome) We will uncover the diversity of thalamocortical (TC) neurons using detailed reconstructions of single cells and measuring their gene expression. We will then map molecular TC types across the thalamus using cutting-edge multiplexed spatial transcriptomics methods. These multi-modal datasets will provide the foundation for genetic access to specific TC types and provide the structural blueprint to understanding how subcortical areas influence cortical activity via the thalamus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL) Retrotransposable elements (RTEs) are virus-like parasites that are permanently embedded in our bodies. We are born with them and we bear the consequences for our entire lives. RTEs are largely deleterious to our health but they are held in check by a variety of defenses. Recent research suggests that these mechanisms fail as we age and the consequent unleashing of RTEs promotes age-related diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. The goal of this program is to study and understand these processes so that we can develop therapies that will cure these devastating neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative, Project 3 (Impact of subcortical inputs on frontal cortex via thalamus) Subcortical brain regions send diverse functional signals to the frontal cortex, but how they are routed through non-sensory thalamus remains mysterious. Here we use a combination of in vivo and ex vivo electrophysiology and voltage imaging to study these connections in unprecedented detail. Our work will reveal the functional organization and physiological properties of connections important for cognitive and reward-related behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative, Project 4 (Identify the schemata by which subcortical signals influence frontal cortical dynamics and cognitive behaviors) We perform high-density electrophysiological recordings in behaving mice to discover how subcortical brain regions influence frontal cortex via the thalamus and enable multiple cognitive behaviors. These studies are expected to lead to a conceptual framework of the non-sensory thalamus, which in turn will lead to an understanding of disorders caused by damage to the thalamus, including cognitive and motor disorders, as well as hypersomnia and coma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Many questions remain regarding the role of immunity in the etiology of cognitive decline and Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias (ADRD). Using the Health and Retirement Study (HRS), we will examine associations between peripheral immunosenescence and cognitive function, decline, and incident ADRD, with specific attention to social inequalities in these processes. At its conclusion, this study will yield critical insights to our understanding of the pathophysiology of cognitive decline and ADRD, creating new opportunities for early detection and targeting at the population level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Meiotic recombination is a fundamental genetic and evolutionary process, whose successful completion is necessary for the production of egg and sperm. How meiotic recombination events are directed to the genome varies across vertebrates and remains poorly understood. By combining approaches from population genetics, genomics and phylogenetics, we will elucidate how recombination events are localized in the genome and how and why the mechanism differs across taxa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Zika virus (ZIKV), an emerging human pathogen, causes congenital eye and neurological diseases, and we observed that ZIKV modulates the components of developmental Hippo signaling and energy sensor AMPK pathways in infected ocular cells. The molecular mechanisms of AMPK and Hippo pathway deregulation and the role of Zika viral virulence factors in ocular injury and development is poorly understood. We propose to elucidate the basic mechanisms of ZIKV mediated- deregulation of AMPK and Hippo pathways and cellular antiviral response using human ocular cell culture systems, retinal cup organoids, and mice models, which could yield novel insights into the pathogenesis of ZIKV ocular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative, Project 5 (Models of computation in multi-regional circuits with thalamus in the middle) The thalamus is the communication hub of the forebrain and plays key roles in cognitive functions such as decision-making, short-term memory, and voluntary motor control. Although subcortical areas influence cortical activity via the thalamus, we lack an understanding how the non-sensory thalamus routes information to influence cortex. Here we develop theoretical models of the interactions between subcortical areas, thalamus and cortex in the context of sensory and value-based decision-making. These models will provide a conceptual framework of the non-sensory thalamus, which in turn may lead to an understanding of disorders caused by damage to the thalamus, including cognitive and motor disorders, as well as hypersomnia and coma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will develop a dynamic simulation modeling framework for surveillance, prediction, and real-time allocation of essential resources to underserved communities in order to reduce health disparities during Covid-19 and future pandemics. Our flexible modeling framework will integrate real-time data on infectious disease outcomes with individual and community level contextual factors to inform infectious disease surveillance and improve understanding of disease epidemiology in underserved communities, and to support the decision-making process for resource allocation to high-risk populations. In collaboration with public health decision-makers, we will utilize our toolkit to inform real-time scheduling of South Carolina’s fleet of Covid-19 mobile vaccination clinics to underserved communities across the state; this has potential to save countless lives during the Covid-19 pandemic and will lay the foundation for effective resource allocation to underserved communities in other health emergencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Malaria is among the deadliest infectious diseases and kills an estimated half million persons every year. This project seeks to identify vaccine epitopes that target three critical stages of parasite infection of the liver. The findings may lead to the development of a novel and improved malaria pre-erythrocytic vaccine.

PHR: Narrative: This project focuses on how RNAs are packaged into extracellular carriers to communicate with neighboring cells, using colorectal carcinoma as a model system. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lenacapavir is a promising, investigational, long-acting and highly potent HIV capsid inhibitor that could complement current antiretroviral compounds to treat people living with HIV. However, cell culture-based viral breakthrough assays and ongoing clinical trials have identified substitutions in capsid that confer substantial resistance to lenacapavir. We propose to rationally modify lenacapavir to develop improved HIV capsid inhibitors with a improved potency and high barrier to resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: exRNA in Colorectal Carcinoma: Biogenesis and Function Project 2. Mechanisms and Functional Consequences of Selective miRNA Transfer via Exosomes Narrative Extracellular communication by RNA is a recently discovered mechanism that may underlie mechanisms explaining tumor-microenvironment interactions, metastasis, and the cancer field effect. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cervical cancer continues to cause disability and death in millions of women living in tropical regions of the world who do not have access to cervical cancer screening and human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccination. People living in tropical countries are commonly infected with intestinal worms (helminths), which can live largely undetected in their hosts by muting the immune response. Understanding the impact of helminth infection on the cervico-vaginal microenvironment may lead to the development of improved cervical cancer prevention strategies in tropical countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Coffey-Project 3 Narrative The intestine is one of the most renewed epithelium in the body, supplied by active stem cells that can incur mutations leading to colorectal cancer. Two important interacting pathways help to regulate stem cell function and can become misregulated in cancer; these are called the WNT and EGFR signaling pathways. Our goal is to understand the cell non-autonomous function played by secreted vesicles and other secreted factors (EVs and exomeres) and associated secreted RNAs in maintaining the normal balance of stem cells and in driving colorectal cancer progression by regulating EGFR and WNT signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Despite the increasing availability and effectiveness of antiretroviral therapy, HIV continues to be the greatest pandemic of the last 50 years — 70 million infected, 36 million currently living with HIV and over 1.8 million new infections, including over 180,000 new infant infections annually — so it is imperative to develop an effective population-based approach to reduce transmission. This proposal for the Leadership and Operations Center of the HIV Vaccine Trials Network, the collaboration of scientists at 64 clinical trial sites in 15 countries on 4 continents dedicated to developing a globally effective HIV vaccine, describes the marked advances in candidate vaccines to induce broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs), the advances in bnAbs administered by injection at levels that can prevent infection, and the HVTN’s extensive programs in engaging both local communities and other scientists throughout the world working to stop the spread of HIV. The goal of the HVTN is to develop a vaccine or monoclonal antibody combination that will, either alone or in combination, reduce HIV acquisition in adults and children by more than 60 percent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – Core 2 The Extracellular Vesicle (EV) Purification and Analysis Core will isolate, quantify, characterize, and assess purity of EVs to be provided to the individual projects so that the needs of the proposed studies are met. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Post-transcriptional regulation can significantly alter gene expression and contribute to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) mechanisms. The proposed research aims to combine bioinformatic and experimental methods to study functional genetic mutations or polymorphisms that cause post-transcriptional changes in AD. This work will provide mechanistic basis for how genetic variations may contribute to AD, such that future interventions can target specific genes therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the current enormous interest in understanding biophysical principles and properties of RNP granules through liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) or condensation, we still lack the full understanding of their function in cells. This study identifies a novel stress response pathway that links stress induced cytosolic RNA aggregation into stress granules to transcription regulation. The proposed research will increase our understanding of stress granule function, their role in coupling cytosolic and nuclear stress responses, and illuminate general principles for other RNP condensates and disease associated RNP aggregates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of obesity and metabolic dysfunction continues to rise, particularly among women; a detrimental consequence is increased breast cancer risk and worse patient outcome. This proposal will 1) advance our understand of obesity’s impact breast cancer; 2) examine if a novel weight loss strategy, intermittent energy restriction, can eliminate obesity-associated tumor progression; and 3) investigate if this intervention will be valuable for helping breast cancer patients improve outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite the high in incidence of deleterious symptoms associated with menopause in women, the only effective treatment to block these symptoms remains estrogen-based therapies which carry significantly elevated risks of breast/uterus cancer in patients on these therapies. There is a critical need to have a safer alternative to estrogen therapy to alleviate the menopausal symptoms, hot flushes in particular, without the peripheral side-effects. This advanced translational project test if the novel prodrug DHED, which is biologically inert in the periphery but converted to estrogen selectively and only in the brain, can prevent hot flushes while having no peripheral effects on breast/uterus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is critical to maintaining our vision, and degeneration of the RPE can lead to irreversible vision loss. This research will examine the basic biology of the RPE and how it supports the health of the retina, allowing our eyes to turn light into a signal that we can perceive as sight. Knowledge of how these processes work is expected to inform the development of therapeutics to combat age-related and genetic blinding diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Neurodegenerative diseases, especially Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and Parkinson’s Disease (PD), are devastating cognitive or motor-disabling conditions, for which there are no therapies currently. We propose to test an innovative genetic tool that helps clear protein aggregates that cause neuronal toxicity from neurons, and investigate its therapeutic effects in vitro and in vivo in AD and PD mouse models. This project may develop a novel potential gene-therapy tool for AD and PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stargardt disease is the most common inherited macular degeneration in children that leads to progressive vision loss and eventually to legal blindness by age 50. The macular degeneration seen in Stargardt disease is caused by impaired clearance of toxic molecules that are released by light-sensitive opsin proteins found in photoreceptors when they capture light. In this proposal, I will investigate whether irreversibly blocking the ability of opsins to release these toxic species is a viable strategy to providing long-lasting protection to the retina from light-induced damage, and delay the onset and progression of macular degeneration in STGD1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The correct topological organization of the B-lymphocyte genome during development and antibody gene diversification events prevents aberrant chromosomal translocations and promote antibody diversification mechanisms. Recent advances in transcriptomics and genomics have identified the role of long noncoding RNA expressing enhancer sequences in the organization of B cell genomes. In this application, we evaluate the role of three long noncoding RNA expressing loci in maintaining the correct architecture and local topology of B cell genomes and for promoting antibody diversification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: In this project, we will quantify the relationship between genetic variants, age, diet, sex, mitochondrial DNA copy number, longevity and Alzheimer’s disease using a diverse cohort of BXD and transgenic AD-BXD mouse lines, which segregate for over 6 million genetic variants. This approach allows a chain of causality between genetic variants, environmental effects, cellular processes, and whole-organism outcomes, such as cognitive decline in aging. The use of a genetically and environmentally reproducible population will allow us to integrate all of our data with a previously collected phenome of over 7500 traits and over 110 omics datasets, including longevity, memory, learning, motor, and neuroanatomical phenotypes, as well as translate across species using human genome-wide (GWAS) and phenome-wide (PheWAS) association study data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optic neuritis (ON), or demyelinating inflammation of the optic nerve, is strongly associated with Multiple Sclerosis (MS), and 50% of all the MS patients (2.5 million globally) are estimated to develop one or more episodes of ON during the course of their disease. For patients with long-term vision loss from ON who have no effective treatment available, remyelination-based treatment has the potential to help, but the remyelination process in human is not fully understood. Here we propose to use human stem cell derived oligodendrocytes (OLs) and retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) to investigate the mechanism involved in RGC myelination by OLs that can be exploited for promoting remyelination of the demyelinated optic nerve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most cancer patients experience financial hardship as a direct result of receiving expensive cancer care and lost income. Our study will test the effectiveness of a multicomponent financial counseling program, CostCOM, that will help patients with newly diagnosed cancer at NCI community oncology research program (NCORP) practices across the United State to learn about their personalized treatment out-of-pocket costs using a price estimator tool, understand their insurance benefits, and receive financial navigation (e.g., get enrolled in financial assistance programs). We anticipate that CostCOM compared to enhanced usual care will improve cost-related cancer care nonadherence and quality of life and decrease material financial hardship and financial worry.

PHR: Double stranded RNAs are exciting regulatory molecules, powerful tools for basic biological sciences, and targets for novel therapeutic approaches. This proposal will explore chemical modifications to optimize the properties of such RNA molecules and study the mechanism of their action. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project will leverage data on two cohorts (Medicaid and Medicare enrollees) to characterize the impact of air pollution on risk for and progression of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD), and identify the complex interactions of individual-level, environmental and societal factors that lead to increased vulnerability in AD/ADRD. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a disabling, chronic, and costly psychiatric condition that is estimated to occur in 23% of Veterans with recent service in Iraq and/or Afghanistan.1 Although there are available treatments for PTSD, studies suggest that fewer than 10% of Veterans receive the recommended dose of psychotherapy;2-4 moreover, the use of efficacious evidenced-based psychotherapy (EBP) is even lower.5 The role of Veteran and family-level determinants in the initiation and completion of an adequate dose of psychotherapy for PTSD is unclear and without robust evidence, efforts to develop and test strategies to strengthen these determinants will remain limited. The proposed research is highly relevant to Veteran health because it will use novel machine learning approaches to identify these risk-factors and test two innovative approaches to strengthen Veterans determinants of PTSD psychotherapy engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have discovered that microglia play a critical role in compacting and insulating amyloid plaques, which renders them less toxic to adjacent neuronal processes. We are proposing to utilize sophisticated live imaging and high-resolution microscopy combined with molecular manipulations to investigate how microglia interact with another cell type, astrocytes, during the protective encapsulation of amyloid plaques. We hypothesize that coordinated encapsulation by these two glial cells is critical for preventing damage to adjacent axons. We hope that this interaction can be exploited therapeutically to diminish the progression of neural dysfunction in Alzheimer disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Protein tyrosine sulfation plays important roles in, e.g., protein-protein interactions, inflammation, and viral infections. Due to the extreme lability of this posttranslational modification (PTM), global liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry analysis has not been feasible to date; however we discovered a novel workflow that partially enables such measurements. Here, we propose new strategies to further enhance detection and allow site determination of this widespread PTM in cells and tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Serotonin, and specifically serotonin receptor 4 (5-HTR4), has been shown to have reparative effects on skin and colonic wounds; however, the mechanism behind this phenomenon is unclear. Our preliminary data in human intestinal enteroids indicate that 5-HTR4 activation stimulates release of trefoil factor 3 (TFF3) to promote repair in live imaging wound healing assays. Thus, in this proposal we seek to definitively link 5-HTR4 and TFF3 and identify the molecular mechanisms of colonic wound repair in mice and enteroids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses gaps in prevention and control of high blood pressures through engagement of trusted community leaders – in this case, by working with highly respected religious leaders in Tanzania. High blood pressure is the leading risk factor for premature mortality worldwide, and is also more common in disadvantaged communities. Therefore, this proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission of fostering “innovative research strategies… for ultimately protecting and improving health” and to reducing health disparities, as well as specifically responsive to the NHLBI’s goal of studying implementation strategies to prevent cardiovascular disease.

PHR: Relevance The basal ganglia are implicated in many neurological and psychiatric disorders, such as Parkinson’s disease, Huntington’s disease, and obsessive-compulsive disorder. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity, which is prevalent in 40% of American adults, is associated with a greater prevalence of high-risk nocturnal blood pressure (BP) profile, which predisposes them to adverse cardiovascular events. The putative deficiency of natriuretic peptides (NPs) in obese, and the misalignment of the NP-RAAS-BP rhythm axis, may contribute to the high nocturnal BP among obese individuals. The proposed study seeks to determine the biological implications of the 1) NP-RAAS-BP rhythm-axis based chronopharmacotherapy to resynchronize the physiological diurnal rhythms, and 2) NP augmentation to restore the normal diurnal BP profile in obese individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The ends of chromosomes, called telomeres, play a key role in dictating long term cellular proliferation and genome stability. As a result, altered telomere maintenance can lead to challenges to human health late in life, as well as playing a role in cancer development. This application presents a new model proposing that the machinery that maintains the ends of chromosomes is closely linked to protein complexes that facilitate genome-wide chromosomal replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the APOE4 gene, encoding one of the variants of apolipoprotein E, is known to greatly increase the chance of developing Alzheimer's disease (AD), the mechanisms by which APOE4 increases AD risk are not completely understood. We will tackle this highly relevant medical question based on a novel hypothesis that focuses on the unique interaction of APOE4 protein with another AD-relevant molecule, heparan sulfate, a highly bioactive sugar chain present on the surface of microglia. Successful completion of this project will not only provide novel insight into the importance of heparan sulfate in AD, but will also identify the APOE4- heparan sulfate interaction as a promising therapeutic target for reducing AD risk in carriers of the APOE4 gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Corneal pain is an important mechanism to detect injury or damage, leading to protective responses to limit injury if possible (tearing to remove a foreign object), initiate healing and protect the ocular surface required for clear vision. When maladaptive, corneal pain can be so debilitating as to limit daily function, dramatically reduce quality of life, and cause significant economic burden. The proposed research will elucidate the molecular, cellular, anatomical and neurobiological mechanisms of ocular pain and hypersensitivity including photoallodynia by investigating corneal nerves and their responses in non- human disease models of corneal surface injury/dry eye, allergic eye disease and migraine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative In this proposal, I will use a preclinical rodent model of repeat traumatic brain injury to investigate the hypothesis that synaptic deficits underly retrograde memory and investigate if forgotten memories can be restored by reactivating memory specific neuronal populations (engram neurons). By leveraging novel techniques never done in the TBI field to label engram neurons, I will exploit immunohistochemistry and electrophysiology to explore synaptic modifications in engram neurons and in vivo optogenetics to reanimate forgotten memories. This research is important for our current understanding of how retrograde cognition arises in the repeat head impact brain and will provide me with training to help me achieve my goals of being a physician-scientist who specializes in treatment of mild traumatic brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) remains a major public health problem with no disease modifying therapies. Converging evidence from human and mouse genetics implicates the gene encoding embryonic ectoderm development (Eed), an essential component of the epigenetic polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2), as a regulator of Trem2 signaling in microglia and AD risk. Our goal is to understand the mechanistic link between Eed and Trem2 and in the long term to target these pathways for therapeutics for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite years of study, we do not understand the developmental mechanisms that are responsible for bringing together the inputs from the two eyes to create a single coherent cortical representation of stimulus features. The proposed experiments will provide new insights into the synaptic basis for binocular integration, and the underlying developmental mechanisms that guide this alignment process—insights that are critical for addressing numerous visual, neurological, and psychiatric disorders that are grounded in cortical circuit dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RNA helicases are enzymes that rearrange RNA structures in all living cells, from bacteria to humans. Misregulation of the RNA helicase DDX5 results in human pathologies including cancer and metabolic disorders. This research aims to uncover the biochemical and biological function of this enzyme as a central tenet to human disease intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our ability to rapidly and effortlessly categorize incoming stimuli is an essential cognitive process that allows us to interpret the meaning of incoming stimuli in our environment and plan appropriate responses—abilities that are disrupted or impaired by a number of brain diseases and conditions including Alzheimer’s disease, autism, schizophrenia, stroke, and attention deficit disorder. Here, we propose to study how neuronal dynamics across oculomotor brain areas are coordinated to achieve categorization and rapid decision making. We argue that developing a detailed understanding of the neuronal mechanisms underlying visual categorization and category-based decision making will enable a new generation of treatments for the cognitive and perceptual impairments that accompany such diseases and conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Principal Investigator: Wu, Xiaohua Investigating DNA double-strand break repair mechanisms in mammalian cells Project Narrative  Gross chromosomal rearrangement (GCR) is a hallmark of cancer cells, and DNA double- strand breaks (DSBs) are a major source of GCR. Given that microhomology sequences are often present at chromosomal rearrangement junctions in cancer, and repetitive sequences constitute about half of the human genome, it is important to understand the mechanisms underlying microhomology-mediated end joining and recombination at repetitive sequences. Our research in this proposal will create new knowledge and insight on DSB repair mechanisms in mammalian cells and shed light on how genome instability is induced upon DNA damage and during the oncogenic process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Successful completion of the proposed research will lead to a detailed understanding of how serine integrases carry out recombination between DNA attachment sites with high specificity and directionality. These enzymes have significant roles in human health through their effects on microbial communities and are used in a variety of genome engineering and synthetic biology applications, including targeted integration of transgenes into eukaryotic cells. This project will provide the groundwork necessary to engineer serine integrases for improved and perhaps novel functions in the biomedical research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Older adults represent a fast-growing segment of medical marijuana (MM) users in this country, with chronic pain as the most cited reason for use. There is a critical need to systematically examine MM’s short- and long- term effects on the core outcomes of chronic pain including pain intensity, physical, emotional, and cognitive functioning, and overall quality of life, and to track its side effects in older adults. This will be the first prospective cohort study that innovatively combines technology-based ecological momentary assessments (EMA) and in-person visits over 12 months to obtain both subjective and objective data on MM’s short- and long-term effects on older adult with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed research is to evaluate whether an admission electroencephalogram (EEG) is a diagnostic and prognostic biomarker for Malawian children with fever and coma. We will evaluate whether EEG can differentiate whether coma with fever is due to malaria or from another source. We will evaluate whether there are EEG factors that can be used to predict outcomes in children with coma and fever who do not have malaria parasites in their blood, just as we did in previous research studies of children with cerebral malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic care models (CCM) that deliver evidence-based practices (EBP) by multidisciplinary teams can improve children’s early behavioral health, but efforts to transport them to pediatric practice – such as our simplified cross-diagnosis CCM protocol for child behavior problems and ADHD (Doctor Office Collaborative Care; DOCC; MH064372) – often face scientific, technical, and practical challenges. Given promising findings by our team showing that such obstacles can be overcome to enhance EBP implementation by applying external and internal facilitation augmentation strategies applied to care teams (TEAM) and leaders (LEAD), respectively, we propose to conduct a hybrid Type 3 effectiveness-implementation trial to test the main and interactive effects of these TEAM and LEAD implementation conditions on provider uptake and clinical outcomes, and to test for their target engagement/mediation and moderation. By proposing one of the first large pragmatic pediatric trials of a CCM-based EBP to address these aims in response to RFA-MH-18-701 and the NIMH’s Strategic Plan (4.2), this research will advance the implementation science knowledge needed to optimize promising strategies for promoting the delivery and scale-up of DOCC in a pediatric medical home.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Gastric cancer is a major cause of cancer related death worldwide and screening practices are not routine in the US, leading to late diagnosis and poor outcomes. To improve accurate diagnoses and medical intervention, different types of metaplasia need to be molecularly defined and the inflammatory signals that trigger development of potentially high-risk metaplastic cells need to be established. The proposed research aims to define types of metaplasia that 1. Arise in models of Helicobacter pylori (Hp) infection compared to models of autoimmune gastritis (AIG), 2. Arise in human Hp compared to AIG patients, and 3. Are selectively induced/expanded by inflammatory cytokines, to ultimately improve methods in gastric cancer early detection and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because a biostable polymeric valved conduit that can be implanted surgically to reconstruct the right ventricular outflow tract in neonates and infants and then expanded by successive transcatheter procedures to reach the adult size, would revolutionize how we treat children with heart valve diseases. Such a new generation of valved conduit would decrease the number of open-heart surgeries and reoperations, decrease the mortality, complications and healthcare costs related to these procedures and increase the life expectancy and quality of life of these patients. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to fostering innovative research strategies as a basis for ultimately protecting health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Development of novel drugs can address antimicrobial resistance and emerging infectious diseases such as Ebola or COVID-19. Oxidative methods are central to the synthesis of novel scaffolds that will become the next- generation of drugs, therefore the development of enzymatic oxidation methods of small molecules will allow for sustainable and streamlined access to diverse building blocks necessary for the synthesis of pharmaceutical agents that can be used to treat diseases and improve human health. In addition, the proposed method will allow for oxidation of existing pharmaceutical agents making a greater number of molecules that could become effective drugs with changes in the solubility, polarity, duration of effect, oral availability, metabolic stability, and binding affinity in enzyme active sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We have discovered that the same principles that cause mixtures of oil and water to spontaneously separate into distinct liquid `droplets', known as phase separation, play a key role in how genomes are organized and regulated. Here we propose to advance our basic knowledge of how phase separation and other biophysical mechanisms and properties organize and regulate a mysterious part of our genomes, known as heterochromatin. Ultimately, we expect that the results of these and related studies will have enormous impact on our understanding of the causes of human diseases such as dementia and cancer, and could generate novel and effective approaches to their diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A healthy retina relies on the proper function of the blood-retina barrier, i.e., the interface between blood vessels and retina that mediates highly selective transport of nutrients, hormones, and metabolic waste. Multiple retinal diseases are associated with blood-retina barrier dysfunction. Here, we will use cell-based systems and mouse models to determine the mechanism of action and efficacy of a novel drug candidate that promotes blood-retina barrier function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current therapies for vascular malformations are not curative and patients often experience recurring disease and relapses. We can advance our knowledge of these difficult-to-treat diseases by studying vascular malformations with a known genetic mutation like Kaposiform Lymphangiomatosis (KLA) that affects children and young adults. The objective of this application is to perform studies that will give vital insights into the disease process so we can close the knowledge gap of how a recently identified genetic mutation drives the disease process in KLA patients and identify new drug targets.

PHR: Project Narrative Intraocular inflammation (uveitis) is poorly-understood, difficult-to-treat, and responsible for up to 25% of cases of legal blindness. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the tremendous therapeutic potential of mRNA lipid nanoparticle vaccines, their utility in geriatric treatments is limited because we currently lack robust age-related data to advance treatment methods. This proposal will determine the effect of age on the process of lipid nanoparticle-mediated mRNA delivery as it relates to changes in biological barriers. Results will decouple age-related reductions in mRNA delivery from impaired immune responses and enable nanoparticle formulation or dosing changes to maximize prophylactic outcomes in the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a global public health problem, with staggering rates of disease evidenced in the US and throughout both developed and developing nations. T2D disparately affects minority populations, with Hispanics being one of the highest at-risk populations. Evidence from both epidemiological and lipidomic studies have shown that specific lipids and their constituent components are important factors in the development of T2D. The human lipidome is made up of thousands of different lipid species, the simpler constituent components of classical lipid measures like HDL. By focusing on biologically simple lipid species, we hope to more rapidly identify genes influencing lipid variation and T2D. We will use whole genome sequencing to identify novel genes underlying the relationship between human lipid variation and T2D in extended pedigrees of Mexican American individuals, and functionally assess identified targets. This approach may lead us to the identification of potential drug targets relevant for lipid modifying therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Our perception of pitch is not only important for listening to and creating music, but also for communication and processing the complex sounds that surround us. However, our neurophysiological understanding of pitch processing and how it is degraded with hearing impairment is limited. The proposed study utilizes a cross-species approach to characterize deficits in pitch coding and perception that occur due to various forms of cochlear damage, which will advance our understanding of the physiological bases for individual differences in the perception of every-day sounds with sensorineural hearing impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) affects about 5% of adults [1] and children [2] in the United States, reducing their quality of life and imposing a substantial burden on the economy [3]. Better understanding of basic neuronal mechanisms related to attention and their interaction with sensory signals is needed for enhancing human performance and for guiding assessment, diagnosis and treatment of deficits of attention. The proposed research will investigate how attention affects visual processing in the nervous system, and in particular how distinct control signals related to attention are distributed to different regions of the visual system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Sensing microbe-associated molecular patterns and host endogenous immunomodulatory phytocytokines by cell surface-resident pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) constitutes a core process in launching an effective immune response against pathogen infections. This project will elucidate the mechanisms underlying PRR complex activation and attenuation by protein post-translational modifications, the elaborate and specific PRR signaling relay, and the feedback loops mediated by phytocytokines. Given the considerable similarities of innate immunity among multicellular eukaryotes, we anticipate that our research will have a broad impact on the study of innate immunity and signal transduction in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Host Factors in Response to Therapeutic Monoclonal Antibodies and Vaccination PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of effective clinical responses in many patients receiving ablative monoclonal antibody therapy challenges clinical and translational investigators to delineate the mechanistic basis for such differences. Genetic inquiry can identify the contributions that the recipient brings to these differences, especially in terms of variant structures of the antibody receptors mediating the responses. Delineation of these variants will inform advances in antibody engineering and will guide, in advance of antibody administration, individual therapeutic choices for effective implementation of precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During obesity, adipose tissue macrophages (ATMs) adopt a metabolically activated phenotype that contributes to low-grade chronic inflammation in adipose tissue and insulin resistance. Although studies in humans and experimental animal models support targeting the inflammatory phenotype of ATMs to improve insulin sensitivity, the molecular mechanisms underlying this inflammation are incompletely understood. We have identified a novel proinflammatory signaling pathway in macrophages triggered by metabolic stimuli and distinct from infectious stimuli – and, our overall goal is to delineate the contribution this pathway to obesity- associated insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This project addresses a novel mechanism of microglial activation and the associated brain pathology in Alzheimer's disease (AD) by aiming to determine the role of Stimulator of interferon genes (STING) activated via cytosolic mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) sensing by cGMP-AMP (cGAMP) synthase (cGAS) in shaping microglial phenotype in an AD animal model. Our studies will elucidate how STING activation contributes to the development of microglial activation and the associated brain pathology in AD as well as how mtDNA is released into the cytosol in AD-related conditions. The results will provide a novel strategy for the treatment of AD, and will impact our understanding of brain pathology in other neurodegenerative diseases such as Diffuse lewy body disease (DLBD) and the Down's syndrome that show hippocampal amyloidopathy.

PHR: Bacteria acquire immunity to their viruses by capturing viral DNA fragments, storing them in their own genomes, and then using these “memories” to recognize the invaders during subsequent infections and destroy them. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Muscularization of distal microvessels is a major pathological feature of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), but sources of smooth muscle cells (SMCs) found within lesions remain unclear. We show for the first time that lung pericytes act as progenitors for SMCs in both PAH and experimental chronic hypoxia. Through a combination of established cellular assays, novel transgenic mouse models and cutting edge CRISPR gene editing, we will demonstrate that activation of a novel HIF2a/SDF1 signaling pathway is essential for differentiation of pericytes into SMCs and that its manipulation has the potential to facilitate the discovery of novel therapeutic approaches capable of reversing muscularization and restoring pulmonary vascular homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Our preliminary published and unpublished studies support a role for the SET-domain containing protein, SETDB2, in glucocorticoid receptor (GR)-dependent gene expression essential to liver metabolism during metabolic stress. We hypothesize liver SETDB2 deficiency will be protective to the metabolic adverse effects of excess endogenous or exogenous glucocorticoids. Successful execution of this proposal will result in mechanistic insight into the genomic regulation behind glucocorticoid- induced diabetes through a potential unique SETDB2-GR regulatory node, which may open new therapeutic strategies for multiple glucocorticoid associated diseases in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Pathological evidence suggests a potential link between neurodegeneration and aberrant intracranial mechanical stress. The project proposed here will (1) identify the sources of such stress and quantify its magnitude in health and disease, (2) measure the effect of these stressors on neuron function, and (3) identify classes of molecules involved in sensing and transducing these stresses from the tissue to the cellular level. Achieving these aims will open new avenues of research for identifying therapeutic targets for neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The most common complaint with respect to sensory processing among the aged is the reduced ability to understand speech in noisy environments. We currently have only a limited understanding of how changes in the central nervous system reflect these perceptual deficits, which can be devastating as they can leave aged individuals socially isolated, depressed, suicidal and has been correlated with Alzheimer's Disease. The experiments of this proposal will investigate the central mechanisms of hearing complex auditory stimuli in young and aged individuals in order to provide insights into remediation of age-related hearing deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will quantify the effects of a new approach for treating patients with obstructive sleep apnea, a disease with substantial cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. It leverages a combination of proven analytical methods to evaluate the impact of ansa cervicalis neurostimulation, a highly novel treatment that has recently demonstrated promise for relieving pharyngeal obstruction in apneic patients by harnessing the substantive effects of caudal traction on the upper airway. Unlocking caudal pharyngeal traction as a therapeutic mechanism for the treatment of obstructive sleep apnea has the potential to generate new medical and surgical approaches for the management of this common disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This study aims to investigate the molecular and cellular bases of the heterogeneity of lens  epithelium that consists of distinct cell clusters with different functions. Moreover, we will explore novel regulatory mechanisms of distinct epithelial cell clusters in lens  growth control, lens homeostasis maintenance and various lens pathological outcomes. We will gain  insights into fundamental mechanisms about how distinct epithelial cell clusters selectively  response to various external stimuli to regulate the lens size and homeostasis over the course of  postnatal lens development and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Strabismus (misaligned eyes) can be both visually and socially debilitating. We recently identified three genetic duplications (areas with an extra copy of the DNA) that increase the risk of strabismus, and this project aims to understand the mechanism by which those duplications increase risk. In the long term, this work will provide fundamental knowledge about how and why strabismus develops and pave the way for the development of new treatments that address its underlying cause.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AML is a lethal blood cancer that needs to develop improved therapeutic approaches. Our proposed research focusing on abnormal vitamin B6 pathway will provide an innovative aspect to understand mechanisms essential to support AML cell proliferation. Functional characterization of abnormal vitamin B6 pathway in AML and detailed understanding of mechanisms underlying its selectivity and synergy will provide novel therapeutic targets and approaches to improve current therapeutic strategies for AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative We have recently found that spontaneous variations in the waking state account for a substantial fraction of the variations in responsiveness of cortical neurons to sensory stimuli. We also found that sorting the animal's cortical sensory responses and behavioral choices by arousal state (as measured by pupil diameter) revealed an inverted U, with optimal responses and performance occurring at intermediate levels of arousal. Here we will address the cellular, network, and neuromodulatory mechanisms underlying the determination of optimal state for neural and behavioral performance. We hypothesize that neuromodulatory transmitter systems are in constant flux and that these fluctuations in release cause ongoing and influential changes in the operating properties of the cerebral cortex. We will use a variety of state-of-the-art techniques, including whole cell recording, two-photon imaging, and optogenetics, to reveal the precise cellular, network, and neuromodulatory mechanisms underlying rapid state control in awake, behaving mice. Dyscontrol of neuromodulatory transmitter release may underlie several different disease disorders. Understanding their mechanisms of function is critical to understanding both the ordered and disordered brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: A Novel Waveguide to Enable MAS-DNP-NMR in Standard-bore High-field Magnets Narrative Thousands of researchers are regularly using Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) techniques, with a majority of the applications driven by the need for structure and function determination in biological macromolecules. The advances developed under this project, in combination with several other advances under separate pro-jects, will allow NMR laboratories to dramatically improve their sensitivity on solids, on a budget they will be able to afford, equipping biomedical researchers with superb new tools for structure-function studies of mem-brane proteins and cellular membrane systems. The components developed under this project will also have major applications in ultra-broadband 6G communications equipment and THz medical imaging methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative The fungus Candida albicans is responsible for significant morbidity and mortality in hospitalized patients, causing deep-seated invasive infections. Other manifestations of candidiasis include mucosal infections in the oral and vaginal cavities. C. albicans is nearly unique amongst fungi in its ability to thrive in and on human hosts; there are few other fungal species that can do so effectively. This ability must be rooted in specialized adaptations of C. albicans to the host environment but, to date, only a few of these are known. In this proposal a validated set of C. albicans genes will be assessed genetically, all of which are uncharacterized, yet upregulated in response to mammalian innate immune cells. We present compelling data that these genes are excellent candidates to mediate the unique commensal-pathogen life style of C. albicans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. health care system is poorly equipped to deal with the growing number of persons living with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (PLWD) and their complex medical and psychosocial needs, which may help explain the high rate of potentially inappropriate psychotropic and opioid polypharmacy these PLWD experience. We will use national Medicare data to characterize patient characteristics associated with such central nervous system-active polypharmacy, followed by a national survey of their treating clinicians to understand the clinical decision-making that underlies such potentially inappropriate prescribing. Finally, with input from a multidisciplinary Expert Panel, we will identify possible intervention targets and critical remaining knowledge gaps to reduce psychotropic and opioid polypharmacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Confluent vascular endothelial cells respond to fluid shear stress from blood flow by activating three distinct signaling pathways at cell-cell contacts, but our molecular understanding of these events is limited. This project will test the role of adhesion GPCRs of the latrophilin family in these events, and will use a new DNA origami nanodevice to visualize effects of mechanical tension on conformation of potential mechanosensing proteins. Together, this work will provide a molecular foundation for understanding at unprecedented depth the mechanotransduction processes that are critical in vascular physiology and disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Noncoding RNAs are major players in the programming of gene expression in development and disease. Our research program uncovers how this programming is initiated at the molecular level and develops fundamental models to study other similar mechanisms that are dysregulated in disease. We dissect key interactions in these pathways to determine how to correct aberrant gene programming.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance: RNA-guided nucleases that protect bacteria and archaea from infection by viruses are now being routinely repurposed for genome engineering in a wide variety of cell types and multicellular organisms. However, creative and safe application of these new tools requires a fundamental understanding of how these systems function. This proposal aims to elucidate the mechanisms of two nucleic acid guided defense systems in bacteria (Argonaute proteins and CRISPR-Cas systems), with an eye toward the development of new tools for molecular biology and medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The intestinal pathogen Clostridiodies difficile is most common hospital-acquired infection in the United States, and the inefficacy of current antibiotic treatment regimens highlight the need to develop alternative treatment strategies. Transplantation of fecal bacteria from a healthy donor into an infected patient’s intestinal tract has emerged as a remarkably effective and promising therapy, however, the mechanism through which beneficial bacteria act to clear C. difficile is not well understood. This proposal seeks to understand how the body’s own immune system works with the fecal transplant to support resolution of C. difficile infection. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative/public health relevance statement This project will examine the effects of the Skilled Nursing Facility Value-Based Purchasing program on outcomes for older adults leaving the hospital and entering skilled nursing facilities for post-acute care. This is important because one in five Medicare beneficiaries currently receives post-acute care in a skilled nursing facility, and this care is expensive and frequently associated with adverse outcomes. Understanding how this program achieves intended results, and what unintended consequences may come from the program particularly given the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, will help shape payment programs intended to improve outcomes in post-acute care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE A vaccine against group A Streptococcus (GAS) is a major global health priority, but this quest must provide efficacy while avoiding autoimmune sequelae linked to the pathogen. We recently made the critical discovery that choice of adjuvant is key for GAS vaccine efficacy. We will undertake head-to-head comparison of M protein and non-M protein GAS vaccines, adjuvanted with both alum and selected emulsion and liposome-based adjuvants, in humanized and outbred murine models and the non-human primate model of GAS pharyngitis. This work will serve as a valuable resource to the entire vaccine research field and facilitate progression of a GAS vaccine into commercial use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This application will investigate major regulatory signaling of APOE variants in peripheral immunity (neutrophils) and brain (microglia) as targets to treat Alzheimer’s disease (AD). We identified a critical role for APOE4 in the induction of inflammatory neutrophils and their recruitment to the diseased brain, which promotes a neurodegenerative phenotype in microglia associated with disease progression. We will implement our new tools to specifically modulate the crosstalk between APOE4-neutrophils and microglia to ameliorate disease progression using novel mouse models and human samples, including microglia and neutrophils from AD patients. These strategies and new tools will allow us to investigate the role of APOE variants in neutrophil- microglia interactions in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory diseases of the eye pose a serious threat of visual impairment or even blindness, especially if they affect the tissues comprising the visual axis. The eye has developed strategies to maintain essential immune competence, while limiting opportunities for inflammatory damage. Our proposed studies focus on important components of these strategies, particularly antigen presentation and the balance between effector T cells, regulatory T cells, and anergic T cells within the retina, and how local manipulations of these components can be used therapeutically to treat inflammatory eye disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Understanding HIV infection status is an important component of reducing spread of the disease and ensuring infected patients receive lasting and effective care. Unfortunately, current HIV self-tests do not detect the virus directly, and therefore aren’t useful at the earliest stages of infection or as a way to monitor if therapy is effective. We will address this gap by developing the first easy to use HIV self-test that directly detects the genetic material of the virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelodysplastic syndrome and myeloproliferative disorders currently affect over 400,000 individuals in the United States alone; they affect blood production and predispose to leukemia. Their onset is age-dependent but the genetic factors that determine their risk with aging is not understood. This proposal examines the role of acquired mutations in the blood with aging that promote and protect against the acquisition of these blood disorders with the goal of identifying new approaches to their early identification and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will provide important new information about the functioning of cones under daylight conditions. Preliminary studies suggest that the regeneration of cone pigments is driven by light through a novel biochemical mechanism in Müller cells. Given the importance of cones to human vision, the proposed research is highly relevant to the NEI mission. The gene for one of the proteins to be studied (RGR) is a susceptibility locus for retinitis pigmentosa, hence the project is also relevant to the broad NIH mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As some children who have obstructive sleep-disordered breathing (snoring or sleep apnea) benefit from tonsillectomy surgery and some do not, the decision for tonsillectomy relies on good communication so that treatment decisions align with the patient and family values. Black and Hispanic children have poorer sleep and surgery outcomes which may in part be attributed to negative clinician attitudes and deficient communication with families. We evaluate how patient race/ethnicity and surgeon bias influence communication and care outcomes, learn how parents and clinicians perceive communication during surgical visits, and ultimately direct interventions to promote respectful communication, reduce disparities, and improve outcomes for children with obstructive sleep-disordered breathing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY SCH OF MED
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies are designed to better understand how age-related hearing loss negatively impacts acoustic information processing in auditory brain centers. Brain substances/neurotransmitters involved in hearing and attention show age-related changes, but those specifically involved in attention seem resistant to aging. Neurotransmitter systems in the older brain may provide unique receptor targets for the development of drugs designed to ameliorate certain aspects of age-related loss of speech understanding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoietic stem cell genome editing has the potential to cure hematologic disorders including hemoglobinopathies. Two major limitations to these advancements are the ability to consistently reach persisting therapeutic threshold of editing post-transplantation and the use of toxic, high-intensity conditioning that poses considerable risks to the treated patients. In this application, we propose a novel in vivo selection strategy for edited HSCs using base editors that will provide the foundation for safer and more effective HSC gene therapy protocols for hemoglobinopathies and other genetic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: African Caribbeans have a high burden of diabetes, muscle fat infiltration and muscle weakness, which may lead to higher levels of age-related physical limitations and disability; however, there is currently no comprehensive information from individuals in this geographic region on muscle and physical performance. Therefore, this study seeks to directly measure skeletal muscle mass, and comprehensively phenotype physical performance in a large, established cohort of African Caribbean men and women living on the island of Tobago. This information can be used in future efforts to better prevent age-related declines in muscle and physical performance – an enormous public health issue – which will greatly enhance the quality of life of older adults in this region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drusen are the hallmark feature of early age-related macular degeneration (AMD), but their pathogenesis remains elusive due to the lack of good animal models. Nonhuman primates (NHP) are the only mammals to possess a true macula similar to humans and spontaneously develop soft drusen with lipid accumulation resembling human AMD. This study will establish an NHP model of soft drusen with detailed ophthalmic, metabolic, and genetic characterization, determine the impact of high-fat/sugar (HFS) diet and atorvastatin on drusen progression, and explore the gene expression of macular retinal pigment epithelial cells in eyes with and without drusen, HFS diet, and statins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gut dysbiosis and dysregulated immune responses have been implicated in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. Metabolites produced by gut microbiota are critical for shaping the host innate immune functions required for controlling intestinal inflammation. These studies seek to uncover the molecular mode of action that governs the innate immune sensing of gut microbial metabolites and promotes intestinal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The Inflammatory Bowel Diseases (IBD), which includes ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease (CD), are diseases of the gastrointestinal tract that result from abnormal immune response to luminal antigens in genetically-susceptible individuals. IBD represents a disease of major interest, with nearly 3 million American afflicted with this chronic inflammatory disorder. The proposed studies are designed to identify and harness information from novel, inflammation-related metabolic pathways that promote tissue healing. Such studies should provide new avenues into our understanding of why inflammatory diseases develop, and in particular, how innate immune responses contribute to inflammatory resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will study unique CD8 T cells that have the potential to confer cross-protection against different virus variants and immunity against persistent immune evasive viral infection. Understanding the requirements for the generation of these CD8 T cells, characterizing their phenotype and function, and creating new tools to track them during an immune response to infection is important to expand our immune armament against viruses. Our studies will inform the design of much needed universal vaccines against existing and emerging viruses, and guide new therapies for chronic viral infections.
