IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to challenge prevailing views on how electrical excitation drives the heartbeat and how the heart responds to ischemic injury. By shifting the paradigm in these two important areas of cardiology, we will provide a better understanding of the basis of cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death, generate novel anti- arrhythmic drugs, and provide a new therapeutic approach to preserve heart muscle lost during the acute phase of a heart attack.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure (HF) is a leading cause of death, but the prevention and treatment remain challenging. Since Rho kinase (ROCK1 and ROCK2) has recently emerged as a potential therapeutic target, the proposed research focus on the pathologic roles of ROCK1 and ROCK2 in HF by deleting both ROCKs in cardiomyocytes and/or fibroblasts. The information obtained from this study can establish the potential therapeutic effects by targeting Rho kinase activity to mitigate heart failure progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE With no unequivocally effective preventative strategies available, preeclampsia is a leading cause of maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality in the US, and African American women are disproportionately affected with higher prevalence, severity and mortality than white Americans. Our limited understanding of causal relationships between risk factors for preeclampsia, its long-term consequences on cardiovascular and metabolic health and limited availability of candidates for pharmaceutical prevention hinders our ability to reduce public health burden associated with this condition. With the goal of informing effective preventative strategies for preeclampsia, our study proposes to understand causal and mechanistic [genetic, clinical and social] relationships involved in preeclampsia and to identify gene targets to accelerate the pipeline for drug discovery and repurposing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Telomere shortening impedes uncontrolled cell division either by triggering replicative senescence or apoptosis or by running transformed cells into telomere crisis, in which rampant end-to-end telomere fusions and chromosome rupture restrict cell viability. This project aims to identify the molecular mechanism and physiologic repressors of telomerase-mediated DNA double-strand break repair, which may enable transformed cells to escape telomere crisis and emerge as clinical tumors. My anticipated findings will illuminate another facet of genomic instability in early tumorigenesis and may lead to novel strategies for cancer diagnosis and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Projective Narrative The interaction between human and its associated bacteria plays a crucial role in determining human’s heath and disease. Our research is focused on studying how human epithelial cells-produced small RNAs can be transported to oral bacteria and affect their behavior. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is one of the most common autoimmune diseases, which is characterized by chronic synovitis of peripheral joints, bone and cartilage degradation, which leads to joint disability, and there is a compelling need to explore novel therapeutic targets to develop safer and more effective therapies for RA. The proposed study will provide important insights into the negative regulation of the cells of the immune system to target inflammation and bone destruction in RA by elucidating the underlying mechanism of Gα13 signaling. Knowledge gained from this study may generate potential therapeutic means for treating RA and other inflammatory bone diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis is a prevalent oral inflammatory disease that is independently associated with systemic disorders (comorbidities). This project investigates the hypothesis that inflammatory memory in bone marrow progenitor cells, which give rise to innate white blood cells, underlies the comorbid connection between periodontitis and systemic inflammatory diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis. If confirmed, this knowledge will provide a platform for novel therapeutic interventions targeting inflammatory comorbidities through a holistic approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative  Tonsillectomy, with or without adenoidectomy, is a very common pediatric surgical procedure and an effective treatment for both obstructive sleep disordered breathing and severe recurrent tonsillitis. There is significant unwarranted variation in tonsillectomy use across racial/ethnic groups and geographic regions in the United States. This project will identify and quantify the impacts of factors acting across multiple levels and domains on racial/ethnic and geographic differences in pediatric tonsillectomy use and will thereby inform the development and targeting of interventions to improve the appropriateness of care of children with obstructive sleep disordered breathing or recurrent tonsillitis.

PHR: Project Narrative  Otitis media (OM) remains the primary infectious bacterial disease in childhood despite the widespread use of pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCVs). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We are proposing to develop a novel ensemble model framework to integrate information across multiple existing air pollution prediction models across the United States and, for the first time, to comprehensively quantify the uncertainty associated with air pollution exposure assessment, in single- and multi-pollutant settings. Subsequently, we propose to propagate the estimated uncertainty in the health effects estimation, to fully characterize the impact of air pollution on adverse health and the shape of the exposure-response curves. The proposed novel paradigm greatly improves communication of exposure uncertainty in the health effect estimates both to policy makers and the public and can easily be extended for use at different locations and at a global scale, as well as for other environmental exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This study examines; 1) coronary artery and heart valve calcification in individuals resilient to pathologic aging, 2) determines if these individuals have an improved ability to remove cholesterol from heart tissues as a potential protective mechanism against cardiac calcification, and 3) explores candidate protective genes against cardiac calcification for the overall aim of identifying new pathways which could be targeted for the prevention or treatment of coronary artery and heart valve disease. The research addresses the National Heart Lung and Blood Institute’s strategic research priorities on the pathobiology of calcification of coronary arteries and heart valves, and resiliency to disease. This research also addresses the broader NHLBI mission to prevent heart disease in older adults, so that Americans not only achieve longevity, but extended healthspan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Animal-coloning bacteria transition from an environmental lifestyle to the host-associated state, in which individual bacterial cells coordinate functions to act as a group. Using a model system that allows for interrogation of bacteria within the animal host, this project addresses how the host and microbes exchange and interpret molecular signals, leading to group versus solitary behaviors of the colonizing microbes. This project has ramifications for therapeutic interventions to establish beneficial microbes (e.g. probiotics) and to understand and interfere with colonization by pathogenic microbes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The work proposed here, a multidisciplinary effort encompassing organic synthesis, oligonucleotide delivery, RNA targeted screening and antibacterial studies, describes the development of sequence-specific cell permeable binders of rRNA as antibacterial therapeutics. The success of the proposed work would be a significant addition to currently available ribosome-specific approaches in broad spectrum antibacterial antibiotic development, in particular for targeting gram negative pathogens such as carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE). We propose using a small rRNA target sequences to design conjugates that can be employed to inhibit bacterial growth, opening possibilities for developing sequence-specific RNA targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) is a fibrotic complication that causes retinal folds and/or traction retinal detachment resulting in loss of visual acuity, and in severe cases, blindness. We propose to study signaling mechanisms involving both cells and the fibrotic extracellular matrix that creates a positive feedback loop that results in PVR. The ultimate aim is to identify key molecules that can become therapeutic targets for the prevention of PVR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The rat has been a primary animal model used to study complex human biology, disease, and biological processes because of the wealth of available biological information, genetic, genomic, and additional molecular systems data. Integrating these datasets with those for human and other mammalian models of human disease, are critical to advancing our knowledge of human health and disease. The primary mission of RGD is to provide novel ways to integrate the vast amount of genomic and biological data for the rat, with similar data in human and other mammalian disease models, to provide a unique comparative discovery platform for researchers to identify and evaluate precision rat models, test novel hypotheses, and make vital discoveries related to human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Altered cell-surface carbohydrates (glycans) play an important role in different infectious and inflammatory diseases of the gut, which is also a key site of HIV pathogenesis and persistence. This study will investigate the role of altered gut carbohydrates in modulating the gut microbiome and mediating HIV-associated gut inflammation. The idea is that, if these glycan structures are altered, then by understanding exactly how they are altered, we will lay the groundwork for developing novel therapeutic strategies to reduce HIV-associated chronic inflammation, and lifelong co-morbidities.

PHR: NARRATIVE Here we propose an improved influenza vaccine that can act more broadly to prevent infection from viruses that have undergone natural genetic changes that prevent current flu vaccines from being efficacious. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative IBD, food allergies and Celiac disease are caused by dysregulated mucosal immune responses to microbial or dietary antigens. The studies proposed here utilize single-cell and in vivo murine, dietary, bacterial and viral approaches to define immune regulatory and inflammatory T cells in specific niches of the intestine, providing a new perspective for the understanding of intestinal health and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In older adults, the complex task of walking is controlled in large part by multiple brain networks that enable one to pay attention to their surroundings, process sensory information, and produce appropriate movements of the body. This career development proposal aims to determine whether a form of non-invasive brain stimulation called transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) can change brain network function and thus improve walking in older adults with unsteady gait. This project is expected to increase our understanding of the brain-level control of walking in older adults, and produce critical information needed to design a larger clinical trial of tDCS to enhance gait and mobility in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed investigations address fundamental aspects of the chemistry of copper and heme-copper coordination complexes with molecular oxygen and nitrogen oxides such as nitric oxide. The interactions of these biologically important gaseous small molecules, especially at metalloenzyme active-sites, are critical in normal functioning and health. Potential long-term applications of this basic research include development of enzyme inhibitors as drugs and relevant disease therapeutic strategies.

PHR: Project Narrative Many human diseases including cancer, diabetes, and inflammatory disorders are causally associated with abnormal protein kinase and glycosyltransferase functions. By characterizing the regulatory functions of these proteins in disease and normal states and by developing new tools to predict disease phenotypes from genotypes, the proposed studies will accelerate the targeting of these proteins for drug discovery and personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Metabolic and bariatric surgery provides a unique opportunity to study the role of gut microbiota in human cardiometabolic health. Very few longitudinal studies among metabolic and bariatric surgery patients, however, have examined pre- to post-surgery changes in gut microbiome and microbial metabolites and the associations of microbiome and metabolites with cardiometabolic improvements after surgery. The proposed study seeks to bridge this research gap by identifying novel microbial features that may improve metabolic surgery outcome prediction (eg; the estimated 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease) and may guide potential future microbiota-targeted interventions to help patients achieve better cardiometabolic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The vascular and neural networks of the kidney help maintain physiological homeostasis. Engineering new organs and regenerative therapies to treat disease will require the proper establishment of these networks, however, little to nothing is known about how neurovascular networks are formed in the kidney. Our proposed research will provide critical insights into how these networks are established, their influence on kidney development, and the implications of proper neurovascular development for physiological function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pathogens from Enterobacteriaceae are responsible for high rates of diarrheal disease, kidney illness, meningitis, urinary tract infections and bowel inflammation worldwide, and a major cause of childhood mortality in developing countries. This proposal aims to characterize a novel class of highly conserved family of small regulatory proteins (termed ANR), associated with the modulation of virulence of epidemiologically relevant pathogens. The findings will greatly advance our understanding on bacterial pathogenesis and will have significant implications in treatment and prevention of infections in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Defects in homeostatic signaling at synapses are associated with a variety of neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases including epilepsy, autism, schizophrenia, Fragile X Syndrome, ALS, and Alzheimer's Disease. However, the mechanisms that ensure stable synaptic strength remain poorly understood. This proposal seeks to reveal fundamental mechanisms that initiate and maintain homeostatic signaling at synapses, insights that are necessary for understanding disease etiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Protein-nucleic acid complexes work in living cells to faithfully replicate (copy) the DNA genome to form the genetic material of the daughter cells, to transcribe and process specific messenger RNA sequences to permit `expression' of the defined genes, and to direct the synthesis of specific required proteins at various stages of development. These molecular complexes, which drive and direct these central processes of cellular function, largely self-assemble from individual protein and nucleic acid components to form the so-called `macromolecular machines of gene expression'. We are continuing a program of research that uses the methods of physics and chemistry to understand the specific molecular processes that are involved in the function and regulation of these machines, in part because understanding these central processes in molecular detail will help in the development of specific tools to control diseases of anomalous gene expression and development, including various forms of cancer and related genetic diseases.
PI_NAMEs: MARCUS, ANDREW HADLEY (contact);VON HIPPEL, PETER H

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a terrible disease that affects approximately 7% of premature children and is lethal in 25-30% of cases. Maternal milk has been shown to reduce the incidence of NEC and this study proposes to investigate the role of maternal antibodies secreted into the milk in preventing bacterial invasion of the intestine and disease. Our proposal aims to describe the mechanism via which maternal milk protects the intestine via shaping the neonatal bacterial flora via specific binding to individual bacterial strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Cirrhosis affects 1.5-9.4 million adult Americans and is associated with high morbidity, hospitalization rates, and mortality with mean life expectancy being 12 years for compensated and 1.8 years for decompensated cirrhosis. Costs are high for patients with cirrhosis, exceeding $16.3 billion in 2015 for hospitalizations alone, but little detailed knowledge about cost and cost-effectiveness related to cirrhosis exists. We will use administrative health payer data with detailed information on diagnoses, procedures, laboratory tests, medications, in- and outpatient care, as well as standardized costs in 396,727 persons diagnosed with cirrhosis between 2011 and 2018 to study the natural history of liver cirrhosis and to develop highly accurate models to predict decompensation of cirrhosis, hospitalization and death in patients with cirrhosis as well as cost analyses, thus identifying opportunities to improve care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Polycystic kidney diseases (PKD) are a complex group of disorders that cause kidney failure and abnormalities in many other organs due to defects of primary cilia. Here we seek to determine the genetic causes of these diseases, correlate the particular genes and alleles involved with the disease presentation and progression, and develop cellular and whole animal models to fully characterize the diseases. Successful execution will mean a better understanding of the origins of these disease, to more precisely predict the disease courses, determine why the diseases occur, and provide clues for novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Information in the nervous system is transmitted between nerve cells at the synapse, where an electrical impulse in the “presynaptic” nerve cell causes the release of neurotransmitter from small membrane bound structures, known as synaptic vesicles. In sensory cell of the eye and inner ear the neurotransmitter, glutamate, is released from synaptic vesicles in a graded and continuous manner and deficiencies in this process may underlie hereditary forms of blindness and deafness. To aid in this process, these cells have evolved a specialized structure called a synaptic ribbon and this proposal studies the function of the structures in this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Robust immune responses must be delicately balanced to ensure pathogen clearance while avoiding damage to the host, as over-exuberant cytokine activity can lead to fatal diseases such as sepsis. Autophagy is a highly evolutionarily conserved cytosol-to-lysosome degradative pathway that plays diverse roles in immunity, and in preliminary studies described in this proposal was found to protect myeloid cells against cytokine-induced cell death and mice from fatal TNF-induced shock. The goal of this K08 proposal is to provide a 5-year training plan for the PI, Dr. Anthony Orvedahl, to develop the skills and resources necessary to establish a robust independent research program aimed at deciphering the mechanisms of pro-survival autophagy and the role of a novel candidate mediator of cytokine-induced death, IRG1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Nearly a quarter of all Americans age 65+ report serious mobility problems, and mobility problems predict greater risk of dementia; thus, preserving mobility in older age is an NIA priority. Our past work suggests that the cortical inhibitory system contributes to motor declines with aging. This proposal will test if cortical inhibition relates to individual differences in walking and balance in older age (F99) and mild cognitive impairment (K00), and whether aerobic exercise affects cortical inhibition (K00). The findings from this work could lead to the development of novel interventions to preserve mobility and prevent disability in aging and mild cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Outcomes following hematopoietic stem cell transplantation for treatment of blood disorders and hematologic malignancies are limited by the availability and quality of donor-matched sources of bone marrow, mobilized peripheral blood, and cord blood. To date, efforts to expand hematopoietic stem cells in culture and develop alternative sources of stem cells have resulted in relatively poor self-renewal, skewed lineage potential, or low engraftment efficiencies. The goal of the current research is to leverage new knowledge supporting an executive role for mitochondrial remodeling in acquisition of hematopoietic fate in the embryo to establish new methods for engineering scalable sources of hematopoietic stem cells that possess long-term, multi-lineage engraftment potential.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The United States performs more robotic surgery than all other countries combined. However, it’s adoption across an increasingly broad range of procedures may be problematic for patients caught between enthusiasm for new technology and a lack of rigorous evidence to support these changes in practice. This proposal will provide patients, providers, and policymakers with real-world estimates on the adoption of robotic surgery, in addition to its short- and long-term outcomes compared to more established approaches (e.g. laparoscopic surgery) for the most common general surgery procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is expected to explain the biophysical principles by which Helicobacter pylori, which cause gastric cancers and peptic ulcers, migrate towards favorable chemical habitats to establish colonies. In the proposed work, we will pioneer the use of novel biophysical methods to determine the molecular mechanisms of bacterial migration. Fundamental insights from our work will likely help develop novel strategies to prevent H. pylori infections of the stomach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative African Americans have 6-fold higher prevalence for carrying an H. pylori Infection. We discovered that an African-centric S47 variant of the cancer suppressor gene - TP53 causes macrophages to engage an anti- inflammatory response to bacterial infections. In this proposal, we will describe the mechanism by which the S47 SNP causes disparities in H. pylori infection, test therapeutic avenues with focus on LXR agonists to reverse the macrophage anti-inflammatory phenotype and reduce the disparity in H. pylori infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Botanical dietary supplements are consumed more by cancer patients than otherwise healthier patients without cancer. However, using botanical dietary supplements in combination with anticancer drugs can lead to life- threatening drug interactions. Our group has reason to believe that botanical dietary supplements containing açaí can cause these adverse events when taken with anticancer drugs that are metabolized by a certain liver enzyme.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatic glycogen accumulation associated with elevated serum levels of liver enzymes, liver fibrosis and cirrhosis is one complication of urea cycle disorders. We will investigate the biochemical basis of hepatic glycogen deposition in urea cycle disorders and test whether a reduction of hepatic glycogen levels leads to improvement in liver disease in urea cycle disorders. The insights from this work have the potential to impact the care of patients with urea cycle disorders and may also elucidate a broader mechanism that contributes to hepatic glucose output and glycogen storage in more common diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative C. difficile is a CDC “Urgent Antibiotic Resistance Threat” as the number one hospital-acquired infection in North America. Current therapy with antibiotics is inadequate, as relapse occurs in up to 20% and death in 6%. The proposed studies, by identifying how innate immunity protects, offer the promise of immunotherapy as an addition to current approaches to treatment and as a replacement for fecal transplant to prevent relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Dermatology has experienced the emergence of targeted immuno-modulating drugs that have unprecedented efficacy in treating recalcitrant atopic dermatitis. We will generate directly applicable clinical insights on the safe and targeted use of new immuno-modulating drugs to treat AD by leveraging existing claims data sources with added EHR data and using novel methods for causal inference. The expedited evidence generation via the proposed prospective monitoring system will efficiently close knowledge gaps for optimal IMD use in patients with AD, including underrepresented and high-risk patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Visual crowding, the inability to identify stimuli amidst clutter, impairs object recognition performance in peripheral vision. Crowding is particularly detrimental in patients with central vision loss such as Macular Degeneration, since these individuals rely exclusively on their peripheral vision for object recognition tasks. In this proposal we will investigate the neural bases of crowding in the visual system of the non-human primate, to inform possible future intervention studies in central vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many cardiorespiratory diseases manifest as unstable breathing and episodic periods of hypoxia resulting in sympathetic-mediated hypertension; an exaggerated chemoreflex and its brain interaction are implicated in these responses. Our studies will determine the importance of altered GABA-mediated inhibition in sensory and brainstem reflex neurons in an episodic hypoxia rat model. We expect to define how targeting these brain mechanisms can be used to design rational and novel therapeutic approaches to the consequences of hypoxia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Health Relevance  Invasive fungal infections in immune compromised patients cause millions of deaths each year and are refractory to antifungal drug treatment with exceedingly high mortality rates. We developed paradigm-changing antifungal delivery system in which drug-loaded liposomes are targeted to specifically to fungal cells and their exopolysaccharide matrices. Targeted liposomes have order of magnitude enhanced antifungal activity toward Candida albicans, Aspergillus fumigatus and Cryptococcus neoformans. We plan to show increased therapeutic efficiency toward candidiasis, aspergillosis, cryptococcosis and mucormycosis in mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because the newly gained knowledge of sex- specific OA progression may lead to development of so-called “senostatic” drugs as a novel approach to targeting patients for precision medical treatment. The re-purpose of the NRTIs for OA treatment is highly attractive because it will greatly shorten the length and expense of OA drug development. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that translating scientific discovery into health that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain organoids are emerging as powerful tools for studying the mechanisms behind human brain development and disease. In our recent studies, we developed a platform for assembling functional neural circuits that exhibit surprisingly complex neural network activities such as oscillatory rhythms. In the proposed studies, we will explore how brain organoids can be best utilized to discover the mechanisms behind a range of neurological disorders and develop strategies for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Without a substantial increase the pool of early stage physicians interested in embarking on a research career, the shortfall of successful physician scientists will continue to worsen. We propose to address this challenge by instituting a program, University of Cincinnati-StARR, that provides internal medicine residents interested in a research career with the research tools available at UC as well as Cincinnati Children’s (CCHMC) to then transition to academic fellowships and a successful physician scientist career. This will complement an infrastructure that is already in place at that has focused more on enhancing academic fellowship training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: After a heart attack, there is a localized site of severe cardiac injury where the tissue experiences poor blood perfusion, low oxygen levels, and death of the beating cells of the heart. Restoration of blood flow is necessary but causes further damage to the heart, known as ischemia-reperfusion injury. By engineering organ-on-a-chip microdevices to model these cardiac injuries, better therapeutic strategies can be developed to minimize damage and promote repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative We propose highly integrated and multidisciplinary mechanistic studies to investigate how activating mutations and post translational modifications in RAS and heterotrimeric guanine nucleotide binding proteins, regulate cell signaling and tumorigenesis. Results from these analyses will inform precision medicine approaches to antagonize deregulated G-protein signaling in cancer. We will also investigate how vinculin and metavinculin proteins individually and coordinately mediate actin cytoskeletal rearrangements and associate with the membrane, to elucidate how they regulate cell morphology, force transmission and cell motility. In addition, we will examine how deregulation of these cell adhesion proteins alters force transmission within the heart leading to cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Escherichia coli) are responsible for a number of human infectious diseases. Much like armor, these bacteria have a unique outer surface that prevents the use of a number of antibiotics. This proposal will help determine the molecular machinery used by the Gram-negative bacterium Acinetobacter baumannii, an extensively drug-resistant bacterium causing devastating disease, to assemble its outer surface. Understanding how bacteria assemble their outer armor will allow for the development of novel therapies to fight multi-drug resistant infections.

PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses the relationship between immune checkpoint inhibitors, a type of cancer therapy, and osteoarthritis. The proposal will determine if osteoarthritis is a risk factor for immune checkpoint inhibitor- induced inflammatory arthritis. The proposal will also evaluate whether there is increased progression of osteoarthritis on imaging in patients treated with immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac arrest is the leading cause of death in the United States and other developed countries. In public discussions, these deaths are often called “heart attacks,” but in reality, they most often occur as a result of lethal ventricular arrhythmias. We previously identified unique elements of the electrical circuits that cause these ventricular arrhythmias. This proposal focuses on developing gene therapies to prevent these unique elements from supporting ventricular tachycardia, thereby eliminating these arrhythmias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Influenza and pneumococcal infections occurring in individuals with glomerular disease are preventable contributors to excess healthcare utilization, morbidity, and mortality. Vaccination is a powerful and cost- effective method to attenuate infectious burden, however, vaccine immunogenicity and effectiveness have been under-studied in this high-risk population. The objective of this proposal is to describe influenza and pneumococcal vaccine effectiveness and immunogenicity in patients with glomerular disease.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The coronavirus disease pandemic has led to rapid expansion of telemedicine services. Our study is focused on evaluating the impact of telemedicine adoption on ambulatory care for Medicare beneficiaries with three specific aims: (1) to identify provider- and market-level determinants of telemedicine use in the Medicare population, (2) to evaluate the association between practice-level telemedicine use and the rate of hospital admissions for ambulatory care sensitive conditions and (3) to evaluate the impact of clinician-level telemedicine use on Medicare spending and utilization. The proposed research will identify policy targets that can be used by policymakers and healthcare organizations to ensure the equitable, efficient, and effective expansion of telemedicine services.

PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluating the Impact of Telemedicine on Ambulatory Care

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular diseases are the leading causes of mortality and morbidity in the United States and worldwide. Current therapies for heart failure after myocardial infarction offer only limited benefit and new, more effective treatments that can slow/halt disease progression and improve heart function are desperately needed. The primary focus of this proposal is to test a novel therapeutic approach for preventing progression of heart failure after myocardial infarction by activating brain melanocortin 4 receptors and to unravel the molecular/cellular mechanisms involved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cryptococcal meningoencephalitis poses a serious threat to public health, causing more than 180,000 deaths from about 225,000 infections each year. Given the poor outcome of the current antifungal therapies to treat cryptococcosis and the lack of vaccines to prevent this deadly disease, it is urgent and critical to develop effective vaccines for high risk patients. Findings from the proposed research will likely provide a successful platform for mRNA vaccine development against cryptococcosis and other deadly fungal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental exposures are related to risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. To achieve unparalleled understanding of brain composition, biology, and response to early life exposure to lead (Pb), the goal of this study is to identify sex-specific consequences of perinatal lead exposure in the mouse brain by pathology, DNA methylation, hydroxymethylation, and RNA expression, including measures at the single cell level. Results from these experiments will advance our understanding of how early life lead exposures affect the later life brain, with potential lifelong impacts on Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Humans express 10 different TMEM16 family members that are expressed in a tissue specific manner, and through their action as ion channels and/or lipid scramblases, they have been implicated in normal physiology such as blood coagulation, nociception, and protection from inflammatory arthritis as well as diseases such as cancer. Unfortunately, it remains unclear how these proteins flip lipids, select one ion over another, and whether all members accomplish these tasks in the same manner. The mechanistic studies outlined here will attempt to answer these questions at the atomic level potentially revealing new therapeutic avenues to treat diseases ranging from stroke to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Subjective cognitive symptoms are common in older adults, but increasing evidence suggests that for a subset of individuals, noticing a change in memory may be an early sign of underlying Alzheimer's disease (AD). The goal of the proposed study is to track subjective cognitive symptoms over time, including an electronic at-home assessment that can be completed on a more frequent basis than questionnaires given at the clinic. The pattern of subjective cognitive symptoms will be compared with in vivo markers of AD pathology; amyloid and tau, and decline in performance on standardized cognitive measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative In the autoimmune disorder called Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS), the presence of autoantibodies targeting the plasma glycoprotein beta-2 glycoprotein I (b2GPI) is associated with arterial and venous thrombosis as well as pregnancy complications. Understanding how b2GPI becomes immunogenic and how autoantibodies in complex with b2GPI cause the blood to clot remains a top priority in the field. By elucidating the structural architecture of b2GPI free and bound to physiological and pathological ligands, our studies have the potential to shed new light on the pathogenic mechanisms of APS and will enable the development of new diagnostics and therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Vaccine hesitancy and the emergence of new SARS-CoV-2 variants are major hurdles in the control of SARS- CoV-2 infection but is also impeded by the lack of specific vaccine guidelines for the inclusion of people with primary immunodeficiency disorders. Individuals with X-linked agammaglobulinemia lack B cells and antibodies, face recurrent infections, depend on lifelong gammaglobulin infusions, but maintain their ability to respond to most vaccines due to their intact T cell development. Therefore, we posit that XLA patients will benefit from mRNA SARS-CoV-2 vaccination through the induction of virus specific T cells that will prevent severe COVID- 19 outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The robust establishment of correct shape is essential for proper tissue function. Tissue shape change is a mechanical process that necessitates the coordinated force generation and motion of thousands of cells. Identifying how physically interacting cells mechanically respond to challenging conditions and modify their behavior to still sculpt the correct final shape will shed light onto many congenital disorders that result from morphogenetic dysregulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is a significant health problem in the United States with very poor survival and disproportionate burden across race/ethnicity. Our objective is to apply an integrative systems biology approach, incorporating epidemiologic, clinical, genetic and metabolomic data, to improve the prediction of pancreatic cancer risk in a racially heterogeneous population. By refining the identification of high-risk individuals, our study will help to establish new strategies for targeted prevention and early detection and reduce the overwhelming burden of this lethal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute and chronic antibody-mediated rejection remain among the leading causes of renal allograft loss. The proposed studies will investigate the mechanisms by which posttransplant inflammation initiates and amplifies the generation of pathogenic alloantibody. The results will fill several critical gaps in current knowledge of humoral alloimmune responses to vascularized organ transplants and identify potential targets of therapeutic intervention to inhibit antibody-mediated rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The work proposed here will yield molecular approaches and tools for manipulation of gene expression in the pathogenic free-living amoebae Naegleria fowleri. Approaches to be developed include those required for gene silencing, gene editing, and transgene expression. The work proposed will provide essential tools for resolving fundamental parasite pathobiology and will also be critical for drug discovery campaigns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accumulation of lipids in liver (NAFLD) is a widespread problem in the western world, and it can lead to chronic inflammation (NASH) and development of cirrhosis and liver cancer. There is no currently available single- agent pharmacologic treatment for NAFLD and its progress to NASH. We discovered that inhibition of EGFR completely prevents and reverses NAFLD, and we aim to apply these unexpected findings to provide mechanistic understandings and therapeutic alternatives that have direct bearing on NAFLD/NASH pharmacology applicable to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative. Integrin α5β1 is a cell surface protein that directs how cells interact with both other cells and molecules within the extracellular matrix. This grant will explore how different factors change the conformational shape of integrin α5β1, and how those changes in shape affect its ability to interact with an important protein binding partner called fibronectin in blood cells. Insights from this research will shed light on how integrin α5β1 and other related integrins function and will aid the development of drugs to treat diseases that are both dependent on, and exacerbated by integrin function including atherosclerosis, fibrosis, sickle cell disease, and cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The years from 2001 to 2014, when the United States was engaged in military operations following the September 11th, 2001 terrorist attacks, were momentous in many ways. For the VHA in particular, the post- 9/11 conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan produced a new generation of returning veterans with deeply complex and challenging mental and physical problems resulting from their combat experiences. Since its inception in 2009, TRACTS has collected a vast array of longitudinal data detailing the complexities of the mental, physical, and brain health of post-9/11 veterans. Our well characterized group of participants is projected to surpass 1000 individuals by 2024. This representative group has allowed us to study the intellectual, emotional, neural, and molecular correlates of brain injury and traumatic experiences, which will lead directly to improved treatment for post-9/11 veterans now and into the future as they age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Hydrogen sulfide is paradigmatic of the rich interplay between host and gut microbial metabolism that is influenced by diet, and in turn, influences whole-body sulfide homeostasis. Our laboratory has been at the forefront of deciphering how sulfide, by reversibly poisoning respiration, also remodels host redox and energy metabolism. In the next cycle, our studies will illuminate how host sulfide metabolism is regulated, and reveal the molecular underpinnings of its intersections with oxygen metabolism in the context of normal physiology and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance) The detailed understanding of the mechanisms by which enzymes maintain, repair and modify DNA is extremely important since errors in the genome can often be key for the development of a large number of diseases. This project focuses on the continued development of advanced QM/MM methods for the computational simulation of biological systems and the computational investigation of the structural, functional and dynamical factors of selected proteins of key families involved in DNA maintenance, repair and modification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The interwoven opioid and HIV epidemics have been linked to opioid exacerbation of inflammation and pathology within the central nervous system (CNS), an increased likelihood of opioid use disorder, and cognitive and behavioral deficits. µ-opioid receptors (MORs) are critical in opioid and neuroHIV co-exposure; but the convergence point of synergistic opioid and HIV neuroinflammation and pathology, and their effects in the particularly vulnerable striatum (critical for motivation and reward) are poorly understood. The goal of this study is to identify the role of CNS cell-specific MOR activation in mediating opioid and HIV-induced neuroinflammation and pathology, and whether targeting these mechanisms can rescue resultant neuronal damage and associated behavioral deficits.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: After a right brain stroke, >50% of veterans experience problems with dressing, eating, self-care or steering their wheelchairs because their ability to move, orient, and respond toward the left side is limited: spatial neglect. Spatial neglect prevents them from functioning independently, and their needs in the hospital and at home are greatly increased. An effective treatment for spatial neglect is 10 days of visuomotor training while wearing optical prisms (PAT), however many clinicians [fail to diagnose spatial neglect and use this approach. In this study, we will develop a brain scanning test that could objectively identify the veterans with spatial neglect after stroke who are the best candidates to receive PAT and recover their ability to function. When the research is complete, we expect that brain scans done in the hospital can guide the team to refer veterans to PAT rehabilitation: improving daily life function] and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The studies in this proposal will test a novel role of systemic upregulation of the signaling molecule, PTEN, by the pharmacological agent, 5-azacytindine, in suppressing vascular disease progression. Studies using cultured smooth muscle cells and macrophages will define the role of 5-azacytidine on PTEN expression and cell phenotypic changes, studies using mouse models of vascular disease and pharmacological approaches will establish the importance of PTEN upregulation on inhibition of vascular disease, and studies using normal and diseased human arteries will add translational significance. As SMC phenotype and recruitment of macrophages are critical to the progression of vascular diseases, our findings will be highly relevant with the potential to develop novel therapeutics aimed at preserving the mature SMC phenotype for purposes such as stabilization of atherosclerotic lesions and inhibition of in-stent restenosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Air pollution exposure early in life is linked to disorders like autism spectrum which show high co-morbidity with gastrointestinal issues. This project will characterize microbiome, gut, and behavioral changes in the offspring of pregnant mice exposed to air pollution. It will determine causality among the microbiome composition changes, gut permeability changes, and behavioral abnormalities and thereby enhance our understanding of this devastating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: During the course of the pandemic and over the last 35 years despite much effort we have only cured a single individual of human immunodeficiency virus or HIV. There is, however, a small group of individuals, termed elite controllers or ECs, who are able to control HIV all on their own, and during our prior studies of these people we have seen that they down-regulate a key human gene that the virus relies upon. This grant is focused on how, at a molecular level, these individuals are capable of doing so.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative: Aging, a strong risk factor for Alzheimer's disease, causes detrimental changes in the hippocampus, which is a key brain region responsible for learning and memory function. This proposal investigates how TIMP2, a protein revealed to be elevated in young blood, acts within the central nervous system to facilitate hippocampal synaptic function on a gene expression, cellular, and cognitive level in the context of Alzheimer's disease pathology. Creating insight into this mechanism will inform therapies targeting facets of Alzheimer's disease, while also providing insights into how other secreted proteins within the hippocampus influence cognitive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell division is a key process in biology; it is the process by which cells separate their genetic material (chromosomes) into two identical daughter cells and coordinated by a microtubule-based machinery called the mitotic spindle. Although spindles are essential to the life of a healthy cell, and spindle malfunction can result in cancers and other disease states, we still do not know how microtubules are made at the correct location and time to build the mitotic spindle. Our work seeks to uncover exactly how microtubules make mitotic spindles, which will help explain not only how a cell divides, but can help us understand the origins of diseases that begin in improper cell division and cell regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROBING ALLOSTERY IN METHYL-LYSINE READER DOMAINS Project Narrative: Chromatin is the complex of histone proteins, RNA, and DNA that dynamically packages the genome within each eukaryotic cell. Allosteric interactions in chromatin regulatory complexes are critically important phenomena that create unique opportunities for pharmacologic intervention. This research will aim to create high-quality allosteric chemical probes for methyl-lysine reader domains to explore chromatin biology and the therapeutic potential of allosterically modulating these domains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Anemia, defined as an insufficient number of red blood cells, affects roughly one third of the world’s population and can be caused by a variety of factors that impair red blood cell production. The process by which functional red blood cells are produced from committed progenitor cells is incompletely understood. The studies outlined in this proposal will significantly enhance our understanding of how essential steps in red blood cell production are coordinated, providing much needed insights into a process fundamental to human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonatal infections are a global health concern, but why neonates are highly susceptible to infections is not well understood. We have shown that neonatal mice have increased iron available for bacterial growth and that decreasing this iron improves neonatal survival during sepsis. The success of the studies outlined in this proposal may lead to the identification of therapeutic targets that can improve outcomes during neonatal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delayed diagnosis of fungal infections is a proven risk factor for increased morbidity and mortality. There currently is no FDA approved, benchtop, pan fungal diagnostic assay that is fast, has inexpensive equipment, can be used directly on pure cultures or clinical specimens, or on mixed cultures. This proposal will use a new, inexpensive sequencing technology called nanopore sequencing, and a little used region in the fungal ribosomal repeat called the intergenic space region to yield a rapid diagnostic assay using a single sequence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This multidisciplinary research will explore the interaction between solid surfaces and microorganisms to improve quantitative understanding of microbial dechlorination kinetics. The new knowledge will be used in mathematical models to optimize bioamendment materials to enhance bioremediation. Collaboration with environmental consulting professionals will integrate the novel technology through advanced site models for evaluation of effectiveness at Superfund sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposed research is related to public health because our study provides a novel therapeutic target for brain aneurysm disease, a condition that leads to a high rate of disability and death in stroke patients upon rupture. In particular, we propose that inhibiting the activity of a special compartment called “podosome” in the cells that locate at the innermost of the blood vessels has a beneficial effect on the formation and growth of brain aneurysms. Therefore, our work is related to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to reducing the burdens of illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Cerebral blood vessels are completely covered by astrocytic processes called endfeet. Recent research shows endfeet releasing vasoactive molecules that regulate blood flow and tropic molecules that induce and maintain the blood brain barrier. It is unknown whether these functions change with aging and may be worsened by the presence of amyloid in Alzheimer disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress in epithelial cells lining the distal lung airspaces (alveolar epithelial cells (AECs)) plays a key role in the development of an age-associated disease called idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). However, what causes ER stress during aging and how ER stress damages AEC is not clear. Here we propose to link chaperone protein GRP78 loss-induced ER stress to AEC dysfunction and IPF by studying how GRP78-loss promotes dysregulated mitochondrial function and metabolism via crosstalk between UPRER and mTOR signaling, leading to an aging phenotype in AECs and subsequent lung fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Appropriate feeding behaviors rely on accurate estimation of future energy balance, which in turn relies on gastrointestinal signals related to stomach stretch and nutrient content. How these visceral signals are integrated to assess internal state and guide feeding behaviors is poorly understood. This proposal will define how interoceptive signals from the gastrointestinal tract lead to satiety-related sensations, drive feeding termination, and ultimately regulate energy balance at the level of the lateral parabrachial nucleus, thereby identifying new therapeutic targets for metabolic diseases such as obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes distress is common affecting over one-third of people with type 2 diabetes, negatively impacting self- management and outcomes, and disproportionately affecting low-income individuals. The proposed project will pilot test a Mindfulness-Based Diabetes Education intervention, specifically adapted for adults with type 2 diabetes and elevated diabetes distress, to assess feasibility and acceptability. Utilizing mixed-methods, this study will also characterize key contextual factors that relevant to intervention delivery and implementation setting the stage for a future, larger study in safety-net healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advancements in antiretroviral therapy, cryptococcal meningitis continues to be the most common cause of meningitis in persons living with HIV and carries a high mortality rate in low-income countries. The proposed research focuses on quantifying human natural killer cell cytotoxicity against Cryptococcus neoformans and the identification of differentially expressed genes involved in exhaustion, cytokine production, and cytotoxicity. This research could lead to the identification of pathways that can be targeted by immunotherapies to enhance natural killer cell cytotoxicity with the overall goal to increase fungal clearance, reduce morbidity, and reduce mortality from cryptococcal meningitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The kidneys are frequent targets of both environmental contaminants and several classes of therapeutic agents that exhibit dose-limiting nephrotoxicity. We will use primary cultures of proximal tubular cells from fresh human kidneys in targeted studies to identify protein, lipid, and low-molecular- weight metabolite patterns that are associated with exposure to a diverse array of nephrotoxic chemicals. We anticipate validating biomarkers that are linked to chemical mechanism of action, are specific and highly sensitive, and correspond to exposure prior to or after onset of only minimal renal injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Importance to public health: The purpose of this project is to understand infection mechanisms of leukocytes with Ehrlichia chaffeensis, which causes an emerging infectious disease, human monocytic ehrlichiosis. Ultimately, our findings are expected to reveal novel molecules and signaling pathways that could serve as relevant targets for future therapeutic discovery; however, what is learned will contribute to a broader understanding of how cellular organelles and intracellular infection are regulated in human cells. Relevance to NIH’s mission: our work pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will reduce the burden of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression and anxiety are common mental health disorders in adolescents, but factors that contribute to these outcomes are poorly understood. We will study how air pollution, which can affect brain development and function, may contribute to these disorders in adolescence by changing the structure, organization, metabolism, or function of the brain. We will combine two existing study populations with repeated measures of air pollution exposure and mental health outcomes from birth through adolescence to provide important information to guide future public health interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Ubiquitin is a post-translational modification that regulates diverse cellular processes and its dysregulation is associated with many human diseases ranging from neurodegeneration to cancer. Here, we propose research directions that will result in a deeper understanding of how ubiquitin networks are regulated during conditions of stress to facilitate the cellular adaptive response. Dissecting these mechanisms will provide a platform for long-term exploration of ubiquitin networks as potential therapeutic targets in the treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Gastroparesis in patients with diabetes mellitus lacks curative therapy and represents a significant health care burden. Reduced expression of the enzyme producing the inhibitory neurotransmitter nitric oxide in gastric neurons is a pathogenetically significant alteration in gastroparesis, but pharmacological modulation of nitric oxide signaling has not been beneficial due to side effects. This project will determine how impaired mitochondrial metabolism in diabetes and consequent dysregulation of gene transcription can be reversed to restore nitric oxide-dependent gastric functions using drugs already approved for use in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our program has assembled outstanding multidisciplinary teams devoted to understanding the roles played by transition metals in catalytic transformations central to human health and disease. The approaches to these problems incorporate a suite of advanced paramagnetic resonance techniques, many of which we have developed, augmented by kinetic and photophysical measurements. The essential biological and biochemical challenges we address include: radical reactions catalyzed by `Radical-SAM' enzymes, the most widespread metalloenzyme superfamily; enzymatic formation of bio-available nitrogen, on which over half the world's population depends; the role of Mn2+ in radiation resistance, including the resistance of human tumors, in aging, and in oocyte fertilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE)  Obesity is an uncontrolled global epidemic. Maternal exposure to ambient fine particulate matter (PM2.5) correlates with offspring obesity. We and others have shown the adverse programming of offspring adiposity by maternal PM2.5 exposure, explaining this association. Using unique knockout and transgenic mouse models, this project will determine the unexplored maternal pathogenesis for this programming, aiming to develop effective intervention strategies that target the maternal pathogenesis and thus may benefit the health of both the mother and child.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Evaluation of fibrosis and tubular atrophy from chemically stained kidney biopsies are essential for diagnosis and disease-severity assessment, but current techniques are time-consuming, non-specific and contribute to interobserver variability and imprecision, affecting care. We propose to optimize and test a new kind of microscope (“DUET”) that can visualize fibrosis (scarring) and other tissue abnormalities directly from standard H&E slides to enable high-quality reproducible and accurate fibrosis scoring and evaluation. This multi-site project will also provide a unique opportunity to perform a retrospective study from hundreds of existing H&E slides with associated months to years of clinical follow-up data, and to create a method with demonstrated utility in more than one institution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The central nervous system comprises numerous neuronal subtypes that form specific connections, allowing for complex computations, such as the detection of various visual features by the retina. Using the retina as a model system, we intend to utilize innovative genetic techniques to investigate the role of the cadherin family of cell-recognition molecules in the process of retinal direction-selective circuit wiring. Our ultimate goal is to understand the principles underlying cadherin-mediated connectivity in the retina as a gateway to understand neuronal patterning in the central nervous system, and to offer new cures for various diseases in the eye and the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is a potent neurotransmitter that is strongly and selectively synthesized in neurons and pancreatic islet beta cells. Our long-term goal is to understand the role of GABA in human islet biology for healthy and disease states such as type 1 and type 2 diabetes. The objectives of this project are to characterize the mechanism of islet GABA release and to bring clarity to the regulatory role of GABA in islet function and blood glucose homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies are proposed to comprehensively assess thermal responses of Culex mosquitoes with and without West Nile virus infection and create more informed transmission models under variable temperatures. Given the strong effects of temperature on viral replication rates, the variability of vector species and population responses to temperature, and the documented role of interactions among viral genotype and environment in governing transmission, studies which aim to model temperature need to consider the evolution of dynamic vector-virus interactions. We will address this gap in infectious disease modeling by simulating evolution under higher temperatures in the lab and utilize these data to inform novel predictive transmission models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Narrative This project focuses on links between circulating glucose metabolism and age-related processes occurring in the cells in the brain that support the neurons. These studies will test the idea that these support cells lose some of their ability to move glucose from the circulation to the neurons, which contributes to the cognitive problems associated with aging and further exaggerated in Alzheimer’s disease. Ultimately, it is anticipated that this study will help us understand changes that occur during aging that make the elderly more vulnerable to disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease, and perhaps even the mental deterioration that sometimes occurs in diabetes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative: Dr Madabhushi's pioneering work on artificial intelligence (AI) has enabled the development of decision support tools to aid clinicians in treating patients suffering from a variety of cancers (breast, prostate, lung, head and neck), but also cardiovascular, kidney and eye disease. Most recently his group adapted AI and radiomics technologies developed for their VA merit project on lung cancer screening for Veterans to digitally analyze CT scans to identify the severity of COVID19 disease. His work has recently focused on the use of AI to help eliminate racial disparities in medicine by identifying disease patterns that might be specific to certain populations, in turn enabling development of population-specific personalized risk calculators. He is applying this AI approach to disease diagnosis, risk stratification, outcome and treatment response prediction in Veterans, where their unique exposure to wartime environments and particular lifestyle choices, engenders different disease phenotypes compared to the civilian population.

PHR: The  collective  burden  of  various  neurodegenerative  diseases  is  large,  yet  no  active  therapeutics  exist  to  effectively  slow  disease  onset  or  progression.  The  studies  proposed  in  this  application  will  allow  us  to  determine  the  molecular  and  cellular  mechanisms  through  which  ataxin- 1  regulates  oligodendroglial  differentiation  and  function,  and  will  elucidate  the  non- neuronal  contributions  to  neurodegenerative  diseases,  revealing  novel  potential  entry  points  for  therapeutic  intervention  in  disorders  associated  with  ataxin- 1  mutations  such  as  spinocerebellar  ataxia  type  1,  frontotemporal  dementia,  amyotrophic  lateral  sclerosis,  and  Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Life-threatening fungal infections occur to more than two million patients annually, with high mortality due to scarcity and limited efficacy of antifungal drugs. The design of novel drugs targeting cell wall biomolecules requires knowledge of their structures and nanoscale assemblies in the native cellular context. We will determine drug-induced structural remodeling of cell walls using living cells of Aspergillus fumigatus, Candida albicans, and Cryptococcus neoformans, the three most prevalent fungal pathogens, thus presenting a significant advance in medical mycology research that guides novel antifungal therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The future of child and adolescent development and behavioral medicine lies in enhancing the diversity and inclusiveness of the research and clinical workforce. The proposed St. Louis Summer Research Immersion Program in Pediatric Neuroscience (SSRIP) will provide a unique and innovative research training experience to high school students who might not otherwise have access to such opportunities. Thus, this proposed R25 program will `grow the pipeline' for early stage learners for research careers in Pediatric Neuroscience, which has been designated by the NIH/NINDS as a priority area for a diverse workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spontaneous preterm birth is a highly significant but understudied perinatal outcome that comprises the majority of premature births and has been linked to prenatal exposure to environmental chemicals, including phthalates. This study will investigate the mechanistic link between prenatal phthalate exposure, placental dysfunction, and spontaneous preterm birth using multi-omics data generated in the placenta. Findings from this study will inform chemical toxicological risk assessment and policy, as well as aid in the development of potential biomarkers of spontaneous preterm birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Latino adolescents consume and misuse alcohol earlier than their peers, placing them at greater risk for developing addiction, health, and mental health problems across their lifetime. The current project examines how several biological and environmental factors work together to increase the risk of alcohol use and misuse in Latino adolescents. Results from this project will allow for the identification of high-risk adolescents and provide broader targets for alcohol use disorder prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Finding the most effective therapies for cancer patients is critically dependent on having detailed genomic and molecular insights into the cancer, which currently is only possible by tissue biopsy. Using multiple myeloma as an example of an incurable cancer we are seeking to demonstrate that liquid biopsy of circulating cancer cells and cell-free DNA can replace tissue biopsy and additionally yields clinically actionable information to inform treatment decisions. In this project, we will employ innovative technologies with the goal to establish multimodal liquid biopsy as a comprehensive longitudinal biomarker and practice-changing standard that eliminates the need for tissue biopsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: We seek to identify novel connections between metabolism and DNA repair in human cancers. We have discovered that mutations in genes associated with metabolism that are either inherited or occur in cancers confer a DNA repair deficiency and a previously unexpected vulnerability to the class of anti-cancer agents called PARP inhibitors. In the proposed work, we will uncover new connections between metabolism and DNA repair in human cells and develop new ways to treat metabolism-driven cancers in a targeted manner to advance effective new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is among the most common and costly challenges confronting modern society. Benzene, one of the major components of air pollution has been found capable of inducing oxidative stress and inflammatory responses, which, may affect insulin resistance (IR), leading to whole-body metabolic imbalance and T2D. To understand the etiology of metabolic disorders, including obesity and T2D, it is essential that we gain insight into the mechanisms by which benzene can cause metabolic imbalance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We plan to establish how the bi-directional transport of the nucleus is orchestrated, which is important for normal brain and muscle development. Human disease mutations of proteins participating in the transport of the nucleus cause severe brain and muscle developmental defects, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), hereditary spastic paraplegia and spinal muscular atrophy, which is the most common genetic cause of death in infants. Results will establish regulatory mechanisms for dynein and kinesin-1-dependent transport, which can be targeted to treat these devastating neuromuscular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: Understanding the allosteric communication mechanisms of how agonist binding to G- protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) allow selective coupling to their cognate G-proteins is the holy grail of functional selectivity in GPCRs. The proposed interdisciplinary research will develop computational methods concurrent with experiments to provide insight into the dynamics and structural basis of how class A GPCRs recognize their cognate G-proteins. The combination of computational methods and experiments will provide an understanding of how agonists with varied efficacies affect the functional selectivity and pave way to designing ligands with functional selectivity for GPCRs for treatment of hypertension, diabetes and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stigma remains a pernicious impediment to health, deterring engagement in services that are vital to ending the HIV epidemic. This K23 plans to integrate frameworks from stigma and implementation science to explore drivers and mitigators of sexual stigma in healthcare, and then to develop and pilot an intervention for health workers that mitigates stigma during their interactions with gay and bisexual men. This approach to intervention development optimizes the likelihood of yielding high acceptability, feasibility, and appropriateness among those intended to benefit from the intervention’s use in healthcare settings, and holds the promise of identifying broadly applicable and theory-based behavior change techniques and mechanisms of action to mitigate stigma among health workers in ways that improve the quality of care and HIV-related outcomes among stigmatized groups.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: This proposal will examine the effects of infection with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (more commonly known as COVID-19) on mental health, cognition, and social integration in recently housed Veterans and Veterans without a history of chronic homelessness. It is evident that the effects of the pandemic on mental health and functioning will be felt for years to come. Many Veterans who have contracted COVID-19 are continuing to exhibit severe cognitive and psychological impacts months after recovering from the acute illness. Furthermore, we do not know the impact of the pandemic on recently housed Veterans, who are considered a vulnerable population. This project will prospectively examine over 18 months cognition, mental health, and social integration in a large sample of vulnerable and non-vulnerable Veterans who have or have not been infected with COVID-19.

PHR: Project Narrative Lymphatic ﬁlariasis is a mosquito-transmitted nematode (roundworm) parasitic disease that infects millions of people worldwide, causing chronic disability and physical disﬁgurement. The goal of this research is to leverage technical advances we have made to (1) gain a better understanding of a parasite tissue system that is essential to how parasites communicate with and manipulate their hosts, and (2) to identify and proﬁle receptors within this system that can potentially be targeted to disrupt the establishment or maintenance of infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The successful duplication of a cell's genome involves replication of both the sequence of the DNA and the structure of the genome. Errors in either of these aspects can result in numerous human diseases. The goal of this proposal is to define how dynamic histone acetylation regulates the epigenetic inheritance of genome structure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our team recently led the clinical development of Sacituzumab Govitecan (SG, aka Trodelvy), the first FDA- approved antibody-drug conjugate (ADC) for triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), leading to substantially improved outcomes for this most aggressive and poor-prognosis breast cancer subtype. Here, we propose to build on this success by testing a new targeted drug combination incorporating SG for resistant tumors, and by developing biomarkers and additional combinations to guide rational use of this new treatment approach. We seek to move potentially transformative new combination therapies rapidly into clinical trials.
