IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anaphylaxis is a potentially life-threatening IgE-mediated systemic allergic reaction with no known preventative therapies. Our preliminary data suggest that pharmacologic inhibitors of Bruton’s tyrosine kinase (BTK) can prevent IgE-mediated human mast cell and basophil activation in vitro and in humanized mouse models in vivo. Specific aims will determine the ability of BTK inhibitors to prevent drug-induced anaphylaxis, in addition to further defining the kinetics and degree of their efficacy as potential therapies for preventing anaphylaxis in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE   Given the involvement of ERK signaling in several diseases including Alzheimer disease, diabetes, obesity and  cancer,  this  proposal  will  establish  a  new  level  of  understanding  of  how  ERK  directly  regulates  activity  of  the  metabolic  pathways  essential  for  cellular  homeostasis.  Our  preliminary  data  place  us  in  the  unique  position  to  uncover and understand at a biochemical and molecular level new regulatory processes, new biomarkers and  new potential strategies that are needed for personalized therapeutic intervention in metabolic diseases that can  be driven by improper ERK signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT High blood pressure is an enormous health care burden in the United States, affecting one in three adults. It is a major cause of stroke, heart attack and kidney disease and despite this, the causes of hypertension remain poorly understood and treatment is not always successful. In our proposed studies, we will further define the inflammation that causes hypertension and develop new strategies to prevent this.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies will provide some of the first insights into mechanisms for how the force of muscle contraction influences gene expression and extracellular matrix assembly during tendon development. Understanding how muscle attachments develop will enhance our ability to discover pharmacological treatments for tendon injuries and atrophy with aging. It will also inform strategies for producing stem/progenitor cells to repair damaged tendons and ligaments as well as genetic disorders of human tendons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  There is an enormous need for students majoring in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM), yet lacking a strong foundation in mathematics makes students, especially women, minorities and those from low-income backgrounds, less likely to pursue careers in STEM. Teachley Problem Solving will bolster students’ mathematics abilities, including mathematical reasoning, problem-solving and self-efficacy in the short and long term. This will, in turn, lead to several positive distal outcomes, such as increased STEM majors and careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The immune system maintains a careful balance between protecting the body from infectious pathogens and the collateral damage that may arise as a result of too much inflammation, particularly autoimmunity. Interleukin (IL)-17 is an important mediator of immune inflammation and protects against various microorganisms. However, an overabundance of IL-17 signaling contributes to the pathogenesis of autoimmunity. Autoimmune kidney damage (glomerulonephritis) is serious consequence of many autoimmune conditions that impact the kidney, and emerging data implicate IL-17 in driving this process. Although we know quite a bit about which cells make IL-17, the molecular process of IL-17 cellular activation in the kidney is poorly defined. This proposal focuses on understanding how regulation of IL-17-driven gene expression promotes pathology in autoimmune kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative A key feature of the immune system is the generation of “memory”, which allows us to become “immune” after the first encounter with a pathogen or vaccine, successfully fending off future encounters with that pathogen. One population of memory cells, called memory T cells, come in a variety of “flavors” which exhibit distinct functional properties – one major subdivision is into memory T cells that patrol the body incessantly (recirculating memory cells) and ones that stay in tissues long-term (resident memory cells) , which can promptly respond to local infections. Key to immune “memory” is that these T cell populations last long-term (decades in humans, years in mice) and preserve their distinct “identities” (e.g. as recirculating or resident cells): however, while this has been a topic of considerable interest for decades, discrepancies in published studies need to be resolved in order to determine how memory T cells are maintained. We will use sophisticated genetic models, as well as pharmaceutical treatments, to accurately determine how distinct subsets of memory T cells are sustained by the soluble factors (called cytokines) IL-7 and IL-15 and how the “identity” of recirculating and resident memory cells is maintained by expression of a DNA binding protein called KLF2 and some of the genes it regulates. These studies will give us an improved understanding of how memory T cell maintenance is maintained and identify areas of potential therapeutic intervention to enhance or reshape the T cell memory population for clinical goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The current next generation sequencing (NGS) data analysis turnaround, not sequencing itself, is too slow for time sensitive clinical applications, such as identifying the optimal treatment for a cancer patient days after biopsying, and according to the unique genomic characteristics of that patient’s tumor. This exploratory development proposal aims to greatly accelerate genomic analysis (60X whole human genome in 10 minutes) using heterogeneous computing techniques. In addition to enabling NGS for time critical clinical applications, our emphasis on an open-source development model, reusable software components, and the acceleration of widely used algorithms will allow for the adoption of accelerated computing by a large developer and user community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: People with physical disabilities may be particularly vulnerable to opioid misuse and overdose, as they have a high prevalence of chronic pain due to musculoskeletal conditions and high exposure to opioid analgesics. However, disabled adults have been largely left out of research into the prevention and treatment of opioid use disorder and overdose. This project will improve understanding of the mechanisms that place low-income, disabled adults at increased risk of opioid overdose, as well as the potential for improved pain management practices and increased receipt of recommended treatments for substance use disorder and chronic pain to reduce overdose risk in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pseudomonas aeruginosa, one of the most problematic antibiotic-resistant Gram-negative pathogens, has a proclivity to form biofilms that are intrinsically tolerant to antibiotics, which is an important reason for the persistence of chronic (biofilm) infections. Our team has discovered proof-of-concept inhibitors of the BfrB-Bfd protein-protein complex which dysregulate bacterial iron metabolism and kill P. aeruginosa in biofilms. This project will improve the proof-of-concept molecules into lead molecules for inhibiting the BfrB-Bfd complex in Gram-negative bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Ascariasis (roundworm) is the most common intestinal parasitic infection globally and causes severe life-long illness in children. The larval stage ascariasis can cause an asthma-like allergic airway disease. This proposal will identify the immunologic mechanisms of Ascaris-induced allergic airway disease in order to develop interventions that are urgently needed to prevent significant illness in children globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Deteriorations in glycemic control are common among adolescents with type 1 diabetes (T1D). Although family-based interventions are empirically supported to bolster disease management during this period, they are not widely implemented. The current study seeks to optimize family-based interventions for adolescents with T1D to provide a judicious, streamlined, and robust program to be implemented within diabetes care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cells respond to and control the tension of their plasma membrane by internalizing parts of their membrane through endocytosis, which regulates the number of receptors on the membrane. When this process is dysregulated, cells tend to lose the molecular identity of their membranes and become metastatic cancer cells, but the physical basis for this transition is not well-understood. This proposed project will combine live cell three-dimensional fluorescence microscopy with mathematical modeling to understand, on a molecular and mechanical level, how which cells regulate their membrane tension by bending and internalizing their plasma membranes during endocytosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This study is designed to test the feasibility and effectiveness of a novel intervention, Motivation Skills Training (MST), for improving functional outcomes for people with a schizophrenia spectrum diagnosis. MST fills a critical gap in the available psychosocial approaches by teaching people how to regulate their own motivational state in the service of personal recovery goal attainment. The knowledge gained will inform the scope of evidence-based services needed to advance recovery outcomes for people with schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder, and therefore alleviate a significant public health burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of mechanisms by which intestinal microorganisms influence dietary fat metabolism is expected to lead to increased understanding and new treatments for human obesity and undernutrition. The proposed research is therefore relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental new knowledge that will enhance health and reduce the burdens of illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Bereaved AD/ADRD caregivers are at elevated risk for clinically pathological and subclinically problematic consequences and their numbers are increasing quickly. This proposal aims uses a model based on self- determination theory to understand the needs of bereaved AD/ADRD caregivers while accounting for the differences in the ways those needs are satisfied among key subgroups. The wider goal of this research is to use the understanding of bereaved AD/ADRD caregivers’ needs to create interventions to satisfy those needs, reducing the clinical and subclinical consequences of bereavement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it reveals new knowledge regarding the cause of brain aneurysms, a condition that leads to a high rate of disability and death in stroke patients upon rupture. In particular, our work for the first time identified the role of a novel degradation pathway that regulates the cell-matrix interaction in brain aneurysms and provides anti-degradation strategy as a novel therapy for treating the disease. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to reducing the burdens of illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative TANK-binding kinase 1 (TBK1), a critical downstream effector of mutant active KRAS, is central to Axl- driven epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in KRAS-mutant Pancreatic Cancer (PDA); however, the mechanism of how TBK1 drives EMT has yet to be elucidated. I hypothesize that Axl-mediated TBK1 drives EMT via direct activation of AKT3 and the stability of downstream transcriptional networks. Despite significant research efforts, the function of EMT in metastasis has yet to be fully elucidated and metastatic cancers and relapse remain the primary cause of cancer related deaths; therefore my postdoctoral studies will be focused on understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying cellular plasticity, EMT, and metastasis to reveal novel strategies to target these programs for effective therapy for metastatic cancer. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative This proposal allows US-China scientists to leverage resources and expertise on both sides to jointly advance environmental health research, with a focus on the inter-generational health effects of mercury, a persistent and widespread environmental pollutant with adverse impact around the globe. If successful, findings from this study will provide critically needed evidence to inform preconception, pregnancy and newborn risk assessment and primary prevention to reduce the adverse health effects of in utero Hg exposure, beginning at critical developmental windows when interventions may have the greatest life-long impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to selectively incorporate heteroatom functionality into unactivated C–H bonds represents a significant advance in chemical synthesis. Developing functional mimics of the monooxygenase reactive intermediates will permit the generation of a new class of catalysts to effect C−H bond functionalization. Correlating the desirable functionality to the underlying electronic structure of reactive intermediates will provide new strategies for catalyst development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malignantly transformed lymphocytes co-opt growth and survival signaling networks used by healthy lymphocytes. We have identified a new protein complex containing Pacs1 and Wdr37 that promotes lymphocyte survival through its effects on endoplasmic reticulum stress response pathways and calcium signaling. This proposal investigates how Pacs1-Wdr37 controls the survival of healthy and transformed lymphocytes with the intention of validating a new therapeutic target for lymphoid malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Stimulating Access to Research in Residency program is designed to provide residents from diverse clinical backgrounds with the tools, mentorship, and support necessary to develop promising careers in aging research. As such, it addresses the need for clinician scientists who combine first-hand perspective on the care of older adults with the methodologic, collaborative, and communication skills necessary to conduct high- impact aging science. By including residencies and departments that do not already have a strong pre-existing tradition of aging research, this proposal also addresses the need for more diverse representation of different clinical perspectives in aging research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) The molecular chaperone Hsp90 is essential for maintaining protein homeostasis, which is critical in many maladies. This project will provide information on complex interplay between regulatory components of the Hsp90 chaperone in cells, which can also be uti- lized to enhance the sensitivity of cells to Hsp90 inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Unhealthful dietary risk factors are rising in parallel with the global diabetes and obesity epidemics, yet the precise aspects of diet that causally influence metabolic disease and overall human health are unknown. Normal human genetic variation known to influence dietary intake will serve as the common human reference to identify comparable dietary traits across diverse studies, which can be combined with unprecedented statistical power for genomic meta-analysis. This approach will uncover novel and robust genetic associations with dietary intake that will enable the identification of diet’s causal role in metabolic health, informing dietary recommendations worldwide and prevent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The career development plan will develop expertise of the investigator in the collection and analysis of passive mobile sensing data, with an emphasis on the application of machine learning methods. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder is a major epidemic in the United States; new, more effective, targeted treatments are critically needed to help prevent craving and relapse as current pharmacological treatments result in ~50% relapse. Focused ultrasound is a new, non-invasive, non-pharmacological method to modulate brain activity with high precision. Here, using an animal model, we will determine whether focused ultrasound can target and repair pathways that are dysfunctional in addiction to reduce craving and prevent relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) Barrett’s esophagus (BE) is a pre-cancerous lesion which gives rise to esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC), one of the most lethal of all cancers. In this proposal, we seek to elucidate the genes and biological pathways that mediate inherited genetic susceptibility to BE, through integration of new analytical tools and data with unique existing resources. Discoveries and insights from this study are expected to inform the development of novel strategies for prevention and treatment and ultimately help reduce the public health burden of BE/EAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Influenza virus can damage the heart, though this is a poorly understood aspect of influenza pathogenesis. We are investigating how and why specific virus strains traffic to the heart from the lung, how these viruses damage the heart, and how the immune system provides both beneficial and nonbeneficial effects during infection. This work will identify new strategies to prevent or treat influenza-associated cardiac dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Reduced kidney function is highly prevalent among patients with heart failure, and has been consistently shown to be one of the most powerful risk factors for poor clinical outcomes. Acute declines in kidney function, on the other hand, remain poorly understood and how they are related to outcomes including longer term kidney function decline and cardiovascular events is controversial. This study will examine acute kidney function declines in the context of three critical factors—congestion, cardiac hemodynamics and neurohormonal activity—in order to better understand mechanisms and develop clinical phenotypes of the acute cardiorenal syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with facial paralysis have a severe facial soft tissue disability that includes impairments in movements, particularly facial expressive behaviors. We have developed and refined novel 3D dynamic and static quantitative (objective) measures and dynamic modeling comparisons for characterization of facial disability and outcomes of treatment in patients with facial paralysis. Thus, the goals of this study are to determine outcomes of mid-facial reanimation surgeries in patients with more extensive and permanent, unilateral, paralysis of varied etiology and presentation using patient-centered 3D objective facial measures/modeling and patient-centered measures of facial appearance and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Parasitic worms, allergens, and some protists all trigger a “type 2” immune response, but we do not yet fully understand the underlying mechanisms of immune sensing and regulation. More than 1 billion individuals are currently infected with worms, and the incidence of allergies is rising worldwide. By studying the role of epithelial tuft cells in type 2 immunity, we hope to discover novel targets for therapeutic intervention in helminth infection and allergy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This study will investigate the impacts of receiving personal information about risk of Alzheimer's disease related to the genetic susceptibility gene APOE, among Latinos who reside in three communities in northern Manhattan. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive risk information based on either (a) self-reported Latino ethnicity and family history of Alzheimer's disease or (b) the same information plus their APOE genotypes. Surveys and in-depth qualitative interviews at 6-weeks, 9-months, and 18-months after they receive risk information will be used to evaluate their responses. The results will provide important information for tailoring genetics education and counseling interventions to Latinos.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection is associated with a myriad of chronic inflammatory organ diseases, which can lead to multi-organ failure in transplant recipients. Inflammatory organ diseases associated with HCMV are a direct consequence of viral replication in tissue and subsequent systemic spread to multiple organ sites mediated by infected circulating blood monocytes. This project will seek to provide a proof-of-concept that targeting unique alterations to the cellular programing of infected cells during HCMV infection can be utilized to simultaneously inhibit virus replication and/or viral dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methamphetamine is a highly addictive psychostimulant that can induce significant neuronal damage. Pilot studies indicated that repeated methamphetamine administration resulted in neuron loss in the substantia nigra pars compacta and locus coeruleus but not the ventral tegmental area or dorsal raphe. Our studies are aimed at understanding why some neuronal populations are vulnerable to methamphetamine-induced neurodegeneration while some are resistant; moreover, by determining mechanisms underlying vulnerability versus resistance we hope to identify neuroprotective strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Postoperative delirium is a common and significant cognitive complication after major surgery in older people. Nonetheless, luck of its underlying pathophysiology delays advances in prevention and treatment of postoperative delirium. In this study, we aim to identify age and gender-dependent microglia-mediated molecular mechanisms underlying postoperative cognitive impairments in mouse models and also examine inhibition of glutaminase may reverse the abdominal surgery-induced microglia-mediated neuroinflammation, which may alleviate age-dependent postoperative cognitive impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular pluripotency in the germline is maintained through processes within cytoplasmic assemblies called germ granules. Core germ-granule proteins are conserved in almost all animals, frequently repurposed during development, and re-expressed in multi-potent cancers. Understanding the function of individual germ-granule proteins, the purpose and conditions of their assembly, and their capacity for cellular reprogramming, will lead to applications that improve reproductive health, regeneration, and cancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Epistasis causes genetic variants to exhibit different effects depending on the genotypic contexts in which they occur. This context dependence makes it hard to achieve a predictive understanding of the relationship between individuals’ genomes and traits. We will improve understanding of epistasis by (1) studying how epistasis causes CRISPR perturbations to show different effects in distinct individuals and (2) using chromosome synthesis to characterize the extent of epistasis between related taxa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: The technology proposed here will lead to new techniques for spatial and temporal control of neuromodulator signaling in the brain. The light sensitive tools we will develop will have multi-functional abilities to allow for discrete control over time and space of critical receptor signaling pathways in the awake- behaving brain. These new optogenetic tools will allow neuroscientists and biologists to have unprecedented resolution in uncovering the basis for brain diseases, and have translational potential for delivery of new treatments for brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) are major pathogens among lung/liver transplant recipients, who continue to experience infections years after transplant. I hypothesize that chronic CRE colonization and late-onset infection are caused by persistence of CRE that colonize the gut early after transplant, a process which is associated with a state of chronic gut dysbiosis and the emergence of antibiotic tolerance. I will longitudinally characterize serial CRE isolates from patients and study the gut microbiome environment in which CRE colonization, persistence, and infection occur, which will lead to future studies evaluating the mechanisms of tolerance among CRE isolates after transplant, and of strategies to modify the microbiome of transplant recipients with CRE infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Project Narrative Bladder pain syndrome (BPS)/interstitial cystitis (IC) is a chronic pelvic pain syndrome, exacerbated by stress, with an enormous impact on quality of life. We hypothesize that increases in urinary frequency and pelvic pain that accompany BPS/IC reflect changes in the expression, function and interactions of neurochemical mediators and the sensory transducer, TRPV4/Ca2+, in the sensory components of the micturition reflex that favor a pro-excitatory state. These studies will provide insights into novel targets with the potential to treat or prevent disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent studies have identified a number of similarities between cancer and cardiovascular disease. Indeed, the uncontrolled growth of ‘stem-like’ cells in the blood vessel wall may cause those vessels to narrow and become obstructed. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This effectiveness trial will increase understanding of the value and cost-effectiveness of diagnostic screening for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) among pregnant women in low and middle-income countries, to reduce adverse pregnancy and infant outcomes. Further, results from this study will provide important data on the role of the vaginal microbiome in Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) testing outcomes and further rationale for studying the vaginal microbiome in pregnant women with CT treatment failure. Together, findings from this R01 are likely to inform changes to STI screening and treatment guidelines in low-middle income countries globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interleukin-2 is an immune hormone that regulates immunity to infection, but also influences the development of inflammatory disorders. Human genetic variation at IL2 and its receptor IL2RA is associated with loss of self- tolerance and increased susceptibility to autoimmune disease. However, these polymorphisms are not in the genes themselves, but are located kilobases away in non-coding DNA. We hypothesize that the function disease- associated variants lie within key gene regulatory regions, and the studies proposed in this application will use state-of-the-art 3D epigenomics and CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing to solve the mystery of how non-coding variation influences IL-2-dependent immune functions, and may suggest new ways that tolerance can be restored, and inflammatory disorders can be treated or avoided.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Macrophages are immune cells that play important roles in defense against infections, inflammation, and repair of injured tissues. The long term goals of this project are to understand how macrophages are regulated to balance inflammatory and reparative functions to promote tissue repair and restore tissue integrity. This project will investigate communication between inflammatory and reparative pathways and injury-associated macrophage subtypes to gain knowledge that can be used to modulate the immune system to promote tissue repair and wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Parkinson’s disease lacks a therapy that could restore dopaminergic neurons permanently lost to the disease process. With a completed development of all steps required for initiating IND-enabling studies, this U01 project in the CREATE Bio Development Track program will accomplish the first cell therapy clinical trials with cGMP frozen autologous midbrain dopaminergic neurons to restore function in patients with Parkinson’s disease. The results from this U01 project will provide necessary information about the safety and feasibility of autologous cell therapy for Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE C. Difficile infection is common in patients undergoing antibiotic treatment and might have severe health consequences, including death. Here we propose to leverage on our recent findings that bacteria-derived metabolites, such as acetate, may decrease severity of C. difficile infection. Our goal is to mechanistically understand how good intestinal bacteria and their metabolites harness immune responses in the gut to contain C. difficile growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: While cognitive impairment is the major manifestation of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), the leading cause of dementia in the elderly, unintentional body weight loss from unclear reasons often precedes the mental decline and can result in faster progression of the disease. The present application seeks to explore the novel hypothesis that brain regions regulating body weight and metabolism, including the hypothalamus, are selectively vulnerable at the early stages of AD. The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the underlying mechanisms for the early weight loss and metabolic dysfunction may suggest new therapies for this currently incurable disease with no effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (PROJECT NARRATIVE) There is growing evidence that pathological accumulation of toxic reactive oxygen species (ROS) is an early event in the hippocampal dentate gyrus (DG) of patients with Alzheimer’s disease. This proposal tests the hypothesis that depletion of the antioxidant all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) in the DG promotes ROS toxicity, mitochondrial dysfunction, and transcriptional dysregulation of ATRA-sensitive genes. Combining novel AD mouse model crosses, single cell transcriptomics, and electrophysiology, this proposal investigates roles of RA in preserving DG-specific learning, DG circuit function, and transcription of RA-sensitive genes across DG cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause serious health problems and life-threatening disease in newborns and immunosuppressed individuals (including cancer and transplant patients). This proposal seeks to understand the transcriptional mechanisms underlying natural killer (NK) cell metabolism in host immunity against CMV infection. Defining the molecular mechanisms by which NK cells respond to pathogens will potentially lead to therapeutic benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Allergic asthma is a chronic inflammatory lung disease, initiated during childhood and directed by T helper type 2 (Th2) cells. The "hygiene hypothesis" proposes that the decreased exposure to dust containing high levels of bacterial endotoxin (LPS) at a very early age increases the incidence of asthma in children, and we have found that this is most likely explained by a natural LPS hyporesponsiveness during infancy. This proposal will determine how natural maternal-interactions and environmental exposure to microbial products can influence the development of allergen-specific Th2 cells and therefore, asthma severity from early infancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite effective anti-retroviral therapy in HIV-infected patients, proviruses persist in a transcriptionally silent, latent state in resting lymphocytes and cells from the central nervous system. Identifying the most effective and selective therapeutic routes to eliminate the latent reservoir requires a comprehensive understanding of the molecular rules normally controlling proviral transcription and how their dysfunction promotes latency establishment and maintenance. In this proposal, we will investigate a previously unexplored host co-factor that is critical for promoting the latency-reactivation switch in response to physiologic immune cell signaling to devise rationale approaches for targeting unique druggable pockets to translate the basic discoveries for pre- clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work will elucidate the epigenetic regulatory mechanisms by long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) that control homeostasis of drug-metabolizing P450 (CYP) enzymes in a positive and negative feedback loop after exposure to drugs. The proposed work will determine the roles of lncRNAs in CYP-mediated drug metabolism and susceptibility to drug induced liver injury (DILI). The generated knowledge will help to identify novel key factors for predicting therapeutic efficacy and adverse drug reactions (ADRs).

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite tuberculosis (TB) being a treatable and preventable disease, recent modeling work estimated that nearly 200,000 children <5 years died of TB during 2015, making it one of the top ten causes of death in children under 5 years globally. Unreliable and incomplete surveillance data for children with TB is a key challenge that currently limits our ability to appropriately manage children with this disease, including those suffering from severe forms such as TB meningitis (TBM) who experiences high mortality and often lifelong disability. This project will use interdisciplinary methods, including modelling and spatial analyses, to provide critical information on the burden, incidence and related mortality of TBM in children at a global, national and sub-national level in South Africa, whilst identifying opportunities to improve prevention and care through in- depth prospective surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity, the leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, is characterized by hypothalamic resistance to the anorexigenic hormone leptin, produced by fat cells, and loss of the satiety hormone uroguanylin, produced by intestinal cells. Receptors for these hormones, leptin receptor and guanylyl cyclase c (GUCY2C), respectively, are uniquely co-expressed by neurons in the hypothalamic ventral premamillary nucleus (PMV), suggesting their function may be linked. Here, we will determine if loss of uroguanylin-GUCY2C signaling in the hypothalamus underlies leptin resistance in obesity and if this resistance, and the associated loss of appetite control, can be reversed using clinically available GUCY2C agonists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Intervertebral disc degeneration, a cascade of cellular, structural and compositional changes, is strongly implicated as a cause of low back pain. Stem cell-based disc regeneration holds promise for low back pain patients, but efficacy is adversely impacted by the nutrient poor, acidic and inflammatory microenvironment of the degenerate disc. The overall objective of this proposal is to develop a novel biological therapy for disc degeneration that maximizes the survival and anabolic potential of therapeutic stem cells by simultaneously neutralizing the degenerate disc microenvironment via the sustained delivery of nutrients, anti-inflammatory drugs and buffering agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative EV is a group of AR inborn errors of cutaneous immunity that underlie persistent and disseminated skin lesions caused by defective yet oncogenic β-HPVs. Despite the identification of several genetic etiologies, suggesting that keratinocytes and T cells jointly contribute to protective immunity against β-HPVs, the molecular and cellular basis of EV remains largely unknown. We will search for novel genetic etiologies of EV, attempt to connect them with known etiologies, and analyze the molecular and cellular mechanisms by which these disorders underlie β- HPVs-driven skin lesions.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative: Improving care for women with urinary incontinence (UI) begins by systematically and equitably screening for this common disease and then partnering with patients on shared decision-making regarding treatment options. In this application, we propose a multi-faceted strategy to implement routine screening for UI in women in sixty-five primary care clinics and then use our unique existing partnership with Wisercare©, an established evidenced-based patient education tool, to inform patients on treatment options and expand access to non-surgical UI treatments through the primary care setting. Our initiative should produce a sustainable transformation in UI care and a replicable model for other health systems.

PROJECT_TITLE: Identify, Teach and Treat (IT2): Automating clinical decision pathways for the care of women

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative This application proposes to isolate neutralizing monoclonal antibodies from the plasma of Zika virus recovered individuals that have been generated from long-lived bone marrow plasma cells, and for the first time, compare the lineages and viral targets of B cell generated antibodies from both circulating and marrow compartments. In addition to this novel work with Zika virus, this proposal will identify broadly neutralizing dengue virus antibodies from the plasma of individuals infected with two different dengue viruses which will inform vaccine design and have the potential to be developed as pan-dengue therapeutics. This award is thus primed to identify a potential paradigm shift in our understanding of the mechanisms by which human B cells develop, mature and respond in acute viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biological interfaces between infectious microbes and their hosts are enriched for bouts of rapid and volatile evolution. In this proposal, we investigate the evolutionary consequences of host- microbial interactions. The work is revealing new antiviral and antimicrobial functions, which might be developed as new interventions to combat infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Many brain disorders result from disruption of genes that regulate cell-cell communications during neural circuit assembly. We are studying genes encoding cell-surface proteins that play important roles in cell-cell communications during dendrite morphogenesis and axon target selection. Understanding how these proteins work will contribute to our understanding of the pathogenesis of brain disorders resulted from disruptions of cell-cell communications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Given the critical role of sleep in enhancing neural recovery, motor learning, neuroprotection, and neuroplasticity, interventions to enhance sleep that target sleep could improve recovery and rehabilitation outcomes for stroke patients. In this proposal, a multidisciplinary group of researchers with expertise in rehabilitation medicine, sleep medicine, nursing, physical therapy, wearable technologies, and implementation science will adapt, implement and evaluate a state-of-the-art intervention to promote sleep for stroke patients undergoing acute rehabilitation. SIESTA-Rehab, adapted from a previous unit-based intervention, bundles two sleep-promoting interventions to address the unique sleep challenges stroke patients face during acute rehabilitation: (1) nursing education and empowerment to reduce unnecessary disruptions; (2) a systematic protocol to screen, diagnose, and treat sleep-disordered breathing if present during acute stroke rehabilitation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal main goal is to investigate the contribution non-coding RNAs and sterol intermediates and derivatives in the regulation of vascular metabolism and immune functions in atherosclerosis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Our group studies the mechanism of meiotic recombination. Defects in meiotic recombination cause chromosome segregation errors during formation of eggs and sperm that lead to birth defects and miscarriage. In addition, meiotic recombination is closely related to mitotic recombinational DNA repair, a process that prevents cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment following stroke is emerging as one of the leading causes of disability in the country. Despite large research efforts, there are currently no approved pharmacotherapies for improving functional outcomes following stroke. This proposal aims to uncover molecular mechanisms underlying stroke-induced synaptic and cognitive deficits to identify potential molecular targets for pharmacologic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Cerebral aneurysms are weakened bulges in arteries in the brain that, if they tear, can cause brain damage or death. We believe that this weakening is due in part to changes in the tissue that makes up the aneurysm and that these changes can be indirectly determined using computational models. This project aims to both measure the key properties of surgically removed aneurysms and develop the models that will be able to predict those properties in intact aneurysms, allowing prediction of future tearing that can be used to guide clinical management of cerebral aneurysms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: In neurons, immediate-early gene transcription factors (IEG-TFs) are expressed in response to depolarization and regulate genes that modify synaptic and cellular function. It is unknown how IEG-TFs disambiguate depolarization that arises from action potentials and synaptic potentials to elicit specific changes in synaptic connectivity. We propose to use electrophysiology, optical, and genomic techniques to investigate how the IEG-TF NPAS4 transforms action potentials and synaptic potentials into gene regulation that drives plasticity of specific synapse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The association between pediatric myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) and monosomy 7 and germline gain of function (GoF) SAMD9/SAMD9L mutations has been made recently, but the molecular and functional consequences of these mutations in hematopoietic cells are not well understood. Furthermore, in many cases additional somatic revertant genetic changes occur that result in hematopoietic recovery. The proposed studies will use an iPSC model system and primary patient samples to characterize the molecular and functional consequences of GoF SAMD9/9L mutations and to describe the resultant clonal architecture and evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To design better malaria vaccines, we propose to learn from nature by studying immune responses against the malaria parasite in people who have developed protection against the disease as a result of life-long exposure. This project will compare antibodies from malaria-protected and susceptible individuals to determine the characteristics of antibodies that a malaria vaccine should elicit. In addition, antibodies that are able to strongly inhibit the parasite will be analyzed in more detail to serve as a blueprint for malaria vaccine design.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Community-wide deworming to significantly reduce and/or break transmission of soil-transmitted helminths in endemic populations can reverse the effects of these infections on host immune responses. In this study, the effect of large-scale, community-wide deworming with albendazole, on the changes to hookworm-modulated host immune response and protective immunity to bystander antigens (tuberculosis and vaccines) will be studied, in both adults and children and furthermore, whether this effect will be sustained in the post deworming period will also be studied. This study will demonstrate the potential additional benefits of deworming and is of particular importance to communities with a high burden of hookworm infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Kidney stones are very common, and most treatments break the stone into smaller fragments that can remain in the kidney and serve as nidi for future stone growth and symptoms recur within 5 years. The goal of this proposal is to overcome the challenges and discover the knowledge needed to develop an ultrasound device known as acoustic forceps to noninvasively target, trap, and reposition the stone from the kidney collecting system in order to facilitate their natural clearance with urine through the ureter. The development of this technology will introduce a fast noninvasive alternative that will eliminate surgical procedures, and reduce the cost associated with stone management protocols while the patient waits to relieve symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Memories are stored at synapses, and synapse loss is hypothesized to be an early hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The major aims of this research are to determine if molecular mechanisms of synapse pruning mediated by an innate immune receptor expressed in neurons and its MHC class I ligands are disrupted in the presence of soluble oligomers of beta amyloid, and to link findings in mouse models of AD to human neurons and pathology by studying brain organoids derived from human iPS cells, as well as autopsy material. Because the homologous receptor in humans also binds soluble oligomers of beta amyloid, this research can offer mechanistic explanations for synapse and memory loss in human AD and may lead to new drug targets for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is making use of computers to analyze data from sickest patients in hospitals. We want to develop methods that work across different demographics groups and hospital settings to identify patterns in the patient data which predict who is at risk for life- threatening conditions such as Sepsis, Septic Shock, Acute Kidney Injury (AKI), Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) and Respiratory Failure (RF), and who might respond to various medications which could make them better. We have a very strong team of doctors and researchers who work closely together, covering all aspects of the proposed research, which we hope will help us improve the lives of the sickest patients in the hospitals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Training the next generation of physician-scientists who will tackle the important clinical issues in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia, frailty, and multimorbidity in aging adults requires a robust and innovative program to provide superb training on an integrated platform. We propose the Massachusetts General Hospital Diseases of Aging Pathway via Stimulating Access to Research in Residency (MGH DAP StARR) program to provide dedicated research time to residents in the Departments of Medicine and Neurology at MGH to foster longitudinal mentorship, skill development, and perform high-quality research related to fundamental questions in dementia and other age-related dysfunctions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An estimated 12 million US adults are living with serious illness, a condition that carries a high risk of mortality and excessively strains their caregivers. Structural racism and racial/ethnic residential segregation may affect health care for patients with serious illness by limiting access to palliative care, the specialty focused on improving quality of life for persons with serious illness and their families and limiting the capacity of family caregivers to engage with the healthcare system. We will conduct at population-based, multi-level, mixed- methods study within and across the state of Massachusetts to disentangle the relationships between residential segregation, neighborhood deprivation, and healthcare utilization in serious illness in order provide evidence that racism, not patient mistrust, is a primary barrier to equitable palliative care and health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), intrusive, traumatic, autobiographical memories lead to anxiety symptoms, and recent work suggests a novel repetitive pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) brain target that might bring relief. Since this proposed target is not well understood, our goal is to use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to identify the brain regions and networks that change with rTMS stimulation at this target in PTSD patients. This project will help us understand how rTMS stimulation at the proposed target affects the brain, and will reveal the benefits of a personalized targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Our studies focus on the molecular basis of memory consolidation and the particular role of a gene termed Arc. We have discovered a new signaling pathway mediated by Arc that appears important for memory and for understanding schizophrenia. Studies will reveal the molecular basis of Arc signaling, its contribution to normal memory, and the impact of its dysfunction in relation to schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health In the US, the lifetime cost of epilepsy for an estimated 181,000 people with an onset in 1995 is projected at $11.1B and the annual cost for an estimated 2.3 million prevalent cases is estimated at $12.5B. In many of these cases, the treatment procedure requires identifying the abnormal brain region involved and removing it via neurosurgery. Epilepsy surgery costs over $100,000 per case and since the surgery is complex and often involves two phases, image analysis software is critical to integrate multimodal imaging and EEG recording for pre- and intra-operative decision support. In this proposal, we aim to build such a product.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Mas-related G protein coupled receptors (MRGs) represent, in humans, a 10-member family of receptors that are involved in sensing nociceptive stimuli such as pain and itch. MRG-family receptors are also important for the actions and side-effects of several drugs of abuse. Here we will solve the structures of representative MRG-family receptors and leverage this information to understand their signaling and to develop selective chemical probes to modulate their function, with potential utility as therapeutic leads.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative By studying healthcare organizations, the nurses providing care in them, and the patients experiencing that care over time, we aim to understand the causal nature of effects that investments in nursing have on patient outcomes and health disparities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The essential spliceosome protein SF3B1 functions as a hub to coordinate the positioning and dynamic rearrangements of numerous RNA and protein splicing factors. SF3B1, as well as many of its interacting cofactors, are frequently mutated, amplified, or deleted in cancers and in developmental syndromes, yet rather than affecting all introns equally, these disease-associated alterations in the core of the spliceosome have different and specific effects on subsets of introns. Understanding the intronic codes that confer sensitivity to these naturally occurring genetic changes will provide insight into the mechanisms of spliceosome function as well as the biological pathways distorted by spliceosome dysfunction that may present new therapeutic vulnerabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The human genome sequence was originally thought to be a user manual for understanding and curing human diseases, but translating its contents into the testable experiments required to discover new medicines is tedious, expensive, and sometimes impossible for certain “undruggable” genes. My laboratory is developing distributable technology that will democratize this process, and further render it “plug-and-play” to target any disease-related gene encoded in the genome. This new therapeutic strategy is likely to have broad applicability to the discovery of new antibiotics, antivirals, anti-cancer agents, and cholesterol-lowering drugs to name a few.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop novel methods based on unsupervised machine learning to derive embeddings for medical concepts and patient clinical histories that combine heterogeneous multi-modal healthcare data. These methods will generate novel data representations that can benefit clinical predictive analyses as well as medical research and discovery. We will build a publicly-available framework to share and combine embeddings via federated learning which will lead to representations that also capture diverse populations and promise to reduce several biases of machine learning models in healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mandibular anomalies are common birth defects that require comprehensive, sometimes repetitive corrective surgeries to manage individual cases, often placing a heavy financial and emotional burden on patients and their families. Development of therapeutic efforts requires a thorough understanding of mandibular development and the timing of events in dysmorphogenesis. We offer innovative approaches for determining the molecular, cellular, and developmental bases of morphogenesis of the mandible and its cartilaginous precursor, Meckel’s cartilage, in normal individuals and in craniofacial conditions with a small mandible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Fetal overnutrition due to maternal diabetes or obesity increases the risk of newborn and adult heart disease in the developing baby, and even more, this risk can be passed on to the next generation. Our previous and preliminary work indicates that damaged mitochondria and their byproduct, reactive oxygen species (ROS) play a causative role. This project will determine 1) whether ROS damages DNA to trigger the problem for not only one, but several generations, and 2) if limiting dietary fat during pregnancy or 3) taking antioxidants during family planning can mitigate the risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Heart failure is still the major cause of death worldwide, with a pressing need for new therapeutic approaches. Recent studies reported that stimulation of lymphatic growth improve heart function in ischemic heart disease, however, the mechanisms have not been fully understood. In this proposal, we will take advantage of variety lymphatic loss- and gain- of function mouse strains to characterize in details the lymphatic functions during heart injury progression, and determine the underlying mechanism by which lymphatic vasculature improve cardiac repair.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Marmosets, squirrel monkeys, and owl monkeys are small South American monkeys used in reproduction, metabolism, infectious disease, aging and neuroscience studies. Identification of biomarkers of inflammation and metabolic hormones is critical for validation of animal models in biomedical research; however, available immunological reagents for biomarkers from these New World Monkeys are scarce. This application proposes to fill this void by generating recombinant NWM proteins, producing mouse monoclonal antibodies against them, validating immunological assays using these reagents, and distributing reagents and related scientific information to interested investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The mammalian retina is comprised of hundreds of distinct neuronal subtypes that are precisely assembled into functional circuits. This project examines how selectively expressed transcription factors are involved in the specification and morphological maturation of specific neuronal subtypes in the retina during development. These studies will provide important insight that can be used to guide regenerative therapies in the nervous system following injury or disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop advanced analyses that combine time-resolved phase-contrast MRI (4D flow MRI) and computational fluid dynamics to provide increased 4D flow resolution. In this research program, we aim to generate super-resolution velocity maps - maps higher resolution than the acquired 4D flow MRI for improved quantification of cerebral hemodynamics. This will better identify, on a patient-specific basis, hemodynamic descriptors that can be used to guide patients to urgent surgical intervention and differentiate them from others where watchful waiting is preferred.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The long-term goal of my research program is to develop methods and tools for comparative analysis of molecular sequences. In this project, we will develop a new class of phylogenomic methods based on sparse machine learning and benchmark their absolute and relative performance. New techniques and their software implementation will greatly facilitate data analyses that are vital for evolutionary and functional genomics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The relationship between sleep and epilepsy can provide key insights into how network dynamics influence epileptic activity; however, the mechanisms that underly this relationship are largely unknown. In this proposal, I will investigate this interplay by 1) probing physiologic sleep-wake states that are naturally associated with different epileptic potential in patients with epilepsy and 2) elucidating pathologic, state-dependent network features that are predictive of epileptic activity. This investigation will take steps toward a long-term goal of devising rational strategies for neuromodulation-based therapies that reconfigure the epileptogenic network toward having favorable dynamics with low epileptogenic potential in patients with drug-resistant epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Providers and policymakers in Puerto Rico are seeking to dramatically expand investments in primary care as part of their recovery from Hurricane Maria, but the ability of Puerto Rico’s physician organizations to undertake large-scale primary care transformation remains unclear. The proposed study will measure changes in physician supply, access, quality of care, and care coordination before and after Hurricane Maria in four types of physician organizations (federally qualified health centers, small independent medical groups, large independent medical groups, and vertically integrated medical groups) to identify high and low-performing physician organizations. We will conduct interviews with leaders of these organizations to identify the advanced primary care infrastructure they have sought to implement as well as implementation barriers, and we will interview Medicare beneficiaries living with Alzheimer’s disease (or Alzheimer’s disease related dementias) and their caregivers to better understand their unmet care needs and how these needs differ across the four types of physician organizations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative It is proposed that by lowering indole and p-cresol in the intestines, the formation of indoxyl sulfate and p-cresol sulfate in the liver can be reduced, hence lowering two important protein- bound uremic retention solutes that otherwise cannot be efficiently removed with dialysis. We will utilize polymer and hydrogel engineering to tailor hydrogel beads that can be ingested as bubble teas, and later be excreted intact from the GI tract. The beads will contain immobilized bacteria and chemistry to degrade indole, p-cresol or their amino acid precursors to non-toxic, beneficial, or probiotic components and their performance will be tested by mathematical modelling and in bioreactor assays which simulate the trip through the gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: In this proposal, we will investigate mechanisms of oral cancer initiation and progression for the identification of novel candidate drivers of the disease amenable to therapeutic targeting. We will apply system-level computational approaches, including novel taxonomy discovery and Markov network inference and comparison methods, to analyze existing multi-omics mouse and human datasets. Our primary, yet not exclusive, focus will be on the definition of the molecular links between somatic variation, ? ? -catenin/CBP, TAZ/YAP, and mTOR activity, and EMT and CSC phenotypes in early and advanced stages of OSCC, and the hypotheses we generate will be evaluated in in-vitro and in-vivo models we have developed in our laboratories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE The mislocalization of key signaling and structural outer segment proteins underlie some of the most severe types of inherited retinal diseases, including the most frequently encountered cases of retinitis pigmentosa – a blinding disease affecting nearly two million people worldwide. Elucidating the intracellular mechanisms guiding these proteins in healthy cells we, as a community, will be better positioned to develop new therapeutic strategies. Furthermore, understanding how the light-sensitive outer segment is normally populated with structural and signaling proteins will be paramount as the community begins to explore new regenerative approaches such as stem cell-derived organoids to treat patients with retinal diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PCDH19-clustering epilepsy (PCE) is a severe developmental and epileptic encephalopathy predominantly affecting girls and caused by pathogenic variants in an X-linked gene. Using a mouse model that we recently developed, we propose to study how this unique inheritance pattern leads to abnormal interneuron development and susceptibility to seizures. This work will provide insight into disease mechanisms and may identify a therapeutic target to treat patients with PCE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Head and neck cancers are a particular threat to individuals in low-income underserved communities, due to the high prevalence of risk factors such as smoking and human papillomavirus infection. We will develop and validate a device, referred to as Raman Assay using Plasmonics for Identification and Diagnosis (RAPID) using ultrabright surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) “nanorattle” probes for multiplexed detection of squamous cell carcinoma and thyroid cancer, which account for more than 90% of all head and neck cancers. Ultimately, , we envision the RAPID technology to be deployed as a low-cost diagnostic tool capable of head and neck cancer identification, with the potential to reduce the morbidity and mortality of this disease in currently underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cells of the innate immune system can be reprogrammed by exposure to stimuli such as cytokines or pathogens in a phenomenon known as “trained immunity.” This can make immune cells either more inflammatory or less inflammatory in response to subsequent infections, but what determines whether a given stimulus will result in potentiated or diminished inflammation is unclear. This proposal explores the hypothesis that dynamic features of the transcription factor NFκB – not if it is activated, but how it is activated – contribute to the stimulus-specificity of trained immunity through the regulation of latent enhancers that control gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: Project Narrative Development of an effective antiviral drug for COVID-19 is widely considered to be a global health priority. COVID-19 severity and death is principally due to a proinflammatory cytokine storm in the lung, which is caused by CFTR loss and consequent activation of NFκB and ENaC signaling. Cardiac glycoside drugs such as ouabain and digitoxin potently block infection by inhibiting the viral spike from binding to ACE2. By inhibiting viral entry, the cardiac glycosides prevent loss of CFTR, and thereby also prevent activation of NFκB and ENaC signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The mechanism of cardiotoxicity due to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) remains poorly understood due varied clinical symptoms cause due to inflammation. The goal of this project is to unravel the underlying mechanisms by systematically studying the effect of ICIs using multicellular cardiac organoids (CO) derived from patient-specific induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs). The results of the study may lead to development of drugs to preserve heart function in cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Every tumor is biologically unique. Moving from “one-size-fits-all” to personalized medicine in cancer, we need to develop novel platforms to help us improve our understanding of cellular characterizations of individual’s cancer biology and therapeutics. In this project we will develop a personalized ex vivo platform including individual’s cancerous epithelium and the tumor microenvironment. We will show the utility of our system for testing conventional and novel therapeutics. The patient-specific drug response assay technology has the potential to inform the way treatment decisions are made within the context of pancreatic cancer and perhaps other complex solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Morphea is a disorder of inflammation followed by fibrosis of the skin and soft tissue that produces devastating effects on appearance and joint function in children and adults when untreated. The biggest challenge for those taking care of patients with morphea is that the molecular underpinnings of the disorder have not been systematically investigated, which creates a huge barrier to the development of targeted, less toxic treatments. The combination of single cell RNA sequencing of skin and fibroblast culture models obtained from morphea patients in this study provides a unique opportunity to understand cellular mechanisms driving morphea pathogenesis, and will identify potential drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The xenicanes are a diverse family of anticancer diterpenes from soft corals with complex, heavily oxidized scaffolds that are unique to marine eukaryotes. In this proposal, I describe my strategy to engineer the terpene synthase that assembles xeniaphyllene (the hydrocarbon core common to all xenicanes), identify and characterize the oxidase(s) that generate the characteristic xenicane scaffold by catalyzing an unprecedented carbon–carbon bond cleavage, and assemble these enzymes into a refactored biosynthetic pathway for microbial production of xenicanes. Through this work we will gain key insights into the enzymology of terpenoid biosynthesis and enable the scalable and sustainable production of coral diterpenoids, facilitating the discovery and development of pharmaceutically relevant marine natural products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: In humans, social attachment with partners, relatives, or friends act as a protective buffer against many negative consequences of life stress, whereas lack of social attachments can lead to serious pathologies including dysphoria, anxiety, depression, sleep disturbance, cardiovascular problems, and immune system deficits. In this proposal, using a highly social animal model, we will examine the role of a specific oxytocinergic circuitry in the brain that may play a key role in mediating some consequences of partner separation and isolation stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Carriers of the APOE4 gene are at a significantly increased risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease. In order to understand the cause of this increased Alzheimer’s risk, we will conduct a comprehensive investigation of how the APOE genotype affects normal biological pathways in the brain, defining how these effects progress with time and within brain regions and cell-types. Using a new APOE mouse line and cutting-edge technology, these experiments will dramatically improve our understanding of why APOE4 carriers are more susceptible to AD and how this susceptibility can be prevented.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is often associated with Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy (CAA), in which the blood circulation becomes impaired because there is amyloid deposition on the blood vessels. Using a newly-developed mouse strain, we will determine if macrophages keep the blood vessels healthy, and, when macrophages fail, AD and CAA ensue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to provide a quantitative understanding of coronavirus biology using single-cell and single-molecule approaches in vitro and with in vivo murine models. We will develop computational models combined with an imaging-based platform to quantitatively assess replication kinetics and spatiotemporal host cell responses of SARS-CoV-2. This platform will then be applied to the study of clinically relevant human genetic variation and pre-existing anti-interferon autoantibodies, emerging viral variants of concern, and to explore the age-associated differences in susceptibility to severe COVID-19 disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE FBN1 is the causative gene for Marfan syndrome, an inherited disorder of fibrillin-1 microfibrils leading to progressive thoracic aortic aneurysm and an elevated risk for aortic dissection and rupture. Based on our recent discovery that the protease ADAMTS6 binds to and cleaves fibrillin-1, and thus regulates microfibril abundance, we will test whether preventing ADAMTS6 cleavage of fibrillin-1 in Marfan syndrome will protect microfibrils from degradation. The clinical promise of this research is that enhancing microfibril abundance by specific targeting of ADAMTS6 in the aortic wall may protect against aortic aneurysm progression or dissection in patients with Marfan syndrome as a novel disease-modifying approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The pathogens Acinetobacter baumannii and Klebsiella pneumoniae, particularly when carbapenem-resistant, cause significant morbidity and mortality for patients. They have recently acquired a number of novel resistance mechanisms that render many of our most active antimicrobials less useful. We will employ the latest mechanistic, translational research approaches via a highly integrated set of three Projects and three Cores to design novel therapeutic regimens to restore our ability to successfully treat these bacterial ‘superbugs’.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is a valvular heart disease caused by the Strep A bacteria that affects over 40 million people, most of whom live in low-resource settings. Regular administration of injectable antibiotics can improve outcomes for children with the earliest forms of RHD, but we do not know if oral antibiotics (which are more practical) can do the same. This study (GOALIE) will determine the effectiveness of injectable as compared to oral antibiotics and measure the costs, impact on quality of life, and patient and parent satisfaction of both approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RNA silencing regulates essentially every biological process in eukaryotes, and their dysregulations causes numerous diseases and physiological disorders in human and in plants. The proposed study is to determine how several newly identified components such as RNA helicases, catalases, U1-70K, and BICE1 contribute to the production of small RNAs for RNA silencing in Arabidopsis. The studies on the new regulatory mechanisms in RNA silencing in the model organism Arabidopsis may enable us to manipulate these components for a better therapeutic strategy to cure physiological disorders that arise from dysfunctions of RNA processing in biotechnology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcriptional regulation of gene expression is central to complex biological processes, such as development, drug responses, and surviving cellular stress. Organisms must properly respond in a coordinated and stabilizing manner to a diversity of cues and insults. The goal of this work is to understand the mechanisms by which factors establish and maintain appropriate levels of gene transcription.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is designed to answer important questions about the connections between making ribosomes and human disease. Ribosomes are the cellular factories that synthesize proteins in all human cells. As both cancer and genetic diseases of newborn babies are linked to abnormalities in the making of ribosomes, our work will be crucial for elucidating the underlying mechanisms of these diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Injury to the central nervous system can produce severe disabilities, and there is a tremendous need for effective rehabilitation interventions to preserve and improve function, independence, and quality of life. The likelihood of surviving a traumatic brain injury, stroke, or spinal cord injury has continually increased due to advancements in emergency medical care in both military and civilian settings. As a result, many Veterans (including those injured while young) are living with injury-related disabilities that interfere with quality of life, engagement in societal roles, and that predispose them to the development of additional neurological and systemic illnesses as they age. The Brain Rehabilitation Research Center (BRRC) seeks to develop practical and effective strategies to rehabilitate chronic cognitive, emotional, and motor disabilities in Veterans affected by central nervous system injuries by capitalizing on the brain’s ability to show physiological and structural recovery in response to appropriately designed treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Overview Narrative This is study of blood immune cells and brain function in patients with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus in long term clinical remission on no corticosteroids or immunosuppressive medication. We believe that studying this population will provide insights into patient heterogeneity, new patterns of immune homeostasis to inform therapeutic strategies and the state of central nervous system inflammation in those with no detectable peripheral organ inflammation. As 25% of patients will flare over 5 years, we will look for predictors of relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed program project will use synergistic experimental and modeling approaches with human clinical samples and metadata, a collection of clinical fungal strains, and reductionist murine models to understand Candida gastrointestinal colonization. These studies will characterize fungal adaptations, immune activation, commensal bacteria, and their biosynthetic products that regulate the Candida host-pathogen interface. This work will have broad implications for closing knowledge gaps to prevent and mitigate invasive candidiasis.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research program can potentially lead to the development of platforms to support high-level production of various natural products including polysaccharides, terpenoids, and plant polyketides in bacteria.
